page.title: 2012 United States Women's Curling Championship – Qualification
2014 United States Men's Curling Championship – Qualification

revision.text:
{{2014USNCC}} {{Main|2014 United States Men's Curling Championship}} '''Qualification''' for the '''2014 [[United States Men's Curling Championship]]''' consisted of three different paths. Four teams qualified directly through the High Performance Program or the Order of Merit system. The number of the remaining entrants to the national championships was cut down to six teams through a challenge round held in early January.
==Qualification system== Teams can qualify to participate in the men's national championship through the High Performance Program, through the [[World Curling Tour]] Order of Merit, or through a challenge round.
Two spots in the nationals were awarded to two teams on the [[United States Curling Association]]'s High Performance National Program. The teams qualified through the High Performance Program were those skipped by [[John Shuster]] and [[Pete Fenson]]. Two more spots were awarded to the top two men's teams on the World Curling Tour Order of Merit standings table at the year's end. The teams qualified through the Order of Merit were those skipped by [[Heath McCormick]] and [[Brady Clark (curler)|Brady Clark]].
The remaining six spots in the nationals will be awarded to the teams that earn qualification spots through the [[#Challenge Round 2|challenge round]]. The challenge round will be held in a triple knockout format.
==Challenge Round== The challenge round for the men's nationals will be held from January 9 to 12 at the [[Four Seasons Curling Club]] in [[Blaine, Minnesota|Blaine]], [[Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teamusa.org/USA-Curling/Features/2014/January/07/Challenge-Round-begins-Thursday|title=Challenge Round begins Thursday|date=7 January 2014|publisher=[[USA Curling]]|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref>

revision.comment: article now exists on English Wikipedia
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} '''''27''''' (or '''''Twenty-Seven''''') is an [[opera]] by composer [[Ricky Ian Gordon]] and [[libretto|librettist]] [[Royce Vavrek]] in a prologue and five acts that explores the relationship of [[Gertrude Stein]] and [[Alice B. Toklas]], and the [[Salon (gathering)|salons]] that they hosted at their residence at [[27 rue de Fleurus]] in Paris. Commissioned by [[Opera Theatre of Saint Louis]] for [[mezzo-soprano]] [[Stephanie Blythe]], the opera premiered on June 14, 2014, in a production directed by James Robinson at the Loretto-Hilton Center in St. Louis, Missouri.{{Cite web|url=http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2014/6/Features/Lucky_Number.html|title=Lucky Number : F. Paul Driscoll talks to the cast and creative team of ''27'' — a new opera by Ricky Ian Gordon and Royce Vavrek about the singular world of Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas. The curtain goes up at Opera Theatre of Saint Louis on June 14.|publisher=Operanews.com|accessdate=29 October 2014}} [[Pittsburgh Opera]] staged the work in February 2016.[http://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/Twenty-Seven ''Twenty-Seven''], performance details, [[Pittsburgh Opera]] The work was premiered in New York City in October 2016 at [[New York City Center]] with Stephanie Blythe, [[Heidi Stober]], Theo Lebow, {{Interlanguage link multi|Tobias Greenhalgh|de}}, and Daniel Brevik. [[Ted Sperling]] conducted the [[Orchestra of St. Luke's]] and Gordon composed new material specially for the [[Collegiate Chorale|MasterVoices]] chorus.[http://www.nycitycenter.org/tickets/productionNew.aspx?performanceNumber=10076#.V9z1r0197CM ''27''], New York City Center performance details, October 2016 ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Roles ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast, 14 June 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.opera-stl.org/about/news-press/2014/02/21/opera-theatre-of-saint-louis-announces-finalcasting-and-production-artists-for-2014-festival-season/|title=Opera Theatre of Saint Louis Announces Final Casting and Production Artists for 2014 Festival Season|author=|publisher=Opera-stl.org|accessdate=29 October 2014}}
([[Conducting|Conductor]]: [[Michael Christie (conductor)|Michael Christie]]) |- |Gertrude Stein||mezzo-soprano||Stephanie Blythe |- |Alice B. Toklas||soprano||[[Elizabeth Futral]] |- |[[Pablo Picasso]], [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]], et al.||[[tenor]]||Theo Lebow |- |[[Leo Stein]], [[Man Ray]], et al.||[[baritone]]||Tobias Greenhalgh |- |[[Henri Matisse]], [[Ernest Hemingway]], et al.||[[bass-baritone]]||Daniel Brevik |} ==Critical reception== ''[[The St. Louis American]]'' called the world premiere production of ''27'' a "flawless commissioned portrait of Gertrude Stein,"{{cite web|url=http://www.stlamerican.com/entertainment/living_it/article_47cc059e-f883-11e3-bbad-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Opera Theatre St. Louis stages flawless commissioned portrait of Gertrude Stein|work=The St. Louis American|accessdate=29 October 2014}} while Ray Mark Rinaldi of ''[[The Denver Post]]'' said that the opera "tells a great American story, as well as American opera in the 21st century" suggesting that "it is every century's job to define the century before it, and ''27'' isn't afraid to do that with certainty and depth."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/artmosphere/2014/06/24/27-tells-american-story-touching-american-way/11181/|title=''27'' tells a great American story, about Gertrude Stein as well as American opera in the 21st century|work=Artmosphere|accessdate=29 October 2014}} In her review for the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'', Sarah Bryan Miller called the work "serious fun" praising Gordon's creation of "hummable tunes and recurring themes, drama and sweetness, in a well-wrought score. Vavrek is Steinian without stealing Stein and keeps the story moving, for a clever, witty libretto,"{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/arts-and-theatre/opera-review-opera-theatre-s-is-serious-fun/article_d0793253-c2ca-50d6-bb42-29a34c027469.html|title=Opera review: Opera Theatre's '27' is serious fun|author=|work=stltoday.com|accessdate=29 October 2014}} while [[Anne Midgette]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote that "[Gordon] clearly found much to inspire him in this libretto and subject, to judge from a score that has an engaging vitality from the opening bars, and is delightfully studded with allusions (a touch of ''[[Lakmé]]'', a hint of ''[[Vanessa (opera)|Vanessa]]'') and adroit vocal ensembles."{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/style/wp/2014/06/18/gertrude-stein-sings-in-new-opera-in-st-louis/|title=Gertrude Stein sings in new opera in St. Louis|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=29 October 2014}} Heidi Waleson of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' commented that "[t]he first thing that you notice about Ricky Ian Gordon's ''27'', an opera about Gertrude Stein that recently had its world premiere at Opera Theatre of Saint Louis, is that it moves. Royce Vavrek, the librettist, taking his cue from Stein's own short phrases and cells of text, created a playful, quick-witted libretto that pushed Mr. Gordon beyond his trademark melodies into a brighter, friskier style."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/opera-review-gertrude-stein-in-st-louis-1403562334|title=Opera Review: Gertrude Stein in St. Louis|date=23 June 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 October 2014}} Critic Scott Cantrell of ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' wrote that "''27'' is an unabashedly populist treatment of a yeasty artistic period, in musical idioms that wouldn't have raised an eyebrow in 1920s Paris,"{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/columnists/scott-cantrell/20140618-gertrude-stein-alice-b.-toklas-come-to-operatic-life-in-st.-louis.ece|title=Gertrude Stein, Alice B. Toklas come to operatic life in St. Louis|work=The Dallas Morning News|accessdate=29 October 2014}} and further described Gordon's score as "tuneful, Frenchified neoclassicism" likening it to the work of [[Lennox Berkeley]] and [[Aaron Copland]]. All five singers received unanimous praise, with Blythe garnering rapturous notices for her portrayal of Stein, and Futral celebrated for her performance as Toklas: "It is no small matter that the piece was written for Stephanie Blythe, an outsize personality herself, whose grand, multifaceted mezzo brings the character to vibrant life." (Waleson, ''Wall Street Journal''){{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/opera-review-gertrude-stein-in-st-louis-1403562334|title=Opera Review: Gertrude Stein in St. Louis|date=23 June 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 October 2014}} "Stephanie Blythe is Gertrude; Elizabeth Futral is Alice. Individually and together, they are brilliant, as is the rest of the cast." (Robert W. Duffy, St. Louis Public Radio){{cite web|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/reflection-27-opera-theatre-again-uses-powerful-art-challenge|title=Reflection: In ''27'', Opera Theatre Again Uses Powerful Art To Challenge|author=Robert W. Duffy|publisher=News.stlpublicradio.org|accessdate=29 October 2014}} "[A] good vehicle for Blythe, who can handle the turns and whose natural magnetism goes a long way toward helping us understand the power Stein had over her world. Futral, one of the better singing actresses working today, makes the relationship believable." (Rinaldi, ''Denver Post'') "[W]ith sublime, powerful, expressive voices, superstars Stephanie Blythe and Elizabeth Futral were a joy to behold, deserving of their robust ovations. [...] Remember the names Theo Lebow, Tobias Greenhalgh and Daniel Brevik. They excelled at portraying all the male characters distinctively and effortlessly, showcasing solid acting and strong singing in intricate, demanding supporting roles." (Lynn Venhaus, ''[[Belleville News-Democrat]]''){{cite web|url=http://www.bnd.com/2014/06/24/3272626/opera-theatre-review-veteran-and.html|title=Metro-east news from Belleville, IL|work=Belleville News-Democrat|accessdate=29 October 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Portal bar|Opera}} [[Category:2014 operas]] [[Category:Operas set in France]] [[Category:Operas based on real people]] [[Category:Operas about writers]] [[Category:Operas set in the 20th century]] [[Category:Operas by Ricky Ian Gordon]] [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Gertrude Stein]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Henri Matisse]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Ernest Hemingway]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Pablo Picasso]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of F. Scott Fitzgerald]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} The '''Aluth Sahal Mangalle''' or the '''New Rice Festival''' is a [[harvest festival]] of the [[Maha kannaya]] in [[Sri Lanka]]. The first batch of new rice after being plucked, [[threshed]] and [[winnowed]] is offered to the Lord Buddha and deities.<ref>[http://sridaladamaligawa.lk/annual-new-rice-festival-sri-dalada-maligawa Annual New Rice Festival of Sri Dalada Maligawa]</ref>
Every January [[Poya Day]], new rice festival commences. Rice and paddy donated to [[Temple of the Tooth]] are stored at [[Kundasale]] [[Pallekele]] in a separate location allocation and distribution of Rice and paddy to [[Devales]] relevant, is done. A traditional procession takes place from the Palace to Kundasale headed by [[Diyawadaered]] to the sacred tooth relic.
Only after the new rice festival at the Sri Dalada Maligawa and offering rice to the sacred tooth relic, can the farmers around the country collect their harvest and commence their own new rice festivals in the respective villages.
The most important new rice festival that happens afterwards is the Aluth Sahal Mangalle at the [[Sri Maha Bodhi]] in [[Anuradhapura]].
This festival was started by a king called Sri weera parakrama narendrasinghe in 1707. Diyawadana Nilame does the main part in this festival. This is about the first harvest in paddy situated in kundasale. Diyawadana nilame and the rest of the people got Kundasale with perahara and take the harvest and come back to the temple of tooth relic. This is done in nice fashion always, according to the tradition these traditions are done in much respect, for tooth relic of Lord Buddha. A man called Nakath Mohottala also does a main part in this festival. He prepares an agenda called 'Nakth pathraya' and whole things were done on it.

Over 420,000 civilians displaced or fled to other countries{{cite web|url=http://m.motherjones.com/politics/2015/01/airstrikes-syria-kobani-statistics-operation-inherent-resolve|title=Most US Airstrikes in Syria Target a City That's Not a "Strategic Objective" - Mother Jones|work=Mother Jones}}At least 20,000 civilians displaced during the [[Al-Hasakah offensive (February–March 2015)]]; 5,000+ in the [[Khabur (Euphrates)|Khabur Valley]] region,[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/124095/World/Region/Kurdish-forces-capture-key-IS-Syria-bastion-Monito.aspx] and 15,000+ in the [[Tal Hamis|Tell Hamis]] region [https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/02/27/activists-kurdish-fighters-advance-on-is-held-syrian-town] |notes = Number of militants killed possibly higher, due to them covering up their losses.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/24/world/middleeast/syria-us-strikes-death-toll.html|title=At Least 500 Militants Killed in U.S.-Led Strikes in Syria, Observer Group Says|first=Ben|last=Hubbard|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 September 2014|accessdate=22 December 2014}} |campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Syrian Civil War}} }} The '''American-led intervention in the Syrian Civil War''' refers to US support of [[Syrian opposition]] and the [[Rojava|Federation of Northern Syria]] during the course of the [[Syrian Civil War]], and active involvement of US military against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] and against the [[al-Nusra Front]] from 2014. Since 2017, the US and some other Coalition nations have also targeted military positions of the Syrian Government. The [[United States]] first supplied the rebels of the [[Free Syrian Army]] with non-lethal aid (including food rations and pickup trucks), but quickly began providing training, cash, and intelligence to selected Syrian rebel commanders. During the [[Syrian Civil War]], which began in 2011, two US programs attempted to assist the Syrian rebels. One was a military program that planned to train and equip 15,000 Syrian rebels, but was canceled in 2015 after spending $500 million and producing only a few dozen fighters. A $1 billion covert program run by the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] was more successful, but was decimated by Russian bombing and canceled in mid-2017 by the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/02/world/middleeast/cia-syria-rebel-arm-train-trump.html|title=Behind the Sudden Death of a $1 Billion Secret C.I.A. War in Syria|last=Goldman|first=Mark Mazzetti, Adam|date=2 August 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=3 August 2017|last2=Schmidt|first2=Michael S.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The United States began surveillance missions on [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) positions in Syria in September 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/09/10/president-obama-we-will-degrade-and-ultimately-destroy-isil|title=President Obama: "We Will Degrade and Ultimately Destroy ISIL"|publisher=[[White House Press Secretary|White House office of the Press Secretary]]|date=10 September 2014|accessdate=24 September 2014}} On 22 September 2014, the United States, Bahrain, Jordan, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates began to attack the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant forces inside Syria,{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/us-airstrikes-syria/story?id=25686031|title=U.S. airstrikes hit ISIS inside Syria for first time|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|first = Martha|last = Raddatz|last2 = Martinez|first2 = Luis|last3 = Ferran|first3 = Lee}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/twitter-user-live-tweets-attack-before-pentagon-breaks-news-9749973.html|title=Syria air strike: Twitter user Abdulkader Hariri live tweets US Islamic State attack 'before Pentagon breaks news'|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|last = Saul|first = Heather|newspaper = [[The Independent]]}} as well as the [[Khorasan (Islamist group)|Khorasan]] group in the [[Idlib Governorate]] to the west of Aleppo and the [[al-Nusra Front]] around [[Raqqa]],{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/syria-strikes-u-s-reports-significant-damage-in-attacks-on-islamic-state-khorasan-1411486035|title=Syria Strikes: U.S. Reports Significant Damage in Attacks on Islamic State, Khorasan|date=24 September 2014|accessdate=26 September 2014|last = E. Barnes|first = Julian|last2 = Dagher|first2 = Sam|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isis-terror/u-s-bombs-isis-sites-syria-targets-khorasan-group-n209421|title=U.S. Bombs ISIS Sites in Syria and Targets Khorasan Group|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=26 September 2014|last = Miklaszewski|first = Jim|last2 = Vinograd|first2 = Cassandra}} as part of the [[military intervention against ISIL]]. The [[2017 Shayrat missile strike|missile strike on the Shayrat Airbase]] conducted by the U.S. on 7 April 2017, was the first time the US has become a deliberate direct combatant against the Syrian government,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/06/trump-syria-missiles-assad-chemical-weapons|title=Syria missile strikes: US launches first direct military action against Assad|first1=Spencer|last1=Ackerman|first2=Ed Pilkington Ben|last2=Jacobs|first3=Julian Borger in|last3=Washington|date=7 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=1 September 2017|via=The Guardian}} and marked the start of a series of deliberate [[List of United States attacks on the Syrian government during the Syrian Civil War|direct military action by the U.S. military against the Syrian government]]′s and pro-government forces in May–June 2017 and February 2018. According to a report by Amnesty International, the US-led coalition has provided falsified data to conceal the actual number of civilian deaths resulting from their bombing campaigns and is "deeply in denial" about civilian casualties in Raqqa. After an investigation by Amnesty International in June 2018, the US-led coalition confirmed that "coalition air strikes killed 70 civilians, mostly women and children – including 39 members of a single family."{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/07/syria-us-led-coalition-deeply-in-denial-about-civilian-casualties-in-raqqa/|title=Syria: US-led Coalition ‘deeply in denial’ about civilian casualties in Raqqa|via=Amnesty International}} In mid-January 2018, the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] indicated that it intended to maintain an open-ended military presence in Syria to counter Iran's influence and oust Syrian president [[Bashar Assad]].[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/17/us-military-syria-isis-iran-assad-tillerson US military to maintain open-ended presence in Syria, Tillerson says: US secretary of state says forces will remain in country in push against Isis, Bashar al-Assad and Iranian influence] The Guardian, 17 January 2018. In early September 2018 the United States started to implement a new strategy that indefinitely extends the military effort and launches a major diplomatic push to achieve American objectives in Syria.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/in-a-shift-trump-approves-an-indefinite-military-and-diplomatic-effort-in-syria-us-officials-say/2018/09/06/0351ab54-b20f-11e8-9a6a-565d92a3585d_story.html|title=Trump agrees to an indefinite military effort and new diplomatic push in Syria, U.S. officials say|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}} == Background == {{Further|Arab Spring|Arab Winter|CIA activities in Syria|Syrian Civil War}} US State Department cables indicate that regime change was a secret goal of the American government in the years leading up to the civil war, even during the period when Barack Obama was publicly engaging with Bashar Al-Assad. A 2006 memorandum by [[William Roebuck]] of the embassy in Damascus stated:
We believe Bashar's weaknesses are in how he chooses to react to looming issues, both perceived and real, such as...the potential threat to the regime from the increasing presence of transiting Islamist extremists. This cable summarizes our assessment of these vulnerabilities and suggests that there may be actions, statements and signals that the USG can send that will improve the likelihood of such opportunities arising.
Roebuck, who went on to be [[Chargé d'affaires|charge d'affair]] of the Libyan embassy under Obama, also considered the advantages of promoting religious sectarianism in Syria.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5s7SCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT280&lpg=PT280&dq=roebuck,+overreact&source=bl&ots=mIGJx-n11s&sig=TqehusGIId8di8bHyX8PwyD7BtQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO_vago7rbAhVKVxQKHRmjAGAQ6AEIXjAE#v=onepage&q=roebuck,%20overreact&f=false|title=The WikiLeaks Files: The World According to US Empire|last=Naiman|first=Robert|last3=|date=2015-09-15|publisher=Verso Books - Random House|year=|isbn=9781781689448|location=|pages=|language=en|chapter=Chapter 10 "Syria"}} Following the start of the [[Arab Spring]] in 2011, [[Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|protests]] in Syria against the Assad administration were violently suppressed and a civil war began.{{cite web|last1=Holliday |first1=Joseph |title=The Struggle for Syria in 2011 – An Operational and Regional Analysis |url=http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Struggle_For_Syria.pdf |publisher=[[Institute for the Study of War]] |accessdate=20 September 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6SibrK1K7?url=http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Struggle_For_Syria.pdf |archivedate=20 September 2014 |date=December 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} By 2012 there were several armed opposition groups operating in the country, including the [[Free Syrian Army]], formed in July 2011 by officers who defected from the [[Syrian Armed Forces]]. In 2012, the [[al-Nusra Front]] was established by the [[Islamic State of Iraq]] as the official branch of ''al-Qaeda in Syria''. The al-Nusra Front was eclipsed by its own creator, and [[al-Qaeda]] severed its ties to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] in February 2014, after an eight-month power struggle.{{cite news|last1=Abouzeid |first1=Rania |title=The Jihad Next Door – The roots of Iraq's newest civil war |url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/06/al-qaeda-iraq-syria-108214_full.html |accessdate=20 September 2014 |date=23 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6SicnSsTj?url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/06/al-qaeda-iraq-syria-108214_full.html |archivedate=20 September 2014 |newspaper=[[Politico]] |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} {{Syrian Civil War map}} === Arming and training the Syrian opposition === {{Further|Foreign involvement in the Syrian Civil War#United States|Timber Sycamore|Syrian Train and Equip Program}} At the direction of U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) was put in charge of the operations, worth about $1 billion annually, to arm anti-government forces in Syria,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/09/us-to-axe-5-scheme-train-syrian-rebels-nyt|title=US axes $500m scheme to train Syrian rebels, says NYT |work=The Guardian|accessdate=13 October 2015|date=9 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/lawmakers-move-to-curb-1-billion-cia-program-to-train-syrian-rebels/2015/06/12/b0f45a9e-1114-11e5-adec-e82f8395c032_story.html|title=Secret CIA effort in Syria faces large funding cut |work=The Washington Post|accessdate=13 October 2015|date=10 June 2015}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/10/world/middleeast/syria-aid-may-resume-despite-fears-over-where-it-will-go.html U.S. Considers Resuming Nonlethal Aid to Syrian Opposition], By MARK LANDLER, 9, January 2014{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/world/middleeast/syria-russia-airstrikes.html?_r=0 |title=U.S. Weaponry Is Turning Syria Into Proxy War With Russia|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 October 2015|date=12 October 2015}} an operation which formally began in 2013, more than two years after the start of the civil war in 2011. Prior to 2013, the CIA only supplied certain rebel groups of the [[Free Syrian Army]] with non-lethal aid, but later began providing training, funding, and intelligence to selected rebel commanders.{{cite news|last1=Bowman|first1=Tom|author2=Fordham, Alice|title=CIA Is Quietly Ramping Up Aid To Syrian Rebels, Sources Say|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/04/23/306233248/cia-is-quietly-ramping-up-aid-to-syrian-rebels-sources-say|accessdate=20 September 2014|date=23 April 2014|work = [[NPR]]}}{{cite news|last1=Spencer|first1=Richard|title=US-backed head of Free Syria Army voted out|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/10644538/US-backed-head-of-Free-Syria-Army-voted-out.html|accessdate=20 September 2014|date=17 February 2014|newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]]}}{{cite news|last1=Youssef |first1=Nancy A. |title=Syrian Rebels Describe U.S.-Backed Training in Qatar |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/foreign-affairs-defense/syria-arming-the-rebels/syrian-rebels-describe-u-s-backed-training-in-qatar/ |accessdate=20 September 2014 |publisher=[[PBS]] – [[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]] |date=26 May 2014 |archive-date=20 September 2014 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6SidZu5ZR?url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/foreign-affairs-defense/syria-arming-the-rebels/syrian-rebels-describe-u-s-backed-training-in-qatar/ |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Although a former intelligence adviser who spoke to journalist [[Seymour Hersh]] claimed the CIA had been facilitating the flow of arms from [[Libya]] to Syria in collaboration with "the UK [[[United Kingdom]]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Qatar]]" since 2012 or 2011,{{cite web|authorlink=Seymour Hersh|last=Hersh|first=Seymour|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n01/seymour-m-hersh/military-to-military|title=Military to Military|work=[[London Review of Books]]|volume=38|issue=1|date=7 January 2016|accessdate=21 July 2017}} the first confirmed CIA weapons arrived in Spring 2014: "There were just a handful, delivered to only one rebel group carefully vetted by the CIA. The group, [[Harakat Hazm]], or the Steadfast Movement, showed off the new weapons system by posting the first successful strike on YouTube in April.{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/09/17/349075789/after-a-long-wait-syrian-rebels-hope-the-weapons-will-now-flow|title=After A Long Wait, Syrian Rebels Hope The Weapons Will Now Flow|date=17 September 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|last = Amos|first = Deborah|work = [[NPR]]}} Another of the groups being vetted was the [[Islamist]] [[Army of Mujahedeen]], formed in January 2014 specifically to combat ISIS.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/01/04/New-Syria-rebel-alliance-declares-war-on-al-Qaeda.html|title=Syria opposition says it backs rebel fight against al-Qaeda|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=24 September 2014}} However, there were indications that the Army of Mujahedeen was still being vetted in September 2014.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/30/us-mideast-crisis-syria-rebels-insight-idUSKCN0HP0BE20140930|title=U.S.-led air strikes pose problem for Assad's moderate foes|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=30 September 2014|last = Perry|first = Tom|last2 = Stewart|first2 = Phil|editor-last = Nakhoul|editor-first = Samia|location = [[Reyhanlı]], [[Turkey]]|work = [[Reuters]]}} In addition to the CIA program, on 17 September 2014 the U.S. House of Representatives voted to authorize the executive branch to overtly [[Syrian Train and Equip Program|train and equip]] Syrian rebels against ISIL forces, at a cost of $500 million.{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2014/09/17/house-grudgingly-approves-arms-for-syrian-rebels/|title=House Grudgingly Approves Arms for Syrian Rebels|date=17 September 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|agency = [[Associated Press]]|work = [[New York Post]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/18/us-iraq-crisis-congress-vote-idUSKBN0HD2P820140918|title=U.S. Congress approves arming Syrian rebels, funding government|date=18 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|last = Zengerle|first = Patricia|last2 = Lawder|first2 = David|work = [[Reuters]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/15/us-usa-syria-rebels-insight-idUSKBN0HA0QX20140915|title=Syria's 'moderate' rebels say they need weapons, not training|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|last = Szep|first = Jason|location = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]]|editor-last = McBride|editor-first = Janet|last2 = Stewart|first2 = Phil|last3 = Spetalnick|first3 = Matt|work = [[Reuters]]}} The United States was set to send 400 troops and hundreds of support staff to countries neighboring Syria to train 5,000 opposition soldiers a year for the next three years.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-30847689 |title= US to send 400 troops to train Syrian rebels|publisher=BBC News|date=16 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015|agency = }} The countries taking part in the train-and-equip program were to include [[Jordan]], Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and [[Turkey]]. The groups that were expected to be armed and trained by the US government included fighters from the [[Free Syrian Army]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isis-terror/who-are-syrian-rebels-u-s-wants-arm-train-n207391|title=Who Are the Syrian Rebels the U.S. Wants to Arm and Train?|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=20 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|last = Plesser|first = Ben|last2 = Cheikh Omar|first2 = Ammar|last3 = McClam|first3 = Erin}} In October 2014, the Turkish government agreed to help train and equip some moderate Syrian rebels in Turkey.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/turkey-to-help-train-equip-moderate-syrian-rebels-u-s-officials-say-1412970068|title=Turkey to Help Train and Equip Moderate Syrian Rebels|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]|last = Schwartz|first = Felicia|last2 = Entous|first2 = Adam|last3 = Albayrak|first3 = Ayla}} The Pentagon confirmed that it had selected 1,200 Syrian opposition members to begin training in March 2015, with 3,000 to complete training by the end of 2015.{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/18/us-mideast-crisis-syria-training-idUSKBN0LM2DN20150218 | title= U.S. identifies 1,200 potential fighters for Syria training |agency=Reuters |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=19 February 2015}} The successful experience in Kobanî had informed U.S. policy in regard to arming Syrian opposition groups other than the Kurdish [[People's Protection Units|YPG]], with plans to give other groups [[Technical (vehicle)|technicals]] equipped with radio and [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] equipment to call in airstrikes.{{cite news|url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-to-give-some-syria-rebels-ability-to-call-airstrikes-1424208053 | title= U.S. to Give Some Syria Rebels Ability to Call Airstrikes |publisher= The Wall Street Journal |agency= |date=17 February 2015 |accessdate=17 February 2015 |last = Barnes|first = Julian E. |last2 =Entous |first2 =Adam | last3= |first3 =|quote= }} [[John R. Allen]], President Obama's envoy to the international coalition against ISIL, has said "It is clearly part of our plan, that not only we will train them, and we will equip them with the latest weapons systems, but we will also protect them when the time comes".{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-2976658/US-protect-Syrian-rebels-time-comes-envoy.html | title= US will 'protect' Syrian rebels when time comes: envoy |publisher= The Daily Mail |agency= AFP |date=22 February 2015 |accessdate=3 March 2015 |quote= }} In March 2015, the United Kingdom announced that it was sending around 75 military instructors to train Syrian opposition forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-32064130|title= UK to give military training to 'moderate Syria forces'|publisher=BBC News|date= 26 March 2015|accessdate=3 April 2015}} The train-and-equip programme started on 9 May 2015.{{cite news | url= https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/May-02/296571-turkey-us-to-start-train-and-equip-plan-for-syria-rebels-may-9-ankara.ashx |title= Turkey, US to start train-and-equip plan for Syria rebels May 9: Ankara | publisher= TDS | agency= Reuters |date= 2 May 2015 |accessdate= 2 May 2015 |quote=}} On 25 May, Turkey and the U.S. agreed "in principle" on the necessity to support these forces with air support.{{cite news | url= http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/May-25/299211-turkey-says-deal-with-us-on-air-support-for-syria-rebels.ashx |title= Turkey says deal with US on air support for Syria rebels |publisher=The Daily Star |agency= Reuters |last= Afanasieva |first= Dasha |date= 25 May 2015 |accessdate= 26 May 2015 |quote=}} However, only about 200 rebel fighters actually began training, the majority of whom left after being required to agree to fight only against ISIL and not the Assad government.{{cite news | url=http://syrianobserver.com/EN/News/29382/Syrian_Opposition_Fighters_Withdraw_from_US_Train_Equip_Program/ | title= Syrian Opposition Fighters Withdraw from US 'Train and Equip' Program | date=22 June 2015 | accessdate=6 September 2015 |publisher=The Syrian Observer}} === July 2014 rescue mission === {{Main|2014 American rescue mission in Syria}} Following the abduction of a number of foreigners in Syria, on 4 July 2014, the U.S. carried out an operation to rescue foreign hostages being held by ISIL. U.S. airstrikes were conducted against an ISIL military base known as the "Osama bin Laden Camp" while at the same time, two dozen [[US special forces]] soldiers parachuted from helicopters near an ISIS building, thought to be for high-value prisoners. No prisoners were found in the building and the soldiers were quickly engaged by ISIL forces dispatched from [[Raqqa]], which started a three-hour firefight.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/11049814/The-failed-US-mission-to-try-and-rescue-James-Foley-from-Islamic-State-terrorists.html|title=The failed US mission to try and rescue James Foley from Islamic State terrorists|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|last = Sherlock|first = Ruth|last2 = Malouf|first2 = Carol|last3 = Ensor|first3 = Josie|location = [[Erbil]], [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]|newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]]}} U.S. forces concluded that the hostages were no longer at the site and abandoned the rescue attempt. At least five ISIL fighters were killed and one U.S. soldier was wounded. Jordanian forces were also reportedly involved in the operation, with one Jordanian soldier reportedly wounded, but Jordanian involvement was not confirmed. Later on, it was reported that the hostages had been moved 24 hours before the attempted rescue. Following the mission, it was still unclear whether the operation failed due to bad intelligence or whether ISIL forces were alerted in advance of the mission.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-us-syria-hostage-failed-rescue-mission-20140820-story.html|title=Rising danger prompted U.S. effort to rescue James Foley, other hostages|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|last = Hennessey|first = Kathleen|last2 = Hennigan|first2 = W.J.|newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]]}} In the aftermath of the rescue mission, and purportedly as a response to airstrikes in Iraq, ISIL beheaded three hostages over a one-month period: Americans [[James Foley (journalist)|James Foley]] and [[Steven Sotloff]] on 19 August and 2 September respectively,{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2741496/British-hostage-life-threatened-latest-ISIS-execution-video-subject-failed-rescue-attempt-US-special-forces.html|title=British hostage whose life is threatened in latest ISIS execution video was subject of failed rescue attempt by US special forces|date=2 September 2014|accessdate=7 September 2014|last = Chorley|first = Matt|last2 = McTague|first2 = Tom|newspaper = [[Daily Mail]]}} and Briton [[David Cawthorne Haines|David Haines]] on 13 September.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/13/world/meast/isis-haines-family-message/|title=ISIS executes British aid worker David Haines; Cameron vows justice|accessdate=26 December 2014|date=14 September 2014|publisher = CNN|last = Botelho|first = Greg}} === Surveillance flights over Syria === On 26 August 2014, the U.S. began sending [[Aerial reconnaissance|surveillance flights]], including [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]], over Syria to gather intelligence on ISIL targets. The flights began gathering intelligence that would aid future airstrikes even though airstrikes were not yet authorized at that point.{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2014/08/26/ap_source_obama_backs_surveillance_over_syria/|title=AP source: Obama backs surveillance over Syria|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=25 August 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|last = Pace|first = Julie|agency = [[Associated Press]]}} No approval was sought from the Assad government for flights entering Syrian airspace.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-military-prepares-for-surveillance-flights-over-syria-1409005925|title=U.S. Lays Groundwork for Syria Strike|date=25 August 2014|accessdate=19 September 2014|last = Entous|first = Adam|last2 = E. Barnes|first2 = Julian|last3 = Nissenbaum|first3 = Dion|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]}} ===Support for Kurdish-led ground forces=== As the [[Siege of Kobanî]] continued there were growing calls to also arm the [[People's Protection Units|YPG]], also known as the People's Protection Units, a Kurdish fighting force in Syria heavily involved in the defense of Kobanî.{{cite news|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/national_petition-calls-on-white-house-to-officially-arm-ypg_361343.html|title=Petition calls on White House to officially arm YPG|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]]|location=[[Ankara]], [[Turkey]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012190349/http://www.todayszaman.com/national_petition-calls-on-white-house-to-officially-arm-ypg_361343.html|archivedate=12 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} On 20 October 2014, the Turkish [[List of Ministers of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)|foreign minister]], [[Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu]] announced that the Turkish government would be allowing [[peshmerga]] from the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|Iraqi Kurdistan Regional Government]] to cross their border into Kobanî to support Kurdish fighters.{{cite news|url=https://news.vice.com/article/us-airdrops-weapons-to-kobane-turkey-to-allow-kurdish-peshmerga-into-town|title=US Airdrops Weapons to Kobanî, Turkey to Allow Kurdish Peshmerga Into Town|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=20 October 2014|work = [[Vice News]]|last = Beck|first = John}} The change in policy came after the Turkish government had refused to allow Kurdish fighters and supplies to pass through the border to [[People's Protection Units|YPG]] units in Kobanî, as it viewed the YPG as an offshoot of the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party|PKK]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/turkey-shifts-stance-help-iraqi-kurds-join-fight-against-isis-syrias-kobani-1707723|title=Turkey Shifts Stance To Help Iraqi Kurds Join Fight Against ISIS In Syria's Kobani|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=20 October 2014|work = [[International Business Times]]|last = Pandey|last2 = Avaneesh}} On 28 October, [[Peshmerga]] from the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|Iraqi Kurdistan Regional Government]] departed [[Erbil]] to travel to [[Turkey]] and eventually to Kobanî.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-10-29/iraq-kurd-fighters-leave-base-for-syria-deployment/5849452|title=Islamic State: Kurdish Peshmerga troops leave Iraq to join battle in Kobane|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)]]|date=28 October 2014|accessdate=28 October 2014|last = Cooper|first = Hayden}} A total of 152 soldiers were deployed starting with forty vehicles carrying weapons, artillery, and machine guns, along with 80 Peshmerga forces, who crossed the border into Turkey by land with the heavy weapons and then drove to the border near Kobanî. The other 72 soldiers in the contingent flew to Turkey and rejoined the rest of the contingent on 29 October. On 29 October 152 Kurdish Peshmerga from Iraq and 50 [[Free Syrian Army]] fighters crossed the border into Kobanî with heavy weapons, small arms, and ammunition.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/30/world/middleeast/reinforcements-enter-besieged-syrian-town-via-turkey-raising-hopes.html?_r=0|title=Reinforcements Enter Besieged Syrian Town via Turkey, Raising Hopes|date=29 October 2014|accessdate=29 October 2014|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|last = Barnard|first = Anne}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29814135|title=Islamic State crisis: Syria rebel forces boost Kobane defence|work=[[BBC News]]|date=29 October 2014|accessdate=29 October 2014}} == U.S.-led coalition against ISIL == {{main| Military intervention against ISIL#International coalitions against ISIS}} The United States had since 2014 led efforts to establish a global coalition to counter ISIL.[http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/BRIE/2015/551330/EPRS_BRI%282015%29551330_EN.pdf The international coalition to counter ISIL/Da'esh (the 'Islamic State')] 17 March 2015. On 5 September, 15 September,{{cite web|url=https://franceintheus.org/spip.php?article5887|title=International Conference on Iraq in Paris (09/15/14)|first=Embassy of France in the United States, Washington,|last=D.C.|website=France in the United States / Embassy of France in Washington, D.C.|accessdate=1 September 2017}} and 3 December 2014, various sets of countries came together to discuss concerted action against ISIL. Present at all three meetings were the United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy, Canada, Turkey and Denmark. The coalition of 5 September (10 countries) decided to support anti-ISIL forces in Iraq and Syria.[http://time.com/3273185/isis-us-nato/ ‘U.S. Forms Anti-ISIS Coalition at NATO Summit’]. ''Time'', 5 September 2014. Retrieved 14 June 2015. On 10 September 2014, U.S. president Barack Obama announced a ″comprehensive″ strategy to counter ISIL that ″in concert with coalition partners <...> will defeat ISIL and deny them safe haven″.[https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2014/09/10/fact-sheet-strategy-counter-islamic-state-iraq-and-levant-isil FACT SHEET: Strategy to Counter the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL)] The White House, 10 September 2014. The coalition of 3 December 2014 (sixty countries) that styled itself as the ''Global Coalition to Counter the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL)''[https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/12/234627.htm ‘Joint Statement Issued by Partners at the Counter-ISIL Coalition Ministerial Meeting’]. ''[[United States Department of State]]'', 3 December 2014. agreed on a many-sided strategy against ISIL, including cutting off ISIL's financing and funding and exposing ISIL's true nature. As of March 2015, the U.S.-led coalition comprised over sixty countries, that contributed in various ways to the effort. == Training Syrian moderate opposition to fight ISIL == {{Main|Syrian Train and Equip Program}} As of mid-2015, only a group of 54 such fighters ([[Division 30]]) had been deployed, which was quickly routed by [[al-Nusra]],{{cite news | url=http://www.startribune.com/syrian-commander-of-u-s-trained-fighters-is-kidnapped-by-al-qaida-affiliate/320211681/ | title= Syrian commander of U.S.-trained fighters is kidnapped by Al-Qaida affiliate | date=30 July 2015 | accessdate=6 September 2015 |publisher= New York Times}} and a further 100 trained in Jordan.{{cite web |url= http://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2015/07/15/first-group-of-fsa-soldiers-trained-by-us-turkey-enters-syria |title=First group of FSA soldiers trained by U.S., Turkey enters Syria |author=Mehmed Cavid Barkçin |work=[[Daily Sabah]] |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2015}} In September it was reported that a further 100-120 were being trained in a second wave,{{cite web |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/news/military/small-number-u-s-trained-syrian-rebels-still-fighting-n428381 |title=Small number of U.S.-trained Syrian rebels still fighting |author=Jim Miklaszewski |work=NBC News |accessdate=26 September 2015|date=16 September 2015}} with 75 more Division 30 fighters reported to have re-entered Syria at the end of the month, immediately attacked by al-Nusra.Nabih Bulos, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/11882195/US-trained-Division-30-rebels-betrayed-US-and-hand-weapons-over-to-al-Qaedas-affiliate-in-Syria.html US-trained Division 30 rebels 'betray US and hand weapons over to al-Qaeda's affiliate in Syria'], Telegraph, 22 September 2015 In March 2015, the [[United Kingdom]] announced that it would provide military training to Syrian moderate opposition forces, to enable them to defend Syrian communities against ISIL, and later also lead offensives against ISIL.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-troops-to-train-moderate-syrian-opposition|title=UK troops to train moderate Syrian opposition|publisher=United Kingdom Ministry of Defence|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=16 July 2015}} ''[[Jane's Defence Weekly]]'' reported that in December 2015 the U.S. shipped 994 tonnes of weapons and ammunition (including packaging and container weight), generally of Soviet-type from Eastern Europe, to Syrian rebel groups under operation [[Timber Sycamore]]. A detailed list of weapon types and shipment weights had been obtained from the US government's Federal Business Opportunities website.{{cite news |url=http://www.janes.com/article/59374/us-arms-shipment-to-syrian-rebels-detailed |title=US arms shipment to Syrian rebels detailed |author=Jeremy Binnie, Neil Gibson |publisher=IHS |work=Jane's Defence Weekly |date=8 April 2016 |accessdate=3 December 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Malone|first1=Paul|title=Save us from the Dr Strangeloves|accessdate=21 September 2016|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/save-us-from-todays-dr-strangeloves-20160707-gq0d74.html|work=Canberra Times|date=10 July 2016}} As of July 2016, extensive arms shipments were continuing.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/27/weapons-flowing-eastern-europe-middle-east-revealed-arms-trade-syria |title=Revealed: the £1bn of weapons flowing from Europe to Middle East |author1=Ivan Angelovski |author2=Miranda Patrucic |author3=Lawrence Marzouk |newspaper=The Guardian |date=27 July 2016 |accessdate=17 December 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/making-a-killing-the-1-2-billion-euros-arms-pipeline-to-middle-east-07-26-2016 |title=Making a Killing: The 1.2 Billion Euro Arms Pipeline to Middle East |author1=Lawrence Marzouk |author2=Ivan Angelovski |author3=Miranda Patrucic |newspaper=BalkanInsight |date=27 July 2016 |accessdate=17 December 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.janes.com/article/61038/is-seizes-saudi-weapons-from-syrian-rebels |title=IS seizes Saudi weapons from Syrian rebels |author=Jeremy Binnie |publisher=IHS |work=Jane's Defence Weekly |date=7 June 2016 |accessdate=17 December 2016}} It was reported in July 2017 that the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Donald Trump administration]] decided to "phase-out" the CIA program to equip and train anti-government rebel groups, a move sought by Russia.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-usa-syria-idUSKBN1A42KC Trump ends CIA arms support for anti-Assad Syria rebels: U.S. officials] Reuters, 19 July 2017.{{cite news|last1=Jaffe|first1=Greg|last2=Entous|first2=Adam|title=Trump halts covert arming of Syria rebels, a move likely to please Russia|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-ends-covert-cia-program-to-arm-anti-assad-rebels-in-syria-a-move-sought-by-moscow/2017/07/19/b6821a62-6beb-11e7-96ab-5f38140b38cc_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-low_ciasyria-310pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory|accessdate=20 July 2017|publisher=Washington Post|date=20 July 2017}}[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40667229 Syria war: Trump 'ends CIA arms programme for rebels'] BBC, 20 July 2017. == Multinational air war == {{further|Authorization for the Use of Military Force Against the Government of Syria to Respond to Use of Chemical Weapons}} === Preparations for American airstrikes === In his address to the nation on 10 September 2014, U.S. President Obama announced his intention to bomb ISIL targets in Syria and called on Congress to authorize a program to train and arm rebels who were fighting ISIL and the Syrian forces of [[Bashar al-Assad]].{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/09/obama-strike-wherever-it-exists-2014910223935601193.html|title=Obama outlines plan to target IS fighters|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=24 September 2014}} For the first time, he authorized direct attacks against the militant group in Syria. In his address, he said the United States were going on offensive, launching "a steady, relentless effort to take out" the group "wherever they exist." Obama also announced creating of a broader coalition against ISIL.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Zake|title=Obama Says U.S. Will Bomb ISIS in Syria, Train Rebels|url=http://time.com/3319658/obama-isis-speech-iraq-syria/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=10 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014}} Commenting on Obama's address, Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman {{Interlanguage link multi|Alexander Lukashevich|2=ru|3=Лукашевич, Александр Казимирович|preserve=1}} opposed the U.S. intervention against ISIL in Syria "without the consent of the legitimate government" and said that "this step, in the absence of a UN Security Council decision, would be an act of aggression, a gross violation of international law". [[Ali Haidar (politician)|Ali Haidar]], Syrian minister of national reconciliation, said that "any action of any kind without the consent of the Syrian government would be an attack on Syria".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29154481|title=Russia warns US against strikes on Islamic State in Syria|work=[[BBC News]]|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=22 September 2014}} On 17 September, the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] approved Obama's plan to train and arm the Syrian rebels in their fight against ISIL. In a statement following the House vote, Obama said that the United States wouldn't send military troops to Syria.{{cite news|last=O'Keefe|first=Ed|title=House approves Obama's Iraq-Syria military strategy amid skepticism|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/congress-poised-to-approve-obamas-iraq-syria-military-strategy-amid-skepticism/2014/09/17/c2494df2-3e85-11e4-b0ea-8141703bbf6f_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=17 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014}} The [[United States Senate|Senate]] gave final congressional approval to Obama's proposal the next day.{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Chelsea J.|last2=Starr|first2=Barbara|title=Obama: ISIS threat against U.S., allies 'doesn't frighten us'|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/09/18/world/meast/isis-threat/|date=19 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|publisher = CNN}} The U.S. did not request permission from the Syrian government, nor did it coordinate its actions with the Syrian government, provide direct notification to the Syrian military or give indication of timing on specific targets, but it did notify the Syrian U.N. representative, which the Syrian government confirmed.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/us-arab-partners-air-strikes-islamic-state-syria/2459099.html|title=US: Syria Won't, Can't Stop Militant Safe Havens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|last = Pande|first = Aru|last2 = Babb|first2 = Carl}} Before the airstrikes began, the United States also informed [[Iran]], the Assad government's largest regional ally, of their intention to launch airstrikes. It did not share specific timing or targets of strikes with the Iranian government but reportedly assured it that the US would not strike any Syrian government targets.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/23/us-syria-crisis-usa-iran-idUSKCN0HI2F220140923|title=Exclusive: U.S. told Iran of intent to strike Islamic State in Syria|publisher=Reuters|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|last = Hafezi|first = Parisa|last2 = Charbonneau|first2 = Louis|last3 = Mohammed|first3 = Arshad|editor-last = Goller|editor-first = Howard|location = [[Headquarters of the United Nations|United Nations, New York City]]}} === Contributing countries === * {{flagu|Australia}} ([[Operation Okra]]) * {{flagu|Bahrain}} * {{flagu|Belgium}} * {{flagu|Canada}} ([[Operation Impact#In Syria|Operation Impact § In Syria]] – pulling out soon{{cite news|title=Trudeau to Obama: Canada to pull out of bombing campaign against ISIS|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/10/21/middleeast/syria-iraq-isis-fight/|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=CNN|date=21 October 2015}}) * {{flagu|France}} ([[Opération Chammal]]) * {{flagu|Germany}} ([[German intervention against ISIL|Operation Counter Daesh]]) * {{flagu|Netherlands}} on 29 January 2016 decided to start air attacks in Syria on ISIL (see [[Dutch involvement in the Syrian Civil War]]) * {{flagu|Jordan}} ([[Jordanian intervention in the Syrian Civil War]]) * {{flagu|Qatar}} * {{flagu|Saudi Arabia}} * {{flagu|Turkey}} ([[Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War]]) * {{flagu|United Arab Emirates}} * {{flagu|United Kingdom|size=22px}} ([[Operation Shader#Intervention in Syria|Operation Shader § Intervention in Syria]]) * {{flagu|United States}} (Leader) === Timeline === [[File:Strikes in Syria and Iraq 2014-09-23.jpg|thumb|right|Map of the first round of U.S. and coalition strikes in Syria]] ==== 2014==== ===== September 2014===== [[File:Tomahawk launch from USS Arleigh Burke (DDG-51) in September 2013.JPG|thumb|left|A [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk cruise missile]] launching from {{USS|Arleigh Burke|DDG-51|6}} to strike ISIL targets in Syria on 23 September]] On 22 September, Pentagon Press Secretary Rear Admiral [[John Kirby (soldier)|John Kirby]] confirmed that the United States and other partner nations had undertaken strikes in Syria using fighters, bombers, and [[Tomahawk missile]]s in strikes authorized by President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/23/world/middleeast/us-and-allies-hit-isis-targets-in-syria.html|title=U.S. Airstrikes by U.S. and Allies Hit ISIS Targets in Syria|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=22 September 2014|last = Cooper|first = Helene|last2 = Schmitt|first2 = Eric|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]}} [[Bahrain]], [[Jordan]], [[Qatar]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] were identified as countries conducting or supporting airstrikes the first night. The initial strikes were coordinated by [[United States Central Command]] and targeted about 20 [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] targets, including headquarters buildings.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/09/22/syria/16005277/|title=U.S. airstrikes on Islamic State targets in Syria start|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=22 September 2014|last = Vanden Brook|first = Tom|newspaper = [[USA Today]]}} Sources in Syria claimed that among the targets was also [[Brigade 93]], a Syrian army base that the militants had recently captured and targets in the towns of [[Al-Thawrah|Tabqa]] and [[Tell Abyad|Tel Abyad]] in [[Raqqa Governorate|Raqqa Province]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/u-s-and-partners-launch-airstrikes-in-syria-against-islamic-state-1.2019104#|title=U.S. and partners launch airstrikes in Syria against Islamic State|publisher=[[CTV News]]|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=22 September 2014|agency = [[Associated Press]]|last = Butler|first = Desmond}} The U.S. also targeted the al-Qaeda-affiliated [[al-Nusra Front]] and the [[Khorasan (Islamist group)|Khorasan Group]]{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Sep-23/271659-us-syria-raids-also-aimed-at-thwarting-attack-plot-pentagon.ashx|title=US Syria raids also aimed at thwarting attack plot: Pentagon|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|newspaper = [[Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]]|agency = [[Agence France-Presse]]}} in the [[Aleppo Governorate|Aleppo]] and [[Idlib Governorate|Idlib]] Governorates of Syria.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/23/us-syria-crisis-airstrikes-targets-idUSKCN0HI0D920140923|title=Air strikes in Syria hit Islamic State and al Qaeda-linked Nusra Front: monitor|publisher=Reuters|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|last = Dziadosz|first = Alexander|editor-last = Graff|editor-first = Peter}} [[Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor|F-22 Raptor]] stealth fighters were reported to be among the U.S. aircraft striking targets in Syria on the first night of the campaign, carrying out their first combat missions ever since entering service in 2005.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/article_email/u-s-arab-allies-launch-strikes-against-militant-targets-in-syria-1411436642-lMyQjAxMTI0NTI4MjQyODIwWj|title=U.S., Arab Allies Launch Strikes Against Militant Targets In Syria|last=Barnes|first=Julian|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=22 September 2014|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]}} At least 70 ISIL fighters, 50 fighters affiliated with al-Qaeda, and an unknown number of civilians were killed overnight by the airstrikes, according to the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] while eight strikes were launched against the [[Khorasan (Islamist group)|Khorasan group]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Sep-23/271647-us-raids-hit-isis-training-camps-supplies-in-syria.ashx|title=US, Arab allies launch first strikes on fighters in Syria|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|newspaper = [[Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]]|agency = [[Reuters]]–|last = Stewart|first = Phil|last2 = Perryl|first2 = Tom}} On 24 September, the United States and coalition partners conducted a second round of airstrikes on ISIL facilities in Syria. The airstrikes were targeting [[oil production in ISIL|oil production facilities controlled by ISIL]] who had been using the oil in order to fund their activities. Some targets were apparently also mobile production facilities which were most likely not refineries.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/us-led-planes-strike-isis-oil-facilities-syria/story?id=25739334|title=US-Led Planes Strike ISIS Oil Facilities in Syria|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=24 September 2014|accessdate=24 September 2014|last = Martinez|first = Luis}} In a third round of airstrikes on ISIL targets on 25 September, Arab partners lead the United States in strikes against militant-held oil facilities in northeastern Syria. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates dropped 80 percent of the bomb tonnage in the third round of strikes, compared to other strikes in which the United States lead Arab partners.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/us-airstrikes-syria-kill-islamic-state-militants/2461756.html|title=Arab Militaries Lead Third Round of Syria Strikes|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=25 September 2014|last = Murdock|first = Heather}} On 26 September, the United States carried out a fourth round of airstrikes on ISIL targets in Eastern Syria. The strikes were targeting IS heavy equipment and destroyed four of their tanks in the [[Deir ez-Zor Governorate|Deir ez-Zor Province]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/isis-hit-by-new-u-s-airstrikes-in-syria-iraq/|title=U.S. airstrikes hit ISIS oil areas, destroy tanks|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=27 September 2014}} In a fifth round of airstrikes in Syria on 27 September, the United States lead strikes along with Saudi Arabia, Jordan and the United Arab Emirates against ISIL forces in the [[Kobanî Canton]] of [[Syrian Kurdistan]]. The strikes destroyed two armored vehicles and an unknown number of fighters in an area that had been put under [[Siege of Kobane|siege]] by ISIL militants. The siege by Islamic State fighters had recently forced over 100,000 Syrian Kurds to flee across the border to Turkey.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/28/world/middleeast/us-strikes-isis-in-syria-to-defend-kurds.html?gwh=B3407C6E57B1E121BA5CD907A73CAA8B&gwt=pay&assetType=nyt_now|title=U.S., Defending Kurds in Syria, Expands Strikes Against ISIS|date=27 September 2014|accessdate=27 September 2014|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|last = E. Sanger|first = David|last2 = Barnard|first2 = Anne}} On 28 and 29 September, the United States carried out two rounds of strikes against IS positions across Syria in 4 provinces. Among the facilities targeted was the entrance to the largest gas plant in Syria, in the [[Deir ez-Zor Governorate|Deir ez-Zor Province]], and ISIL training camp and vehicles near an ISIL controlled grain silo in [[Manbij]], Aleppo province.{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2014/09/29/us-led-airstrikes-hit-4-syrian-provinces|title=US-led coalition hits Islamic State group in 4 provinces across northern and eastern Syria|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=29 September 2014|work = [[U.S. News & World Report]]|last = Lucas|first = Ryan|agency = [[Associated Press]]}} ===== October 2014 ===== [[File:Night launch of F-18s from USS GHW Bush (CVN-77) in September 2014.JPG|thumb|left|[[FA-18]] Hornets takes off from {{USS|George H.W. Bush|CVN-77|6}} to strike ISIL targets in Syria]] In an eighth round of airstrikes in Syria on 1 October, the United States and coalition partners struck ISIL targets in Northern Syria. The daytime strikes targeted ISIL forces [[Siege of Kobanî|laying siege]] to [[Kobanî]], a primarily Kurdish city in [[Syrian Kurdistan]], in support of the [[People's Protection Units]] (YPG) and [[Free Syrian Army]], who were defending the city.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-led-forces-carry-out-airstrikes-near-besieged-syrian-city-1412165394|title=U.S.-Led Forces Carry Out Airstrikes Near Besieged Syrian City|date=1 October 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014|newspaper = [[Wall Street Journal]]|last = Albayrak|first = Ayla}} On 2 October, the United States lead a ninth round of strikes, along with the United Arab Emirates, against ISIL forces across Syria. The strikes destroyed an ISIL checkpoint near Kobanî, damaged a tank north of Sinjar Mountain, destroyed a tank west of [[Raqqa]], and several ISIL facilities east of [[Aleppo]].{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123325|title=U.S., Allied Airstrikes Hit ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=2 October 2014|accessdate=4 October 2014}} In a tenth round of airstrikes in Syria on 3 October, the United States, assisted by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates struck ISIL forces in Northern and Eastern Syria. The strikes destroyed an ISIL garrison south of Al-Hasakah, destroyed two tanks southeast of [[Deir ez-Zor]], destroyed two modular oil refineries and a training camp south of Raqqa, and struck an ISIL building northeast of Aleppo.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123332|title=Airstrikes Hit ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=3 October 2014|accessdate=4 October 2014}} On 4 October, the United States lead an 11th round of airstrikes, along with Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates, against ISIL forces across Syria. The US and partner nations carried out nine strikes, destroying an ISIL infantry unit, armored personnel carrier, and a vehicle south of Kobanî, destroying a tank and a vehicle southeast of Deir ez-Zor, damaging the Taqba airfield and destroying an artillery piece near Raqqa, as well as destroying an IS depot and logistics complex south of Al-Hasakah.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/home/features/2014/0814_iraq/Airstrikes3.html|title=U.S. Military, Partner Nations Conduct Airstrikes Against ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=4 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}} In a 12th round of airstrikes in Syria on 5 October, the United States carried out three airstrikes against ISIL forces in Central and Eastern Syria. The strikes destroyed an ISIL bulldozer, two ISIL tanks and another vehicle northwest of [[Mayadin]], and destroyed six firing positions and a large ISIL unit northwest of Raqqa.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123346|title=U.S. Military Conducts Airstrikes Against ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=5 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}} On 6 October, the United States carried out a 13th round of airstrikes in Syria against ISIL forces across Syria. The strikes destroyed an ISIL tank near Taqba airfield west of Raqqa, destroyed two fighting positions south of [[Kobanî]], and destroyed a tank southeast of Deir ez-Zor.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123350|title=U.S., Partner Nations Strike ISIL in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=6 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014}} In a 14th round of airstrikes in Syria on 7 October, the United States, assisted by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates against ISIL forces across Syria. The United States and partner nations carried out nine strikes damaging multiple ISIL controlled buildings west of Al-Hasakah, damaging a staging area and IED production facility northeast of Deir ez-Zor, destroying three armed vehicles, damaging one armed vehicle, destroying a vehicle carrying anti-aircraft artillery, destroying an ISIL tank, and an ISIL unit in and around Kobanî, and killing a small group of fighters southwest of Rabiyah.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123353|title=Airstrikes Pound ISIL in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=7 October 2014|accessdate=7 October 2014}} On 8 October, the United States lead a 15th round of airstrikes along with the United Arab Emirates against ISIL forces across Syria. The US and the United Arab Emirates carried out nine strikes destroying an armored personnel carrier, four armed vehicles, an artillery piece, and damaged another armed vehicle in and around Kobanî, striking an ISIL training camp and fighters northwest of Raqqa, and destroying a tank northwest of Deir ez-Zor.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123364|title=Airstrikes Hit ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=8 October 2014|accessdate=8 October 2014}} In a 16th round of airstrikes in Syria on 9 October, the United States carried out nine airstrikes in the areas in and around the border town of Kobanî that is under siege. The US carried out six airstrikes south of Kobanî that destroyed two ISIL-held buildings, one tank and one heavy machine gun along, a fighting position along with one large and two small ISIL units. Along with strikes south of Kobanî, the US carried out three airstrikes north of Kobanî which struck two small ISIL units and destroyed two ISIL-held buildings.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123379|title=U.S. Military Conducts Airstrikes Against ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=9 October 2014|accessdate=9 October 2014}} [[File:USAF F-22 Strike Syria.jpg|200px|thumb|right|A before and after picture of an ISIL command and control center, after an [[Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor|F-22]] airstrike on 23 September]] On 10 October, the United States led a 17th round of airstrikes along with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates against ISIL forces across Syria. The US and coalition partners carried out nine strikes, destroying two ISIL training facilities, three vehicles, damaging a tank and striking two ISIL units in and around Kobanî. The strikes also destroyed an armored vehicle staging facility east of Deir ez-Zor and struck a small ISIL unit northeast of Al-Hasakah.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123382|title=Airstrikes Target ISIL in Syria and Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=10 October 2014}} In an 18th round of airstrikes in Syria on 11 October, the United States carried out six airstrikes in and around the border town of Kobanî that is under siege by ISIL forces. The US carried out four strikes north of Kobanî striking a fighting position, damaging a command and control facility, destroying a staging building, and striking two small ISIL units. South of Kobanî, two airstrikes destroyed three trucks.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123390|title=U.S. Continues Strikes on ISIL, Drops Supplies to Iraqi Troops|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=11 October 2014}} On 12 October, the United States led a 19th round of airstrikes along with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates against ISIL forces across Syria. The US and partner nations carried out four strikes, three in Kobanî, destroying a fighting position and a staging area, and one strike northwest of Raqqa, destroying an armored vehicle compound.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123394|title=U.S. Military, Partners Continue Airstrikes Against ISIL|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014}} Also, on 12 October, the United States announced that the Turkish government had approved the use of Turkish military bases by coalition forces fighting ISIL in Syria and Iraq. These installations will include key bases only {{convert|100|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} from the Syrian border and important US military bases in Turkey such as the [[Incirlik Air Base]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/us-turkey-allows-coalition-military-forces-use-its-bases-1703571|title=US: Turkey Allows Coalition Military Forces To Use Its Bases|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|work = [[International Business Times]]|last = Banco|first = Erin}}{{cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/fc357175430e48739a47832cd3006048/us-says-turkey-oks-use-bases-against-militants|title=US says Turkey OKs use of bases against militants|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|work = Associated Press|last = C. Baldor|first = Lolita|last2 = Klapper|first2 = Bradley}} Despite the announcement of Turkish government approval, on 13 October, Turkish officials denied that any agreement had been made over coalition use of Turkish Airbases including Incirlik.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/confusion-reigns-turkey-appears-renege-base-deal-us-strikes-against-isis-syria-1704096|title=Confusion Reigns As Turkey Appears to Renege on Base Deal For US Strikes Against ISIS In Syria|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=13 October 2014|work = [[International Business Times]]|last = Harress|first = Christopher}} In a 20th round of airstrikes in Syria on 13 October, the United States and Saudi Arabia carried out eight airstrikes against ISIL forces in Syria. The United States and Saudi Arabia carried out seven strikes in and around Kobanî, striking a large ISIL unit, two small units; damaging one staging location and destroying another, destroying a heavy-machine-gun firing position, destroying three buildings, and damaging two others. One other strike northwest of Raqqa struck an ISIL garrison.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123397|title=U.S., Saudi Arabia Conduct Airstrikes Against ISIL in Syria|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=13 October 2014}} On 14 October, the United States and Saudi Arabia carried out the 21st round and the largest set of strikes against ISIL in Syria since the beginning of the intervention, with 21 strikes against targets in and around Kobanî, and an additional strike near Deir ez-Zor. According to the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], the strikes were designed to interdict ISIL reinforcements and resupply zones and prevent ISIL from massing combat power on the Kurdish held portions of Kobanî. The strikes destroyed two staging locations and damaged another, destroyed one ISIL building and damaged two others, damaged three ISIL compounds, destroyed one truck, one armed vehicle, and one other vehicle near Kobanî in support of Kurdish forces resisting the |siege of the town. In addition to those targets, the airstrikes struck seven staging areas, two mortar positions, three ISIL occupied buildings, and an artillery storage facility. An additional strike near Deir ez-Zor struck a modular oil refinery.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123409|title=U.S., Partners Continue Airstrikes Against ISIL|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=14 October 2014|accessdate=14 October 2014}} [[File:FA-18 launch during Inherent Resolve.jpg|200px|thumb|left|A [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet|F/A-18 Super Hornet]] taking off from {{USS|Carl Vinson|CVN-70|6}} before carrying out strikes on ISIL targets in Syria]] In a 22nd round of airstrikes on 15 October, the United States carried out 18 strikes against ISIL targets in and around [[Kobanî]]. The strikes destroyed multiple fighting positions and also successfully struck sixteen ISIL-occupied buildings.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123420|title=Airstrikes Continue Against ISIL Targets in Iraq, Syria|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=15 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014}} On 16 October, the United States carried out a 23rd round of airstrikes with 14 airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around [[Kobanî]] striking nineteen ISIL controlled-buildings, two command posts, three fighting positions, three sniper positions, one staging location, and one heavy machine gun position.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123429|title=Inherent Resolve Airstrikes Continue in Syria|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=16 October 2014|accessdate=16 October 2014}} In a 24th round of airstrikes on 17 October, the United States carried out seven airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around Kobanî and in north-eastern Syria. Six airstrikes took place near Kobanî, striking three ISIL controlled buildings; destroyed two fighting positions, suppressed three fighting positions, and destroyed two vehicles. One other airstrike near [[Al-Shaddadah|Al-Shaddadi]] struck ISIL-controlled oil collection equipment, including several petroleum, oil, and lubricants tanks, and a pump station.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123444|title=Airstrikes Hit ISIL in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=17 October 2014|accessdate=17 October 2014}} On 20 October, the United States carried out a 25th round of airstrikes, with six airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around Kobanî. The strikes destroyed ISIL fighting positions, ISIL mortar positions, a vehicle, and one stray equipment supply bundle from a U.S. airdrop of Kurdish supplies in order to prevent the supplies from being captured.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123449|title=Inherent Resolve Airstrikes Continue in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=20 October 2014}} In a 26th round of airstrikes on 21 October, the United States carried out four airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around Kobanî. The strikes destroyed several ISIL fighting positions, an ISIL controlled building, and a large ISIL unit.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123455|title=Airstrikes Continue Against ISIL Targets in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=21 October 2014|accessdate=21 October 2014}} The British Royal Air Force began operating over Syria in a surveillance role on the same date, making the UK the first Western country other than the United States to operate in both Iraq and Syria simultaneously.{{cite news|title= Surveillance missions over Syria confirmed|url= https://www.gov.uk/government/news/surveillance-missions-over-syria-confirmed | accessdate = 21 October 2014 | publisher=Ministry of Defence|date=21 October 2014}} On 22 October, the United States carried out a 27th round of airstrikes with six airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around Kobanî. The strikes destroyed several ISIL fighting positions, two ISIL vehicles, an ISIL controlled building and an ISIL logistical center.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123463|title=Airstrikes Continue in Support of Operation Inherent Resolve|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=22 October 2014|accessdate=22 October 2014}} In a 28th round of airstrikes on 23 October, the United States carried out six airstrikes in and around Kobanî and near Deir ez-Zor. Four strikes destroyed several ISIL fighting positions, an ISIL vehicle, and an ISIL command and control center near [[Kobanî]]. Two strikes east of Deir ez-Zor destroyed several ISIL oil holding tanks.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123471|title=Airstrikes Against ISIL Continue in Iraq, Syria|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=23 October 2014|accessdate=23 October 2014}} On 24 October, the United States carried out a 29th round of airstrikes with six airstrikes against ISIL targets in and around Kobanî. The strikes destroyed an ISIL vehicle and struck three ISIL units.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123485|title=Airstrikes Against ISIL Forces Continue in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=24 October 2014|accessdate=24 October 2014}} In a 30th round of airstrikes on 25 October, the United States carried out one strike near Kobanî, destroying an ISIL artillery piece.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123492|title=Military Airstrikes Continue Against ISIL in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=25 October 2014|accessdate=25 October 2014}} On 26 October, the United States carried out a 31st round of airstrikes with five airstrikes against ISIL targets near Kobanî, destroying seven ISIL vehicles and an ISIL-controlled building.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123494|title=Military Airstrikes Continue Against ISIL in Syria, Iraq|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=26 October 2014|accessdate=26 October 2014}} [[File:F-22 Refueling Syria.jpg|200px|thumb|right|An [[Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor|F-22
