The force is part of the [[11th Marine Expeditionary Unit|11th MEU]], 400 [[United States Marine Corps|US Marines]] from the Battalion Landing Team [[1st Battalion, 4th Marines]] will crew an artillery battery of M-777 Howitzers; whilst additional infantrymen from the unit will provide security, while resupplies will be handled by part of the expeditionary force's combat logistics element. A defense official with direct knowledge of the operation said the Marines were flown from [[Djibouti]] to [[Kuwait]] and then into Syria. There are 900 US soldiers and Marines deployed to Syria in total (500 special forces troops were already on the ground to train and support the SDF); under the existing limits put in place by the Obama administration, the formal troop cap for Syria is 503, but commanders have the authority to temporarily exceed that limit to meet military requirements. There are approximately 100 [[75th Ranger Regiment (United States)|US Army Rangers]] in [[Stryker]]s and armored Humvees deployed in and around Manbij, US officials said. They are there to discourage Syrian, Russian, or Turkish troops from making any moves that could shift the focus away from an assault on IS militants, specifically preventing them inadvertently coming under fire. The US believes the pressure on ISIS in Raqqa is working, a US official said that intelligence indicates some ISIS leadership and operatives continue to try to leave the city. He added that there is also US intelligence that indicates the city is laced with trenches, tunnels, roadside bombs and houses and buildings wired to explode, which if correct indicates that the US has likely been able to gather intelligence from both overhead surveillance aircraft and people on the ground. However, the official also noted that "Raqqa will probably not be the final battle against ISIS" and added that the group still has some personnel dispersed in areas south and east of the city. According to the official the US estimates that ISIS could have roughly as many as 4,000 fighters in Raqqa. An official told ''the Guardian'' that in addition, the US is preparing to send hundreds of troops to Kuwait to be ready to fight Isis there if needed and the number would be fewer than 1,000. The ''Independent'' reported that Colonel John Dorrian, a spokesperson for Operation Inherent Resolve, said the artillery unit and the Army Rangers would not have a frontline role.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/03/08/marines-have-arrived-in-syria-to-fire-artillery-in-the-fight-for-raqqa/|title=Marines have arrived in Syria to fire artillery in the fight for Raqqa|publisher=Washington post|date=8 March 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/08/politics/marines-raqqa-assault-syria/ |title=US Marines join local forces fighting in Raqqa|work=CNN|date=8 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/09/us-troops-arrival-syria-intensifies-struggle-for-influence|title=Arrival of US troops intensifies struggle for influence in Syria|publisher=the Guardian|date=9 March 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/world/middleeast/us-troops-syria.html?_r=0|title=U.S. Is Sending 400 More Troops to Syria|publisher=New York Times|date=9 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/09/us-sends-hundreds-of-marines-to-syria-to-support-fight-against-isis|title=US sends hundreds of marines to Syria to support fight against Isis|publisher=the Guardian|date=9 March 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/us-marine-corps-syria-raqqa-isis-stronghold-assault-attack-donald-trump-islamic-state-a7620236.html|title=US marines sent to Syria to help assault on Isis' Raqqa stronghold|publisher=the Independent|date=9 March 2017}} [[File:U.S. Marines with the 11th Marine Expeditionary Unit fire an M777 Howitzer during a fire mission in northern Syria as part of Operation Inherent Resolve, Mar. 24, 2017.jpg|thumb|U.S. Marines in northern Syria, March 2017]] On 16 March, a [[2017 Syrian mosque airstrike|US airstrike hit a mosque in western Aleppo]] and killed more than 42 people, mostly civilians. The location was assessed by the US military as a meeting place for al-Qaeda and the US military claimed that the airstrike hit a target across the mosque and was not targeted at the mosque itself.{{cite web|url=https://airwars.org/news/unilateral-strike/|title=Exclusive: US Says it Carried Out Deadly Strike that Hit an Aleppo Mosque|work=Airwars|author=Samuel Oakford|date=16 March 2017}} ''Stars and Stripes'' reported that on 28 March, an airman assigned to the [[21st Space Wing]] was killed in a non-combat incident (possibly natural causes) in northern Syria.{{cite web|url=https://www.stripes.com/news/air-force/peterson-air-force-base-airman-from-oregon-dies-in-syria-1.461233#.WOPCuPWcGUn|title=Peterson Air Force Base airman from Oregon dies in Syria|publisher=Stars and Stripes|date=30 March 2017}} The ''Washington Post'' reported that on the night of 21 March, hundreds of Kurdish and Arab SDF fighters and an undisclosed number of U.S. Special Operations troops as their advisers launched a large-scale heliborne assault on IS around the area of the [[Tabqa Dam]] with the eventual goal of taking the dam. They were inserted on the southern bank of the Euphrates river behind IS's defenses to take them by surprise, Col Joe Scrocca, the spokesman for the U.S.-led campaign in Iraq and Syria said that as a result they did not come under fire. The following day, there was heavy fighting in the area; Scrocca added that the ground forces were supported by helicopter gunships, US Marine 155mm artillery and U.S. airstrikes.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/03/22/u-s-troops-syrian-fighters-insert-behind-isis-lines-to-retake-key-dam-in-syria/|title=U.S. troops, Syrian fighters insert behind ISIS lines to retake key dam in Syria|publisher=Washington Post|date=22 March 2017}} =====April 2017===== {{see|2017 Shayrat missile strike}} {{see|List of United States attacks on the Syrian government during the Syrian Civil War}} [[File:US armoured vehicles pass through Qamishli.ogg|right|thumb|US Army [[Stryker]] armoured vehicles drive through [[Qamishli]] and head to the Syria-Turkey border after [[April 2017 Turkish airstrikes in Syria and Iraq|border clashes]] between the YPG and Turkey.]] [[File:US military transport helicopters fly over northeastern Syria.png|left|thumb|US military transport helicopters fly over northeastern Syria.]] On 6 April, the US conducted a landing operation against ISIL, to the west of Deir ez-Zor. 2 Coalition helicopters airdropped soldiers in the area and targeted a car{{cite web|url=http://en.deirezzor24.net/the-international-coalition-carried-out-a-landing-operation-in-west-of-deir-ezzor/|title=The International Coalition Carried out a Landing Operation in west of Deir Ezzor, killing high-ranking Daesh commanders|work=Deir Ezzor 24|date=7 April 2017}} on route from Raqqa to Deir ez-Zor. During the landing, US forces killed 4 ISIL commanders and extracted a [[Jordan]]ian [[spy]], who had infiltrated ISIL and served as one of its leaders.{{cite web|url=http://en.deirezzor24.net/the-coalition-withdrew-a-jordanian-spy-who-had-served-as-a-daesh-emir-in-the-recent-landing-operation-in-deir-ezzor/|title=The coalition withdrew a Jordanian spy, who had served as a Daesh emir, in the recent landing operation in Deir Ezzor|work=Deir Ezzor 24|date=8 April 2017}} ''CNN'' reported that the operation took place near [[Mayadin]] and that one of the ISIS commanders killed by US special forces was Abdurakhmon Uzbeki, a top facilitator and close associate of ISIS' leader, he was also connected to the [[2017 Istanbul nightclub shooting|New Year's nightclub bombing in Turkey]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/21/middleeast/us-syria-isis-death/|title=US forces in Syria kill associate of ISIS leader linked to Istanbul nightclub strike|publisher=CNN|date=21 April 2017}} On 7 April, in response to [[Use of chemical weapons in the Syrian Civil War|chemical weapon attacks]] (most notably the [[Khan Shaykhun chemical attack]]) against Syrian civilians allegedly by the Syrian government, the US [[2017 Shayrat missile strike|launched missile strikes]] on the airfield from which the chemical weapon attacks were launched.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/04/06/522948481/u-s-launches-airstrikes-against-syria-after-chemical-attack|title=U.S. Launches Airstrikes Against Syria After Chemical Attack|publisher=NPR|date=6 April 2017}} This incident marks the first direct attack by the US on the Assad government.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-weighing-military-options-following-chemical-weapons-attack-in-syria/2017/04/06/0c59603a-1ae8-11e7-9887-1a5314b56a08_story.html|title=U.S. strikes Syrian military airfield in first direct assault on Bashar al-Assad's government|publisher=The Washington Post|date=6 April 2017}} The Russian Foreign Ministry denounced the attack as being based on false intelligence and against international law, suspended the Memorandum of Understanding on Prevention of Flight Safety Incidents that had been signed with the US, and called an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council.{{cite web|url=http://www.mid.ru/ru/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/2717798?p_p_id=101_INSTANCE_cKNonkJE02Bw&_101_INSTANCE_cKNonkJE02Bw_languageId=en_GB|title=Заявление МИД России в связи с вооруженной акцией США в Сирии 7 апреля 2017 года|publisher=}} On 8 April, ISIS militants attacked a U.S. garrison at [[Al Waleed border crossing|Al Tanf]] in Southern Syria: the garrison's main gate was blown up with a vehicle-borne improvised explosive device, followed by a ground assault of about twenty to thirty ISIS militants, some of whom were wearing suicide vests. The U.S. Central Command said that the ″U.S. special operators″ at the base along with other coalition members and ″U.S.-backed Syrian fighters″, supported by multiple airstrikes, repelled the attack, with no U.S. casualties.{{Cite news|first=Christopher |last=Woody |title=ISIS fighters got inside the wire during a hellish firefight with US Special Ops in Syria |date=11 April 2017 |newspaper=Business Insider |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/isis-attack-on-us-troops-at-al-tanf-in-southern-syria-2017-4 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413044118/http://www.businessinsider.com/isis-attack-on-us-troops-at-al-tanf-in-southern-syria-2017-4 |archive-date=13 April 2017 |deadurl=no}}{{Cite news|first=Corey |last=Dickstein |title=US forces help repel ISIS attack on southern Syrian base |date=10 April 2017 |newspaper=Stars and Stripes |url=https://www.stripes.com/news/us-forces-help-repel-isis-attack-on-southern-syrian-base-1.462898 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413045033/https://www.stripes.com/news/us-forces-help-repel-isis-attack-on-southern-syrian-base-1.462898 |archive-date=13 April 2017 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/u-s-special-forces-kill-isis-fighters-repel-attack-syria-n744651|title=U.S. Special Forces Kill ISIS Fighters, Repel Attack in Syria|publisher=NBC News|date=10 April 2017}} The ''Telegraph'' reported that during the battle ISIS militants also ambushed a convoy of reinforcements from an allied rebel group who were trying to relieve the base.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/10/isil-militants-attack-british-special-forces-base-syria/|title=Isil militants attack British special forces base in Syria|publisher=the telegraph|date=10 April 2017}} On ''CNN'' reported that on 11 April, a misdirected US airstrike near Tabqa during the Raqqa offensive killed 18 SDF soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/14/middleeast/syria-conflict/|title=Search for answers after coalition strike kills US allies in Syria|publisher=CNN|date=14 April 2017}} The ''BBC'' reported that on 21 April, US ground troops killed Abdurakhmon Uzbeki, a senior member of ISIS who played a key role in an attack on a [[2017 Istanbul nightclub shooting|night club in Istanbul]] and was a close associate of the leader of ISIS. The targeted commando raid took place in [[Mayadin]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-39673142|title=Syria war: US ground troops kill 'leading IS member'|publisher=BBC|date=21 April 2017}} =====May 2017===== The ''BBC'' reported that on 9 May an RAF drone strike in Syria stopped an ISIS-staged public killing, its hellfire missile killed an ISIS sniper positioned on a rooftop so that the sniper could shoot civilians attempting to walk away. No civilians were harmed and other ISIS fighters fled on motorbikes.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-middle-east-41331644/islamic-state-execution-stopped-by-raf-drone-in-syria|title=Islamic State 'execution' stopped by RAF drone in Syria|publisher=BBC|date=20 September 2017}} The ''Independent'' reported that on 12 May, SDF forces took control of the Taqba Dam after a deal struck by the SDF and around 70 ISIS militants at the dam which included dismantling of IEDs and booby traps, the surrender of heavy weaponry and forced withdrawal of remaining fighters from Tabqa city.{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-syria-raqqa-offensive-advance-tabqa-dam-deal-sdf-kurds-ypg-us-led-coalition-deal-deserted-a7733101.html |title= Isis fighters strike deal with US-backed forces in exchange for their lives |publisher= The Independent |date= 12 May 2017}} On 18 May, the US conducted airstrikes on a convoy of a pro-government militia during the [[2017 Baghdad–Damascus highway offensive]].{{cite web |url= http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/05/18/us-air-strikes-pound-pro-assad-forces-in-syria.html |title= US air strikes pound pro-Assad forces in Syria |publisher= Fox News |date= 18 May 2017}} According to a US defense official, before the strikes were conducted, government troops were warned they were getting too close to Coalition forces garrisoned at al-Tanf but did not respond.{{cite web |url= http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2017/05/18/US-led-Coalition-strikes-pro-regime-convoy-in-Syria-near-Jordan.html|title=US-led coalition strikes pro-regime convoy in Syria near Jordan|publisher=}} According to the US, four or five vehicles were destroyed, including a tank{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-launches-rare-intentional-strike-on-pro-government-forces-in-syria/2017/05/18/9e4e2830-3bf0-11e7-8854-21f359183e8c_story.html|title=U.S. launches rare intentional strike on pro-government forces in Syria|publisher=}} and two bulldozers.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/05/18/united-states-official-airstrike-syria/101835198/|title=Military official: U.S. airstrike hits pro-regime forces in Syria|publisher=}} In contrast, the Syrian Army reported that two tanks were destroyed and a [[ZSU-23-4|Shilka]] [[self-propelled anti-aircraft weapon|SPAAG]] was damaged.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/details-us-attack-syrian-military-southern-syria/|title=Details of US attack on Syrian military in southern Syria|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=18 May 2017|publisher=}} Eight soldiers were killed.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/syria-us-airstrike-killed-soldiers-jordan-47506449|title=Syria says US airstrike killed several soldiers near Jordan|first=ABC|last=News|publisher=|accessdate=22 May 2017}} =====June 2017===== [[File:US fire support for SDF at Raqqa.png|thumb|The [[United States Marine Corps]] provides [[fire support]] to the SDF during the [[Battle of Raqqa (2017)|Battle of Raqqa]]]] On 6 June, U.S. aircraft conducted airstrikes on over 60 troops, a tank, artillery, antiaircraft weapons, and armed technical vehicles from pro-government forces that had entered what the Coalition called Al-Tanf "deconfliction zone".{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/us-led-coalition-strike-on-pro-regime-assad-forces-at-al-tanf-syria-2017-6|title=The US-led coalition destroyed more pro-Assad forces at a growing hotspot in the Syrian desert|author=Christopher Woody|publisher=Business Insider|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/News-Releases/Article/1205543/coalition-statement-on-actions-near-at-tanf-syria/|title=Coalition statement on actions near At Tanf, Syria|date=7 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}} On 8 June, a U.S. [[F-15E]] aircraft shot down a drone while other U.S. aircraft destroyed two armed pick-up trucks belonging to pro-government forced that moved near U.S. backed fighters at Al-Tanf.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-usa-syria-idUSKBN18Z2CP?il=0|title=U.S. downs pro-Syrian drone that fired at coalition forces: spokesman|date=8 June 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017|publisher=Reuters}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/News-Releases/Article/1208008/coalition-statement-on-at-tanf/|title=Coalition statement on At Tanf|date=8 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}} On 18 June, a U.S. [[F/A-18E Super Hornet]] shot down a Syrian [[Sukhoi Su-17#Variants|Su-22]] after it allegedly bombed a SDF position in Ja'Din, south of Tabqa. A statement by the Syrian army claimed that the plane was on a mission to bomb ISIL militants. In the same day, Syrian government forces captured the village of Ja'Din following an SDF withdrawal.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40322666|title=US coalition downs Syrian army plane in Raqqa|work=BBC|date=19 June 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-usa-idUSKBN1990XI|title=U.S. warplane downs Syrian army in Raqqa province|last=Al-Khalidi|first=Suleiman|date=18 June 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=18 June 2017|last2=Spetalnick|first2=Matt}}{{Cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/us-shoots-syrian-fighter-jet-syria/story?id=48119895|title=U.S. shoots down Syrian fighter jet over Syria|last=Martinez|first=Luis|date=18 June 2017|work=[[ABC News]]|access-date=18 June 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/News-Releases/Article/1217917/coalition-defends-partner-forces-from-syrian-fighter-jet-attack/|title=Coalition Defends Partner Forces from Syrian Fighter Jet Attack|date=18 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}} On 20 June, a U.S. [[F-15E Strike Eagle]] shot down a pro-Syrian government [[Shahed 129]] drone near Al-Tanf after it displayed hostile intent and advanced on Coalition forces.{{Cite news|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/Article/1219859/coalition-shoots-down-armed-uav-in-syria/|title=Coalition shoots down armed UAV in Syra|date=20 June 2017|accessdate=20 June 2017}} =====August 2017===== On 21 August, US forces in northern Syria were fired on by [[Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army]] units near Manbij, and returned fire in a short firefight.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/30/world/middleeast/isis-syria-lebanon-us-military.html |title=U.S. Airstrikes Block Convoy Transferring ISIS Fighters |last=Nordland |first=Rod |newspaper=New York Times |date=30 August 2017 |accessdate=6 September 2017}} On 29 August, after the [[Qalamoun offensive (July–August 2017)|Qalamoun offensive]], ISIL militants were surrounded by Lebanese, Hezbollah and Syrian forces on both sides of the Lebanese-Syrian border and therefore negotiated a safe-passage deal so that 670 ISIL fighters and their relatives were to be taken from the border in vehicles to [[Abu Kamal]]. The US military disapproved of the deal, Colonel Ryan Dillon, a spokesman for the US-led coalition said the deal undermined efforts to fight the ISIL in Syria; US aircraft carried out airstrikes, blocking the road the ISIL convoy was travelling on, before it reached ISIL-occupied territory in [[Deir ez-Zor Governorate]]. Dillon added that other US airstrikes hit militants apparently attempting to join the stranded militants in the convoy. The ''Independent'' later reported that the convoy was trapped the towns of Humayma and al-Sukhnah.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/us-led-coalition-isis-syria-iraq-hezbollah-islamic-state-brett-mcgurk-deir-al-zour-a7927391.html|title=Isis convoy 'escape in civilian vehicles' after US-led coalition bombs road to stop them fleeing Syria|publisher=the Independent|date=3 September 2017}} =====September 2017===== On 3 September, the ''Independent'' reported that 400 ISIS militants and their families traveling in the convoy that was trapped by US airstrikes in Syria in late August, abandoned their vehicles and began travelling on foot to the Iraqi border. =====December 2017===== ''CNN'' reported that on 12 December, [[Revolutionary Commando Army|Maghawir Al-Thawra]] fighters accompanied by US advisers intercepted a convoy of about 10 vehicles that was passing through the 55 km "de-confliction" zone surrounding the coalition base at Al-Tanf, a firefight ensued resulting in 21 ISIL terrorists killed and a further 17 captured.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/14/politics/us-syria-battle-isis/index.html|title=Exclusive: US troops and Syrian forces battle ISIS near key base|publisher=CNN|date=15 December 2017}} ''CNN'' reported that on 13 December, two U.S. F-22A fighters intercepted two Russian Su-25s jets that crossed the "de-confliction line" multiple times, an Air Forces Central Command spokesman said that "The F-22s conducted multiple maneuvers to persuade the Su-25s to depart our de-conflicted airspace, including the release of chaff and flares in close proximity to the Russian aircraft and placing multiple calls on the emergency channel to convey to the Russian pilots that they needed to depart the area." One US defense official said that a Russian Su-35 fighter was also involved in the incident.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/14/politics/us-f-22-intercept-russian-jets-syria/index.html|title= US F-22s intercept Russian jets over Syria, fire warning flares|publisher=CNN|date=15 December 2017}} On 22 December, Australian Defense Minister [[Marise Payne]] said that Australia will end air strikes against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and bring its six Super Hornet planes back home. She also added that other Australian operations in the region would continue, with 80 personnel who are part of the Special Operations Task Group in Iraq, including Australian special forces, continuing their deployment.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/australia-to-end-air-strikes-in-iraq-and-syria-bring-super-hornets-home-124613|title=Australia to end air strikes in Iraq and Syria, bring Super Hornets home - World News|website=Hürriyet Daily News}} ====2018==== =====January 2018===== ''Military Times'' reported on 12 January that Coalition aircraft carried out more than 90 airstrikes between January 4 and January 11 near the Iraq-Syria border.{{cite web|url=https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2018/01/12/more-than-90-airstrikes-pummel-last-isis-stronghold-in-syria/|title=More than 90 airstrikes pummel last ISIS stronghold in Syria|publisher=Military Times|date=12 January 2017}} ''Military Times'' reported that on 20 January, U.S. airstrikes targeting an ISIS headquarters and command and control center in the Middle Euphrates River Valley near [[Al-Shaafah|Al-Shafah]] killed nearly 150 ISIS militants, according to a press release SDF fighters provided target observation and intelligence on the target.{{cite web |url=https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2018/01/23/us-airstrikes-decimate-nearly-150-isis-militants/ |title=US airstrikes decimate nearly 150 ISIS militants |publisher=Military Times |date=23 January 2018 |accessdate=2018-11-20}} =====February 2018===== {{Main|Battle of Khasham}} According to the U.S. military officials, on 7 February in deliberate air and artillery strikes, the U.S.-led coalition killed more than 100 pro-government fighters in eastern Syria, in the Euphrates River valley in the province of Deir Ezzor, after they launched an "unprovoked attack" against the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF).[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/02/08/us-kills-100-assad-regime-fighters-largest-deliberate-strike/ US kills more than 100 Assad regime fighters in largest deliberate strike against Syrian government forces] The Telegraph, 8 February 2018. Syrian state news corroborated the events, but insisted that the Kurdish forces were mixed in with ISIS forces; it also stated that 10 Russian mercenaries were among those killed.[https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/us-attack-pro-govt-forces-deir-ezzor-killed-10-russians-photos/ US attack on pro-gov’t forces in Deir Ezzor killed more than 10 Russians (photos).] Al-Masdar News. =====March 2018===== ''CNN'' reported that on 30 March, [[Master sergeant#U.S. Army|Master Sergeant]] Jonathan J. Dunbar of Delta Force and [[Sergeant#United Kingdom|Sergeant]] Matt Tonroe of the British Special Air Service were killed by an IED blast during a mission in Manbij, the objective of mission was what Pentagon spokesman Major Adrian Rankine-Galloway described as "kill or capture a known ISIS member."{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/02/politics/us-british-soldiers-killed-syria-isis-kill-mission/index.html|title=US and British soldiers killed in Syria were on ISIS 'kill or capture' mission|publisher=CNN|date=2 April 2018}} =====April 2018===== {{main|2018 bombing of Damascus and Homs}} On 14 April, [[Donald Trump]], [[president of the United States]], announced that the US, [[France]], and the [[United Kingdom]] had decided to carry out a series of military strikes against the [[Syrian government]] of [[Bashar al-Assad]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/13/politics/trump-us-syria/index.html|title=Trump: US launches strikes on Syria|last=CNN|first=Kevin Liptak, Jeff Zeleny and Zachary Cohen,|work=CNN|access-date=14 April 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/u-taken-decision-strike-syria-fox-news-010058571.html|title=U.S. has taken decision to strike Syria: Fox News|access-date=14 April 2018|language=en-US}} The strikes came in the wake of the [[Douma chemical attack]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria/trump-says-ordered-precision-strikes-against-syria-chemical-weapons-capabilities-idUSKBN1HJ0ZS|title=Trump says ordered precision strikes against Syria chemical weapons...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=14 April 2018|language=en-US}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-launches-missile-strikes-in-syria/2018/04/13/c68e89d0-3f4a-11e8-974f-aacd97698cef_story.html|title=U.S. launches missile strikes in Syria|first1=Anne|last1=Gearan|first2=Missy|last2=Ryan|date=13 April 2018|publisher=|via=www.washingtonpost.com}} =====May 2018===== On 1 May, the SDF, in coordination with the [[Iraqi Armed Forces]], announced the [[Deir ez-Zor offensive (September 2017–present)#Offensive resumes|resumption]] of their Deir ez-Zor offensive to capture the final ISIL pockets near the Iraqi border and along the Euphrates.{{cite news|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/030520181|title=SDF advance 8km against ISIS in Deir ez-Zor|work=Rudaw|date=3 May 2018}} By 3 May, the [[USS Harry S. Truman]] [[Carrier Strike Group 8|aircraft carrier strike group]] had joined the SDF's anti-ISIL operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.c6f.navy.mil/news/truman-strike-group-conducts-aviation-ops-support-oir|title=Truman Strike Group Conducts Aviation Ops in Support of OIR|date=3 May 2018}} =====June 2018===== One 21 June, US-led Coalition conducted airstrike against Syrian army positions in east of Homs, resulting with the killing of at least 1 Syrian soldiers.{{cite web|url=https://sputniknews.com/middleeast/201806211065644823-syria-homs-coalition-strike-casualties/|title=US-Led Coalition Strikes Syria's Homs Province: Syrian Soldier Killed - Reports|first=|last=Sputnik|website=sputniknews.com}} On 22 June, US-led coalition spokesman claimed that they responded to an attack by an "unidentified hostile force" near [[al-Tanf]].{{cite web|url=https://sputniknews.com/middleeast/201806221065667208-shelling-us-military-advisers-al-tanf/|title=Unknown Force Shells US Military Advisers, Allies in al-Tanf - Coalition|first=|last=Sputnik|website=sputniknews.com}} [[File:Second us turkey joint patrol.jpg|thumb|U.S. and Turkish forces conduct joint patrols on the outskirts of Manbij, Syria, 8 November 2018]] =====November 2018===== On 1 November, the Coalition began a series of [[2018 northern Syria border clashes|joint patrols]] with the [[Turkish Armed Forces]] along the frontlines of the [[Manbij Military Council|Kurdish]]-controlled [[Manbij District|Manbij]] region and the [[Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army]]'s [[Operation Euphrates Shield|territory]]. The move was seen as a part of a "roadmap" to ease tensions between the two [[NATO]] allies and reduce violence between Kurdish and Turkish elements.{{cite news|url=https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2018/11/01/us-turkey-begin-joint-patrols-around-northern-syrian-town-of-manbij/|title=US, Turkey begin joint patrols around northern Syrian town of Manbij|date=1 November 2018}} On 21 November, [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[Jim Mattis]] announced the U.S. would set up new [[observation post]]s along the Turkish border in northern Syria in order to reduce [[skirmish]]es between Turkish forces and armed Kurdish militants in the region such as the [[2018 northern Syria border clashes|border clashes]] in late October-early November. Mattis affirms it is a co-operational endeavor with Turkey and it will not require additional US troops to be deployed to Syria.{{cite news|url=https://www.armytimes.com/news/your-army/2018/11/21/the-us-military-is-putting-brand-new-observation-posts-in-northern-syria/|title=The US military is putting brand new observation posts in northern Syria|date=21 November 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/syria/211120182|title=US to establish observation posts on Syria-Turkey border: Mattis|work=[[Rudaw Media Network]]|date=21 November 2018}} === Airstrikes on the Khorasan Group === [[File:Sept 23 ISIL compound strike.WebM|thumb|A U.S. Air Force fighter jet drops ordnance on an ISIL compound in Raqqa, Syria on 23 September 2014.]] One of the groups targeted by U.S. airstrikes was the [[Khorasan (Islamist group)|Khorasan Group]], an [[Islamic extremism|extremist]] group of suspected al-Qaeda "core" members who were alleged to have been plotting an attack against the U.S. and other Western nations. The strikes targeted Khorasan training camps, explosives and munitions production facilities, communications facilities, as well as command and control facilities. The group has been claimed to possess advanced bomb making skills and their plot is claimed to involve a bomb made of a nonmetallic device such as a toothpaste container or clothes dipped in explosive material.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/22/world/meast/al-qaeda-syria-khorasan/|title=Source: Al Qaeda group in Syria plotted attack against U.S. with explosive clothes|publisher=CNN|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|last = Levis|first = Josh|last2 = Cruickshank|first2 = Paul|last3 = Lister|first3 = Time}} The group is reportedly led by [[Muhsin al-Fadhli]], a leader of [[al-Qaeda]] and a close confidant of [[Osama bin Laden]]. Intelligence officials expressed concern that the group may include militants who were taught by [[Ibrahim al-Asiri]], the chief bomb maker for [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]], who is known for his sophisticated bomb making techniques that nearly downed two Western airliners. Later statements by government officials indicated that the threat of a plot may have been less severe than initially reported.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/25/world/middleeast/khorasan-a-terror-cell-that-avoided-the-spotlight.html|title=A terror cell that avoided the spotlight|date=24 September 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|last = Mazzetti|first = Mark}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/25/us-officials-terror-group-khorasan-syria|title=US officials unclear on threat posed by obscure al-Qaida cell in Syria|date=25 September 2014|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=6 October 2014|last = Ackerman|first = Spencer}} One official indicated that "there did not yet seem to be a concrete plan in the works", while another told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that "there was no indication of an imminent domestic threat from the group" at the time the United States began bombing. On 6 November, a second round of airstrikes was launched against Khorasan and al-Nusra in northwestern Syria, along with [[Ahrar ash-Sham]] at its headquarters in [[Idlib]], whose leadership had been infiltrated by al-Qaeda. On 13 November 2014, the US launched a third set of airstrikes against Khorasan.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/us-bombs-al-qaeda-offshoot-khorasan-third-time-233406321.html|title=US bombs Al-Qaeda offshoot Khorasan for third time|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=13 November 2014|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|agency = [[Agence France-Presse]]}} On 19 November, the US carried out another airstrike on Khorasan near [[Hazm, Hama|Hazm]], which struck and destroyed a storage facility associated with the group. On 1 December, the US carried out another airstrike on Khorasan near Aleppo. On 24 March 2015, it was revealed that the US airstrikes on Khorasan had killed 17 militants from the group.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/analysis/2015/03/24/Nusra-Front-quietly-rises-in-Syria-as-ISIS-targeted.html|title=Nusra Front quietly rises in Syria as ISIS targeted|work=Al Arabiya|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=9 January 2016}} On 8 July 2015, a US airstrike near the town of [[Sarmada]] in [[Idlib Governorate|Idlib]], Syria, killed [[Muhsin al-Fadhli]], the leader of Khorasan. === Syrian reaction to the airstrikes === Syrian military radar was "[[passive radar|passive]]" during the first air strikes, with no attempt to counter US aircraft.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/syria-informed-in-advance-of-us-led-airstrikes-against-islamic-state/2014/09/23/848d79ae-4315-11e4-b437-1a7368204804_story.html|title=Syria informed in advance of U.S.-led airstrikes against Islamic State|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=24 September 2014|newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]|last = Collard|first = Rebecca|last2 = Murphy|first2 = Brian}} During the first night of airstrikes, the United States' force deployed with [[AGM-88 HARM|HARM missiles]] as a precaution, as it was uncertain how Syria's air-defense network would react.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/10/syria-united-states-warplanes-111748.html|title=Syria could threaten U.S. warplanes|date=9 October 2014|accessdate=26 December 2014|newspaper = [[Politico]]|last = Ewing|first = Philip}} In response to the errant airstrike of its forces in September 2016, the [[Syrian Armed Forces]] called it a "serious and blatant attack on Syria and its military". === Reports of civilian casualties and war crimes=== The website Airwars which "maintains an extensive database of all known allegations in which civilians and friendly forces have been reported killed by the Coalition since August 2014" reports between 503 and 700 civilians killed by Coalition airstrikes in Syria as of April 2016.{{cite web|url=http://airwars.org/civilian-casualty-claims/|title=Civilian and 'friendly fire' casualties|work=airwars.org|accessdate=19 April 2016}} On 29 September 2014, several groups including the [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]], the Aleppo Media Center, and the Local Coordination Committees reported that U.S. strikes hit a grain silo in the ISIL-controlled town of Manbij in northern Syria, killing two civilians.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2773864/Civilians-killed-US-airstrike-ISIS-controlled-region-Syria-missiles-hit-grain-silos-say-British-human-rights-group.html|title=U.S. airstrikes on ISIS 'killed Syrian civilians after mistaking grain silo for jihadist base'|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=30 September 2014|newspaper = [[Daily Mail]]|last = Crone|first = Jack|last2 = Crossley|first2 = Lucy}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/09/29/us-led-airstrikes-hit-four-syrian-provinces-activists-claim-civilians-killed/|title=US-led airstrikes hit four Syrian provinces, activists claim civilians killed|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=30 September 2014|agency = [[Associated Press]]}} The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported ten airstrikes, also targeting various parts of the [[Idlib Governorate|province of Idlib]], killed at least one child and six other civilians. The group said at least 19 civilians had been killed in coalition airstrikes at that time.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/09/isil-closes-border-town-kobane-with-turkey-20149302422265674.html|title=ISIL closes in on border town with Turkey|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=30 September 2014}} The Pentagon reported it had no evidence of any civilian casualties from airstrikes targeting militants in Syria.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/219195-pentagon-no-evidence-airstrikes-killed-civilians-in-syria|title=Pentagon: No evidence airstrikes killed civilians|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|first = Kristina|last = Wong}} The United States has also acknowledged that its rules to avoid civilian casualties are looser in Syria than those for drone strikes elsewhere.{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21621863-are-american-led-air-strikes-creating-sunni-backlash-unintended-consequences|title=Unintended consequences: Are U.S.-led air strikes creating a Sunni backlash?|date=4 October 2014|accessdate=3 October 2014|work = [[The Economist]]}} The SOHR and other activist groups, reported that seven civilians were killed when an air strike hit a gas distribution facility near the town of al-Khasham is the eastern Deir al-Zor province on 17 October 2014 and three civilians were killed in an air strike on 16 October 2014 in the north east province of al-Hassakah. According to their reports, most of the civilians killed were fuel tanker drivers.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/18/us-airstrike-isis-gas_n_6007780.html|title=U.S. Coalition Airstrike On ISIS Gas Station Kills 8 In Syria: Activists|publisher=Huffington Post|date=18 October 2014|accessdate=18 October 2014|agency = [[Associated Press]]|last = Becatoros|first = Elena|last2 = Hadid|first2 = Dia}} [[File:Destroyed neighborhood in Raqqa.png|thumb|Destroyed neighborhood in [[Raqqa]] in August 2017]] According to [[Reuters]], 50 civilians were killed in Syria by US-led airstrikes, since the start of the campaign in late September 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/12/us-mideast-crisis-syria-toll-idUSKCN0IW0W420141112?irpc=932|title=U.S.-led strikes have killed 865 people in Syria, 50 civilians: monitor|publisher=Reuters|date=12 November 2014|accessdate=14 November 2014|last = Westall|first = Sylvia|location = [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]]|editor-last = Chopra|editor-first = Toby}} On 28 December 2014, a U.S. airstrike in the northern Syrian town of [[Al-Bab]] killed more than 50 civilians.{{Cite news|url = http://www.ibtimes.com/northern-syria-coalition-airstrike-killed-least-50-civilians-december-report-1780248|title = Northern Syria Coalition Airstrike Killed At Least 50 Civilians In December: Report|last = Pandey|first = Avaneesh|date = 12 January 2015|work = [[International Business Times]]|access-date = 19 January 2015}} On 21 May 2015, the United States admitted it "probably" killed two children in bombings near [[Harem, Syria|Harem]] on 4 and 5 November 2014. These are the first such admissions of the campaign, and followed a military investigation. A similar investigation regarding an event in Syria is underway, and two regarding events in Iraq.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32840132|title=Syria crisis: 'Children died' in US air strike|work=BBC News}} Two adult civilians were also minorly injured in the Harem strikes. The deaths and injuries are attributed by the military investigation to unintentional secondary explosions, after the bombers hit their intended targets, linked to the [[Khorasan (Islamist group)|Khorasan]].{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/05/21/mideast-crisis-casualties-usa-idINKBN0O62JW20150521|title=U.S. admits two children killed in Islamic State campaign|work=Reuters India}} On 19 July 2016 a coalition led airstrike on the ISIL controlled villages of Tokhar and Hoshariyeh reportedly killed at least 56 civilians, including 11 children.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/us-coalition-airstrikes-isis-syria-allegedly-kill-civilians-manbij/ | title=Dozens of civilians killed in alleged U.S. coalition strikes in Syria | work=[[CBS News]] | date=19 July 2016 | agency=[[Associated Press]] | accessdate=19 July 2016}} On 3 August 2016, dozens of civilians were killed after an airstrike in [[Al-Qa'im (town)|al-Qa'im]], some sources claiming that 30 were killed.http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/aerial-bombing-in-anbar-kills-civilians/ At least 33 people were killed in a U.S.-led coalition airstrike on a school near Raqqa in March 2017"[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/s-coalition-syria-air-strike-raqq-isis-school-killed-al-mansoura-human-rights-observatory-a7642781.html US-led coalition air strike in Syria kills more than 30 people in school near Isis-held Raqqa, says human rights watchdog]". ''The Independent''. 22 March 2017. in what is described as war crime.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} On 16 March 2017, a U.S. airstrike in rebel-held Aleppo [[2017 Syrian mosque airstrike|killed at least 46 people]] and wounded more than 100 after warplanes hit a [[mosque]]."[https://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/34685331/us-claims-syria-strike-denies-targeting-mosque-where-46-killed/ US claims Syria strike, denies hitting mosque where 46 killed]". Yahoo News. 18 March 2017. According to ''Airwars'',"[https://www.smh.com.au/world/usled-coalition-killed-up-to-6000-civilians-in-fight-against-is-watchdog-says-20180119-h0kpx3.html US-led coalition killed up to 6000 civilians in fight against IS: watchdog says]". ''The Sydney Morning Herald.'' 18 January 2018. the strikes of U.S.-led coalition killed as many as 6,000 civilians in Syria and Iraq in 2017."[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/civilian-deaths-tripled-in-us-led-campaign-during-2017-watchdog-alleges/2018/01/18/ccfae298-fc6d-11e7-a46b-a3614530bd87_story.html Civilian deaths tripled in U.S.-led campaign against ISIS in 2017, watchdog alleges]". ''The Washington Post.'' 18 January 2018. On 2 May 2018, Britain's [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defense]] admitted for the first time that a civilian was "unintentionally" killed in an anti-ISIL [[General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper|drone]] strike on 26 March 2018. According to the MoD, the civilian was on a motorbike and entered the target area at the last minute. [[Secretary of State for Defence|Defense Secretary]] [[Gavin Williamson]] said the incident was "deeply regrettable".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-43977394|title=Syria war: MoD admits civilian died in RAF strike on Islamic State|work=[[BBC News]]}}{{cite news|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/02/syria-raf-airstrike-kills-civilian-uk-campaign|title=Syria: RAF admits drone strike killed civilian in attack targeting Isis}} ===Results=== According to CJTF-OIR, by May 2016, ISIL has lost 25% of the territory it possessed in Syria since the campaign began, mostly due to advances by YPG/SDF forces with heavy Coalition air support.Jim Michaels, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/05/17/exclusive-isil-loses-45-territory-iraq-20-syria/84499682/ "ISIL loses 45% of territory in Iraq, 20% in Syria "], USA Today, 19 May 2016. Overall the American-led air campaign against ISIL is estimated by the Pentagon to have struck 32,000 targets (including 164 tanks, 400 Humvees, and 2,638 pieces of oil infrastructure) and killed 50,000 militants, with approximately 1/3 of these losses taking place in Syria.Barbara Starr. [www.cnn.com/2016/12/09/politics/isis-dead-us-military/ "Military: 50,000 ISIS fighters killed"]. CNN. 9 December 2016. == Air supply == On 20 October 2014 the United States began airdropping supplies to [[Syrian Kurdistan|Syrian Kurdish]] forces, including the [[People's Protection Units|YPG]], in Kobanî.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/20/world/meast/isis-airstrikes/|title=U.S. airdrops weapons, medical supplies to fighters in Kobani|publisher=CNN|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=20 October 2014|last = Walker|first = Brian}} The Kurdish forces there have been engaged in battle with ISIL during the [[Siege of Kobanî]]. Prior to 20 October, the United States and its coalition partners fighting against ISIL in Syria, had not provided any supplies to Kurdish forces in their fight against ISIL. Much of the reason for US having to airdrop supplies was due to the Turkish government's refusal to allow supplies to pass through their border into Kobanî. The U.S. specifically airdropped weapons, ammunition, and medical supplies supplied by [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] specifically to supply the Kurdish forces in Syria. On 21 October, a video was released by ISIL showing what it claimed was a bundle of airdropped small arms, ammunition, and other supplies from the United States. The Pentagon said it was analyzing the video and could not at the time confirm whether the video was authentic but that the materials were similar and video would be analyzed by the Department of Defense to analyze its authenticity.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29715044|title=Islamic State: US probes 'stray Syria air drop' in IS video|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 October 2014|accessdate=21 October 2014}} On 22 October, the Pentagon confirmed that one of the airdrops had been intercepted by ISIL but that it most likely would not give ISIL any real advantage in their operations.{{cite news|url=http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=123464|title=One Airdrop to Kurds Fighting in Kobani Intercepted|publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]|date=22 October 2014|accessdate=22 October 2014}} == Ground forces == {{see also|Al-Tanf (US base)}} [[File:BatailledeManbij2.jpg|300px|thumb|left|[[Syrian Democratic Forces]] soldiers in [[Manbij]]]] During the beginning of the coalition interventions, leaders including U.S. President Obama, said coalition ground forces would not be used in the fight against ISIL either in Iraq or Syria unless they were local coalition forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/why-obamas-assurance-of-no-boots-on-the-ground-isnt-so-reassuring/2014/09/26/c56d859e-44bf-11e4-9a15-137aa0153527_story.html|title=Why Obama's assurance of 'no boots on the ground' isn't so reassuring|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]|last = Brooks|first = Rosa}} While in Iraq thousands of coalition troops from the United States and other nations have been deployed in an advisory capacity, in Syria no ground troops from the coalition intervening in Syria were deployed in the beginning of the intervention.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/16/politics/boots-on-the-ground-semantics/|title=When are troops 'advisers' and when are they 'boots on the ground'?|publisher=CNN|date=16 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|last = Diamond|first = Jeremy}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/09/25/obama-syria-iraq-air-strikes/16172893/|title=Analysis: Syria will test no-boots-on-ground strategy|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|newspaper = [[USA Today]]|last = Michaels|first = Jim}} In November 2015, The Obama administration began the deployment of U.S. special forces to Syria, on the mission of assisting rebel forces in their fight against ISIL, President Obama then ordered several dozen Special Operations troops into [[Rojava]] in northern Syria to assist local fighters battling the Islamic State, authorizing the first open-ended mission by American ground forces into the country.{{cite news |last1=BAKER |first1=PETER |last2=COOPER |first2=HELENE |author-link1=Peter Baker (author) |author-link2=Helene Cooper |date=30 October 2015 |title=Obama Sends Special Operations Forces to Help Fight ISIS in Syria |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/31/world/obama-will-send-forces-to-syria-to-help-fight-the-islamic-state.html |newspaper=The New York Times |location=WASHINGTON |access-date=30 October 2015}} ISIL's deputy leader in Syria, [[Abu Ali al-Anbari]], was killed by [[Joint Special Operations Command|JSOC]] special forces operatives in March 2016, in eastern Syria near the Syrian–Iraqi border, while he and three other ISIL members were traveling in a vehicle coming from [[Raqqa]]. The US Special Forces ordered him to exit the vehicle, intending to arrest him. When he refused and pulled out an assault rifle instead, US forces fired at the vehicle, killing him and the other passengers on board. US commandos also seized electronics and other documents during the operation for intelligence purposes.{{cite news |last1=Kesling|first1=Ben|last2=Entous|first2=Adam|last3=Paletta|first3=Damian|title=Senior Islamic State Leader Killed|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/senior-islamic-state-leader-killed-1458921361|accessdate=26 March 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=25 March 2016}} In March 2016, [[Abdullah II of Jordan|King Abdullah of Jordan]] said that British forces had helped in the building up of a mechanised battalion in southern Syria, consisting of tribal fighters to combat the [[Syrian Army]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/defence/12204658/Leaked-report-SAS-on-ground-in-Libya-for-months.html|title=Leaked report: SAS on ground in Libya for months|publisher=the Telegraph|date=25 March 2016}} On 17 March 2016, the day after the declaration of the [[Rojava|Federation of Northern Syria]], U.S. Defense Secretary [[Ashton Carter]] praised the [[Syrian Democratic Forces]] as having "proven to be excellent partners of ours on the ground in fighting ISIL. We are grateful for that, and we intend to continue to do that, recognizing the complexities of their regional role."{{cite web |title=Pentagon chief praises Kurdish fighters in Syria|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/pentagon-chief-praises-kurdish-fighters-in-syria.aspx?pageID=238&nID=96609&NewsCatID=352|work=Hurriyet Daily News|date=18 March 2016|accessdate=13 June 2016}} During the SDF's May 2016 offensive against ISIL in Northern Raqqa, [[Special Forces (United States Army)|U.S. Special Forces]] were widely reported and photographed to be present, and to wear badges of YPG and YPJ on their uniforms.{{cite news|title=U.S. Troops 18 Miles from ISIS Capital|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/26/u-s-troops-18-miles-from-isis-capital.html|date=27 May 2016|accessdate=27 May 2016|work=The Daily Beast}} On 21 May 2016, [[Joseph Votel]], commanding general of [[United States Central Command|U.S. Central Command]], completed a secret several-hour-long trip to northern Syria to visit several locations where there were U.S. special operations forces and meet with local forces the U.S. was helping train to fight ISIL. The visit came as the first of 250 additional U.S. special operations forces were beginning to arrive in Syria to work with local forces. The commander overseeing the war in [[Syria]], at the end of a long Saturday spent touring SDF bases, said "We do, absolutely, have to go with what we've got".{{cite web|url=http://wpo.st/fEbb1|title=The new coalition to destroy the Islamic State |work=The Washington Post)|date=22 May 2016}} In September 2016, the U.S. spokesman for the [[Combined Joint Task Force – Operation Inherent Resolve]] (CJTF–OIR) confirmed that the SDF, including the YPG, is also part of the "vetted forces" in the train and equip program and will be supplied with weapons. The [[President of Turkey]], [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], condemned this and claimed that the SDF are "endangering our future".{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2016/09/us-sending-arms-kurdish-led-sdf-syria-turkeys-erdogan-outraged/|title=US sending arms to Kurdish-led SDF in Syria, Turkey's Erdogan outraged|work=ARA News|date=25 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161031120226/http://aranews.net/2016/09/us-sending-arms-kurdish-led-sdf-syria-turkeys-erdogan-outraged/|archivedate=31 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} In October 2016, U.S. Army Lt. Gen. [[Stephen J. Townsend]], the commander of the international coalition against ISIL, said that the SDF would lead the impending assault on [[Raqqa]], ISIL's stronghold and capital, and that SDF commanders would plan the operation with advice from American and coalition troops.{{cite news|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/us-general-syrian-democratic-forces-will-lead-the-assault-on-raqqa-1.435953|publisher=Stars and Stripes|title=US general: Syrian Democratic Forces will lead the assault on Raqqa|date=26 October 2016|accessdate=31 October 2016}} From November, more than 300 U.S. Special Operations Forces were embedded to train and advise SDF fighters in the [[Northern Raqqa offensive (November 2016)|Raqqa offensive]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/24/world/middleeast/syria-warplanes-turkey.html?&moduleDetail=section-news-3|title=American Is Killed in First Casualty for U.S. Forces in Syria Combat|work=New York Times|date=24 November 2016}} In March 2017, the [[Donald Trump Administration]] deployed an additional 400 [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marines]] in Syria to expand the fight against ISIS in the [[Northern Raqqa offensive (November 2016)|Raqqa offensive]] where they could provide artillery support for U.S.-backed local forces that were preparing an assault on Raqqa to liberate the city from IS militants. The deployment marked a new escalation in the U.S. war in Syria, and put more conventional U.S. troops in the battle that, until then, had primarily used Special Operations units. The 400 Marines were part of the [[11th Marine Expeditionary Unit|11th MEU]] from the Battalion Landing Team [[1st Battalion, 4th Marines]]. They manned an artillery battery of M-777 Howitzers whilst additional infantrymen from the unit provided security and resupplies were handled by part of the expeditionary force's combat logistics element.{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2017/03/09/more-troops-in-syria-trump-orders/|title=More troops in Syria: Trump orders boots on the ground to battle ISIS|work=Salon|date=10 March 2017}} During the [[Raqqa campaign (2016–2017)|Raqqa campaign]] alone, this small artillery battalion fired over 40,000 shells (including 34,033 155mm), more than were used in the entire [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] and only 20,000 fewer than all those fired by the U.S. military in [[Operation Desert Storm]].[https://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/your-marine-corps/2018/02/06/these-marines-in-syria-fired-more-artillery-than-any-battalion-since-vietnam/ These Marines in Syria fired more artillery than any battalion since Vietnam.] Marines Corps Times. Feb 6 2018. In March 2018, SDF press secretary in Deir ez-Zor Mehdi Kobani reportedly told [[Sputnik News|Sputnik Turkiye]] that U.S. forces were building a "large military base" in the oil-rich al-Omar region of Deir ez-Zor as new equipment had been reportedly arriving to U.S. bases in Syria. The al-Omar oilfield is the largest oil deposit in Syria, and was captured by the SDF during their campaign against ISIL in October 2017.{{cite news|work=[[Al Masdar News]]|date=27 March 2018|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/us-establishes-large-military-base-in-oil-rich-syrian-province-sdf/|title=US establishes large military base in oil-rich Syrian province – SDF}}{{cite news|title=U.S. Bases On Syrian Oilfields Receive New Equipment|url=https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/US-Bases-On-Syrian-Oilfields-Receive-New-Equipment.html|date=21 March 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://southfront.org/sdf-confirms-reports-us-establishes-military-base-vicinity-syrias-largest-oil-field/|title=SDF Confirms Reports That US Establishes Military Base In Vicinity Of Syria's Largest Oil Field|date=27 March 2018}} The [[441st Air Expeditionary Squadron]] reportedly maintains an unpaved [[runway]] in [[Sarrin]], [[Raqqa Governorate]].{{cite tweet |user=FranticGoat |number=1004545403101032449 |date=June 6, 2018 |title=Lotta interesting stuff happening in this picture, reportedly taken in Syria. Armored forklift loading the MV-22 reportedly belongs to the 441st Air Expeditionary Squadron, which runs the site. h/t @obretix |first=Joseph |last=Trevithick |archive-url=https://archive.li/20180609015352/https://twitter.com/FranticGoat/status/1004545403101032449 |archive-date=June 9, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.defense.gov/News/Special-Reports/Videos/?videoid=604284&dvpcc=false |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |title=441st Air Expeditionary Squadron Civil Engineer Runway Repair |access-date=June 8, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://en.muraselon.com/2018/06/pictures-first-seen-ever-images-mini-us-airbase-syria-raqqa/ |publisher=Muraselon |title=Pictures: First Seen Ever Images Of Mini US Airbase In Syria’s Al-Raqqa |date=June 7, 2018 |quote=Nevertheless, opposition media said that the US airbase is located in “Sarrin” in the western countryside of Al-Raqqa. |archive-url=https://archive.li/20180609015201/https://en.muraselon.com/2018/06/pictures-first-seen-ever-images-mini-us-airbase-syria-raqqa/ |archive-date=June 9, 2018}} == Naming of Operation Inherent Resolve == {{main|Operation Inherent Resolve}} Unlike previous U.S. combat operations, no name had been given to the American intervention in Syria and Iraq until it was announced in mid-October that the operational name would be Inherent Resolve.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/113178.aspx|title=US military names coalition operation against Islamic State 'Inherent Resolve'|date=15 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|work = [[Al-Ahram]]|agency = [[Reuters]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.military.com/daily-news/2014/08/18/us-operation-against-isil-in-iraq-remains-nameless.html|title=US Operation Against ISIL in Iraq Remains Nameless|publisher=[[Military.com]]|date=18 August 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014|last = Sisk|first = Richard}} The decision to keep the conflict nameless drew considerable media criticism.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-war-on-isis-has-no-name-2014-10|title=The War On ISIS Has 'No Name|date=3 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014|work = [[Business Insider]]|last = Walker|first = Hunter}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/03/pentagon-operation-inherent-resolve_n_5928388.html|title=The Military Can't Come Up With A Name For Its War Against ISIS. We're Here To Help|date=3 October 2014|accessdate=6 October 2014|work = [[Huffington Post]]|last = Linkins|first = Jason}} == Turkish involvement == {{Update section|date=November 2018}} {{Main|Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War}} [[File:Turkish Army Captured Afrin 01.jpg|thumb|[[Turkish Land Forces|Turkish soldiers]] and [[Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army|Free Syrian Army]] fighters at the building in [[Afrin, Syria|Afrin]] that had hosted the [[Democratic Union Party (Syria)|PYD]]-led government of [[Afrin Region]], 18 March 2018]] [[Turkey]], a [[NATO]] member, has been involved in the [[Syrian Civil War]] since the beginning of hostilities. Turkey has trained and armed some members of the Free Syrian Army, and has been involved in certain [[Spillover of the Syrian Civil War#Turkey|spillover incidents]], however so far Turkey has not been involved in direct combat. On 2 October 2014, the Turkish Parliament authorized direct military action in both [[Iraq]] and [[Syria]] including using military force in Syria and Iraq as well as allowing coalition members to use bases in Turkey.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/10/02/Turkish-military-given-OK-for-Syria-Iraq-intervention.html|title=Turkey greenlights military ops in Syria, Iraq|date=3 October 2014|accessdate=3 October 2014|publisher = [[Al Arabiya]]}} Turkey has also stationed troops and tanks on its southern border near the Syrian border city of Kobanî.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/11129001/Isil-jihadists-bombard-Syrian-border-town-despite-allied-air-strikes.html|title=ISIL jihadists bombard Syrian border town despite allied air strikes|date=29 September 2014|accessdate=3 October 2014|newspaper = [[Daily Telegraph]]|last = Tait|first = Robert|location = [[Suruç|Mürşitpınar]], [[Turkey]]}} The Turkish government demanded several things to go along with them intervening against ISIL, including a buffer zone in Northern Syria, a [[no-fly zone]] over certain parts of northern Syria, ground troops from other countries, and the training of moderate opposition forces to fight both ISIL and al-Assad.{{cite news|url=http://english.cntv.cn/2014/10/11/ARTI1412984655681994.shtml|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|title=Turkey's Syria buffer zone idea not well received|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher = [[China Central Television]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/10/11/for-obama-enforcing-no-fly-zone-in-syria-would-mean-war-or-cooperation-with/|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=For Obama, enforcing no-fly zone in Syria would mean war or cooperation with Assad government|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher = [[Fox News Channel]]}} Turkey also holds sovereignty over the [[Tomb of Suleyman Shah]] 35 km inside Syria, where it maintains a small garrison of Special forces that is surrounded by ISIL-controlled territory.{{Cite news|url = http://www.businessinsider.com/the-fight-for-the-tomb-of-suelyman-shah-2014-10|title = ISIS Is Closing In On A Turkish Enclave Inside Of Syria — And Ankara Is Facing A Huge Dilemma|last = Rosen|first = Armin|date = 1 October 2014|work = [[Business Insider]]|access-date = 28 December 2014}} On 22 February 2015, the [[Turkish Army]] mounted a rescue operation across the border to evacuate its soldiers from the [[Tomb of Suleyman Shah]], an exclave of [[Turkey]] south of Kobanî. The Turkish convoy reportedly transited through Kurdish-held Kobanî ''en route'' to the tomb. One Turkish soldier was killed in what [[government of Turkey|Ankara]] described as an accident. The success of the operation was announced 22 February by Turkish Prime Minister [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31572257|agency=BBC News|title=Turkey enters Syria to evacuate Suleyman Shah tomb|date=22 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}} == Reactions == === Foreign reactions === * {{flagu|Australia}} – [[Tony Abbott]], the [[Prime Minister of Australia]], praised the intervention, saying that an international effort was needed in order to combat the ISIL threat. Despite Abbott's support for the intervention, the Australian Government said it is not likely to contribute forces to operations in Syria.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-09-26/government-to-decide-in-coming-days-on-joining-iraq-strikes/5770874|title=Islamic State: PM Tony Abbott says Government to decide in coming days on order to join Iraq air strikes|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=2 October 2014|publisher = [[ABC News (Australia)]]}} * {{flagu|Canada}} – [[Stephen Harper]], the [[Prime Minister of Canada]], said in October 2014 Canada would strike ISIL targets in Syria if the Assad government gave approval.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/10/03/harper-syria-airstrikes-isis-canada_n_5929436.html|title=Harper Says Canada Will Bomb ISIS In Syria If Murderous Despot Asks Him To|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=3 October 2014|accessdate=3 October 2014|last = Bolen|first = Michael}} New Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] called President Obama almost immediately after coming into office to inform him that Canada will be ceasing air operations in coordination with Americans. Trudeau did not give a time frame.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/10/21/middleeast/syria-iraq-isis-fight/|title=Canada to pull out of bombing campaign against ISIS|first=Jethro|last=Mullen, CNN|date=21 October 2015|work=CNN|accessdate=28 November 2015}} * {{flagu|Czech Republic}} – [[Lubomír Zaorálek]], the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Czech Republic]] supported the intervention against the Islamic State and said that it's important to keep supporting the ground forces in the battle against ISIS and the Czech Republic will keep providing military support to the [[Iraqi army]] and to the Kurdish Peshmerga. He also noted that air strikes won't defeat Islamic State. The [[Czech government]] said that ISIS is enemy not only for safety in the [[Middle East]], but also for security and stability in the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Europe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vlada.cz/cz/media-centrum/aktualne/ministr-zaoralek-podporil-mezinarodni-usili-v-boji-proti-tzv--islamskemu-statu--125104/|title=Ministr Zaorálek podpořil mezinárodní úsilí v boji proti tzv. Islámskému státu|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=19 July 2015|language=cs|publisher =[[Government of the Czech Republic]]}} * {{flagu|Ecuador}} – The Ecuadorian government opposed the airstrikes in Syria without the consent of the Syrian government.{{cite news|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/actualidad/onu-ricardo-patino-julian-assange.html|title=Cancillería ecuatoriana califica como 'inaceptable' la ofensiva contra Siria|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=25 September 2014|language=es|newspaper = [[El Comercio (Ecuador)|El Comercio]]}} * {{flagu|Egypt}} - Egyptian [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] expressed his government's support for the international campaign against ISIL, and a spokesperson for the Egyptian foreign ministry echoed his statements by reiterating the Egyptian government's willingness to back the war against ISIL.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/arab-backing-to-us-led-airstrikes-in-syria-widens-front-against-islamic-state/2014/09/23/85664a44-430c-11e4-b437-1a7368204804_story.html|title=Arab backing for U.S.-led airstrikes in Syria widens front against Islamic State|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=11 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]|last = Morris|first = Loveday}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/around-world-mixed-reaction-to-us-led-airstrikes-in-syria/2014/09/23/16985bb6-4352-11e4-9a15-137aa0153527_story.html|title=Around world, mixed reactions to U.S.-led airstrikes in Syria|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=11 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Washington Post]]|last = Morello|first = Carol|last2 = Gearan|first2 = Anne}} * {{flagu|Germany}} - [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)|German foreign minister]] [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] questioned whether President Obama's plan was adequate in order to combat ISIL and said Germany had not been asked to participate in airstrikes nor would it participate if asked.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/obama-isis-speech-reaction-germany-turkey-wont-join-airstrikes-syria-uk-wont-rule-them-out-1685828|title=Obama ISIS Speech Reaction: Germany, Turkey Won't Join Airstrikes In Syria; UK Won't Rule Them Out|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|work = [[International Business Times]]|last = Koplowitz|first = Howard}} * {{flagu|Iran}} - Iranian [[President of Iran|President]] [[Hassan Rouhani]] condemned ISIL's actions but also called the airstrikes in Syria "illegal" because they were conducted without the consent of the Syrian government.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-air-strikes-iran-says-us-attacks-on-isis-are-illegal-9751245.html|title=Syria air strikes: Iran 'says US attacks on Isis are illegal'|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=11 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Independent]]|last = Saul|first = Heather}} Iran's deputy foreign minister [[Hossein Amir Abdollahian]] was reported in Iranian media as saying that Iran had warned the United States that [[Israel]] would be at risk should the US and its allies seek to topple Syrian president Bashar al-Assad while fighting ISIL in Syria.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/11/iran-syria-israel-us-air-strikes-isis-assad|title=Iran warns of risk to Israel's security should US seek overthrow of Assad|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=11 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]}} * {{flagu|Israel}} - Israeli [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] said Israel fully supported the U.S. government's calls for united action against ISIL. * {{flagu|Japan}} - A spokesperson for the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said the Japanese government would continue to closely coordinate with the United States and other countries, along with offering support and cooperation in their strikes against ISIL.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/obama-speech-gets-muted-gulf-region-response-1410414757|title=Mixed International Reaction to Obama Plan on Islamic State|date=11 September 2014|accessdate=12 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]|last = Torry|first = Harriet|first2 = Nicholas|last2 = Winning|last3 = Meichtry|first3 = Stacy}} * {{flagu|Netherlands}} – [[Mark Rutte]], the [[Prime Minister of the Netherlands]], showed understanding for the intervention against ISIL in Syria and said that his government was exploring options to contribute in the fight against ISIL.{{cite news|url=http://www.dvhn.nl/nieuws/nederland/rutte-begrip-voor-bombardement-syrie-11706183.html|title=Rutte: begrip voor bombardement Syrië (Dutch)|work=[[Dagblad van het Noorden]]|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|language=nl}} * {{flagu|Russia}} – Alexander Lukashevich, Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, opposed the military intervention "without the consent of the legitimate government" and said that "this step, in the absence of a UN Security Council decision, would be an act of aggression, a gross violation of international law". On 14 October, Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] questioned the motives of the intervention, saying "Maybe their stated goal is not entirely sincere? Maybe it is [[regime change]]?" He also questioned the effectiveness of the year long campaign "With, as far as I know, 25,000 sorties they [US-led air campaign] could have smashed the entire [country of] Syria into smithereens," continuing to remark that "positive results 'on the ground' are not visible". He also criticized the continued supply of arms to rebels, saying "I want to be honest, we barely have any doubt that at least a considerable part of these weapons will fall into the terrorists' hands." He continued to call for the countries involved to join a coalition made up of [[Russia-Syria-Iran-Iraq-Jordan Coalition|Russian, Syrian, Iranian, Iraqi, Jordanian and Hezbollah forces]] against what Russia claims is solely ISIL and al Qaeda, but the US has asserted is primarily non-jihadist opposition forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/318615-syria-usa-results-lavrov/|title=Lavrov: Unclear what exactly US is doing in Syria & why results so insignificant|work=RT English|date=14 October 2015|accessdate=28 November 2015}}{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/07/russia-airstrikes-syria-not-targetting-isis|title = 'More than 90%' of Russian airstrikes in Syria have not targeted Isis, US says|date = 7 October 2015|work = |access-date = 14 October 2015|via = |agency = [[Agence France-Presse]]|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]}} Dmitry Peskov, spokesman for the Russian President Vladimir Putin, described the US air strikes on the Shayrat airbase as "an act of aggression against a sovereign state delivered in violation of international law under a far-fetched pretext.... a serious blow to Russian-US relations, which are already in a poor state".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-39526089|title=Syria war: World reaction to US missile attack|date=7 April 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov referred to the Sharyat attack as "an act of aggression under a completely invented pretext". He compared events in April 2017 to "the situation of 2003, when the USA, the UK and several of their allies invaded Iraq without the UN Security Council's approval - a grave violation of international law - but at that point they at least tried to show some material evidence." * {{flagu|Turkey}} – The [[2015 interim election government of Turkey|Davutoglu Government]] called on the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]] to approve measures that would grant extensive authority to the President to launch military operations in both Syria [[American-led intervention in Iraq|and Iraq]], including the authority to send troops across the border, although it is unclear whether the Turkish leadership intends to act on that authority. President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan has urged the establishment of a [[no-fly zone]] by coalition forces in northern Syria.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/turkey-government-to-seek-parliamentary-approval-to-join-campaign-against-islamic-state-1412077676|title=Turkey Government to Ask Parliament for Approval to Join Campaign Against Islamic State|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=30 September 2014|newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]]|last = Albayrak|first = Ayla|last2 = Parkinson|first2 = Joe}} * {{flagu|United Kingdom}} – A spokesperson for [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]] said the UK would not rule out airstrikes in Syria against ISIL. On 26 September 2014 Parliament voted 524 to 43 to approve action inside Iraq.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2014/sep/26/mps-debate-and-vote-on-air-strikes-against-islamic-state-politics-live-blog|title=UK parliament approves air strikes against Isis in Iraq – as it happened|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=26 December 2014|newspaper = [[The Guardian]]|last = Sparrow|first = Andrew|last2 = Phipps|first2 = Claire}} While visiting [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] in mid October, British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Philip Hammond]] said he saw no immediate demand from U.S. and Arab militaries for Britain to extend its airstrikes to Syria.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Oct-13/273941-britain-sees-no-early-demand-from-us-for-air-strikes-in-syria.ashx|title=Britain sees no early demand from U.S. for air strikes in Syria|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=13 October 2014|newspaper = [[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]|last = Coles|first = Isabel|agency = [[Reuters]]}} British Defense Minister Michael Fallon said on 21 October that British Reaper drones and Rivet Joint surveillance aircraft would be starting intelligence-gathering missions in Syria "very shortly." * {{flagu|United Nations}} – [[Ban Ki-moon]], [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN secretary-general]], welcomed the airstrikes against militants in Syria, but noted that the involved parties "must abide by international humanitarian law and take all precautions to avoid and minimize civilian casualties".{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Sep-23/271703-un-chief-welcomes-airstrikes-in-syria.ashx|title=UN chief welcomes airstrikes in Syria|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014|newspaper = [[Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]]|agency = [[Associated Press]]}} * {{flag|Venezuela}} – At the [[General Assembly of the United Nations|69th General Assembly of the United Nations]], President Nicolas Maduro said "It's President Bashar al-Assad and the Syrian government which have stopped the terrorists" and continued by saying "Instead of bombing and bombing, we must make an alliance for peace".{{cite news|last1=Shankar|first1=Sneha|title=Venezuela's Nicolas Maduro Calls For 'Re-Founding' Of UN; Slams US-Led Airstrikes In Iraq And Syria|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/venezuelas-nicolas-maduro-calls-re-founding-un-slams-us-led-airstrikes-iraq-syria-1694699|accessdate=5 October 2014|date=25 September 2014|work = [[International Business Times]]}}{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/world/2014/09/25/Venezuela-leader-calls-ISIS-a-Western-Frankenstein-.html|title=Venezuela leader calls ISIS a Western 'Frankenstein'|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=5 October 2014|agency = [[Agence France-Presse]]}} === Syrian reactions === * {{flag|Syria}} – A week before the first airstrikes, [[Ali Haidar (politician)|Ali Haidar]], the Syrian Minister of National Reconciliation, said that "any action of any kind without the consent of the Syrian government would be an attack on Syria". However, despite Haidar's original statement, after the coalition campaign began, the Syrian government struck a more conciliatory tone with Foreign Minister [[Walid al-Moallem]] suggesting the airstrikes were an indication that Syria and the anti-ISIL coalition were on the same side.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/syrian-foreign-minister-the-us-said-we-are-not-after-the-syrian-army-before-airstrikes-2014-9|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Syrian Foreign Minister: The US Said 'We Are Not After The Syrian Army' Before Airstrikes|date=30 September 2014|accessdate=3 October 2014|work = [[Business Insider]]|last = Karam|first = Zeina}} * {{flagicon|Syrian National Coalition}} [[Syrian opposition]] – Hadi Bahra, the leader of the [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces]] called for airstrikes against ISIL before the intervention began. The coalition is recognized by 20 countries, the European Union, and the Arab league as the legitimate representative of Syria in opposition to the [[Bashar al-Assad|Assad]] government. Bahra said strikes were needed to weaken ISIL, a faction in the [[inter-rebel conflict during the Syrian Civil War]], so that the [[Free Syrian Army]] and other moderate opposition forces could oppose Assad more effectively.{{cite news|url= http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2604d6bcf901452ab74000f2e769e54e/syrian-opposition-chief-urges-airstrikes-syria|title= Syrian Opposition Chief Urges Airstrikes in Syria|first= Zeina|last=Karam|quote=We must begin airstrikes in Syria — immediately as we speak. Time is of essence to avert catastrophe|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=4 October 2014|work = Associated Press}} Despite Bahra's support, many Syrian rebel groups have criticized U.S. airstrikes for targeting only ISIL who are enemies of the Assad government, while not also targeting Assad government forces, the results of which could help government forces gain more ground. Meanwhile, jihadist groups within the opposition have portrayed the coalition as an anti-Sunni stooge of the Syrian regime,{{cite
