revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | |name=Bristol International Balloon Fiesta |logo= |image=File:Bristol International Balloon Fiesta.JPG |caption= A 6am mass ascent |location=[[Ashton Court]], [[Bristol]] |country= [[United Kingdom]] |coordinates= {{coord|51.448|-2.645|display=inline}} |years_active=1979 - present |dates=August |founder_name= Don Cameron |genre=[[Hot air balloon festival]] |website={{URL|bristolballoonfiesta.co.uk}} }}
The '''Bristol International Balloon Fiesta''' is held annually in England. Teams from the UK and other parts of the world bring their [[hot air balloons]] to the site and participate in mass ascents where as many as 100 balloons may launch at a time.
The event was first held in 1979 and is now one of the largest in Europe. It is common to have crowds of over 100,000 on each of the four days of the festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bristol/content/articles/2008/03/20/balloon_fiesta2008_feature.shtml|title=Balloon Fiesta features|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 March 2010}}</ref> It takes place in a large country estate [[Ashton Court]]. Mass launches are made twice a day, at 6am and 6pm, subject to weather conditions. [[File:Map ashton court.png|thumb|220px|Location of [[Ashton Court]], where Fiesta takes place]] One popular attraction is the [[night glow]], when balloons are inflated and glow to music after dark. These are held on the opening Thursday night at approx 9:30pm, followed by a spectacular fireworks display. There is another night glow at the same time followed by the fireworks on the Saturday night. Some people see these as the highlight of the fiesta.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bristol/content/articles/2004/08/04/fiesta_nightglowguide_feature.shtml|title=Balloon Fiesta Night Glow punter guide|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 March 2010}}</ref>
The balloon makers [[Cameron Balloons]] are near to the fiesta site, in [[Bedminster, Bristol|Bedminster]], and make many of the special shaped balloons, which have included [[Rupert Bear|Rupert the Bear]], The Scottish Piper, [[Liquorice allsorts#Bertie Bassett|Bertie Bassett]], the [[Tesco]] Trolley, [[Despicable Me (franchise)|Stuart the Minion]], and the [[BBC One 'Balloon' idents|BBC One Balloon]]. Many shapes have also attended the fiesta from abroad, over the years a [[UFO]] and a [[beaver]] have travelled from the USA, a [[Kiwi|kiwi bird]] from New Zealand, and an upside down balloon from the Netherlands.
In the past, the fiesta used to be held in the second week of September, but due to cancellations of flights and the muddy ground because of bad weather, it has been moved in the start of August. This has had a great effect as more flights manage to fly; cancellations are now normally due to high winds.
[[Image:Bristol international Balloon fiesta 403.JPG|thumb|The nightglow is one of the most popular parts of the fiesta.]] In 2003, the weight of crowds returning from the Balloon Fiesta and [[Ashton Court festival]] put such a great strain on the [[Clifton Suspension Bridge]] that it was decided to close the bridge to all traffic, including pedestrians, during these events from 2004 onwards.<ref>{{cite web | title=Suspension bridge shut for events | work=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/4633715.stm | accessdate=2007-03-25 | date=2005-06-29}}</ref>
In recent years, the event has diversified to include small scale air displays, attracting the likes of [[The Blades (aerobatic team)|The Blades]], [[Eurofighter Typhoon#Airshow displays|Typhoon display team]] and the [[Red Arrows]].
On 10 August 2013 they broke a balloon fiesta record after 74 balloons landed in one field near the former [[Somerdale Factory]] in [[Keynsham]]. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Balloon-fiesta-record-74-balloons-land-near/story-19642727-detail/story.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2014-02-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222200313/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Balloon-fiesta-record-74-balloons-land-near/story-19642727-detail/story.html# |archive-date=2014-02-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The record was then broken a year later, when 90 balloons again landed in the former Cadbury's chocolate factory on 9 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolballoonfiesta.co.uk/news/116/dates-announced-for-2015-fiesta.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908000235/http://www.bristolballoonfiesta.co.uk/news/116/dates-announced-for-2015-fiesta.aspx |archivedate=2014-09-08 |df= }}</ref>
[[Image:BristolBalloonFiesta2013-masslanding.JPG|thumb|The mass-landing in 2013 at the former Cadbury's factory.]]
==See also== *[[Hot air balloon festival]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Bristol Balloon Fiesta}} * [http://www.bristolballoonfiesta.co.uk/ Official site]
{{Culture in Bristol}}
{{coord|51.4437|-2.64157|display=title}}
[[Category:Festivals in Bristol]] [[Category:Hot air balloon festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Somerset]] [[Category:Annual events in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1979]] [[Category:1979 establishments in England]] [[Category:Annual events in England]] [[Category:Sports festivals in the United Kingdom]]

{{about|the removal of land mines|the removal of naval mines|Minesweeping}} [[File:Colarmyminesweep.png|thumb|right|[[Colombia]]n soldier minesweeping.]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - The Combat Engineering Corps Newest Recruits.jpg|thumb|right|Israeli [[Combat Engineering]] soldier clears a minefield]]
'''Demining''' or '''mine clearance''' is the process of removing [[land mine]]s from an area, while '''minesweeping''' describes the act of detecting mines. There are two distinct types of mine detection and removal: military and humanitarian.
Minesweepers use many tools in order to accomplish their task. Tools have historically included many trained animals, including dogs and rats, but most often in the modern world minesweepers rely on metal detectors or vehicles with a wide variety of mechanical tools attached to them. Other methods have been developed to detect mines, including the use of trained marine mammals, bacteria, acoustics, and other more exotic methods.
== Military mine clearance == {{refimprove section|date=April 2013}} [[File:Defense.gov News Photo 110721-A-DK678-581 - A U.S. Army soldier throws a grappling hook to clear a potential mine field before advancing during a field training exercise at Fort Bragg N.C..jpg|thumb|A US soldier clears a mine using a [[grappling hook]] during training]] [[File:DeminingRoscheiderHof.webm|thumbtime=248|thumb|Demining after WWII, May 1945 (reenactment)]] In the combat zone, the process is referred to as '''mine clearance'''. According to the doctrine of the U.S. and other armies, mine clearance is carried out by [[combat engineering|combat engineers]].
The military priority is to breach the minefield quickly in order to create a safe path for troops or ships. Speed is vital, both for tactical reasons and because units attempting to breach the minefield may be under enemy fire. Both anti-personnel mines and anti-tank mines must be removed, although only in the lanes through which troops or vehicles are planned to advance.
The risk to [[sapper]]s is far greater because they may be called upon to perform clearance as tactics dictate, including operating under any weather conditions and on schedule; they can also be under enemy fire. Commanders may accept casualties in the process. Furthermore, it is accepted that mine clearance will be imperfect due to speed and there may be casualties from undiscovered mines. One advantage is that, in military operations, sappers are generally dealing with recently laid mines that respond predictably to clearance, have not 'migrated', and have not degraded (unless old stock was used; old mines can become unstable). In this they are often aided by [[technical intelligence]] on the current adversary's mines, which are usually of a single type.
In these mine clearance operations, the methods that are applied for detection and removal are quicker, but less exhaustive. These methods include those that detect and remove in a single action, such as mechanical demining, [[carpet bombing]], burning of the land or the use of [[Bangalore torpedo]]es or [[mine-clearing line charge]]s.
== Humanitarian demining == In times of relative peace, the process of mine removal is referred to as '''demining'''. This is a thorough, time-intensive process that seeks to locate any and all mines so that the land or sea area may be safely returned to normal use. It is vital that this process be exhaustive. Even if only a small handful of mines remain undiscovered, incomplete demining can actually lead to an increase in civilian mine casualties as local people re-occupy an area they previously avoided in the belief that it has been made safe. In this context demining is one of the tools of [[mine action]]. Coordinated by [[Mine Action Coordination Center]]s run by the [[United Nations]] or a host government, civilian [[mine clearance agencies]] are tasked with the demining. In post-conflict areas, minefields are often contaminated with a mixture of [[explosive remnants of war]] (ERW) that includes [[unexploded ordnance]] as well as landmines. In that context, the humanitarian clearance effort is often referred to as battle area clearance.
In some situations, clearing landmines is a necessary condition before other humanitarian programs can be implemented.<ref name="drmyths">'[http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/info/myths.html Landmines - Some Common Myths]" Demining Research website. University of Western Australia, updated January, 2000.</ref> A large-scale international effort has been made to test and evaluate existing and new technologies for humanitarian demining, notably by the EU, US, Canadian and Japanese governments and by the Mine Action Centres of affected countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itep.ws |title=International Test and Evaluation Program for Humanitarian Demining (ITEP) |publisher=Itep.ws |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310031206/http://www.itep.ws/ |archivedate=March 10, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://serac.jrc.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogsection&id=7&Itemid=51 |title=Serac Unit - :Metal detector Trials |publisher=Serac.jrc.it |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604015421/http://serac.jrc.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogsection&id=7&Itemid=51 |archivedate=June 4, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
Currently, Afghanistan and Iraq is consuming the largest amount of demining funds, with 24.8% and 15.1% respectively of the global spending on humanitarian demining.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mineaction.org/pms/visualization |title=Portfolio of Mine Action Projects - graphs and charts |publisher=[[UNMAS]] |accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref>
== Current humanitarian demining methods == The main methods used for humanitarian demining on land are: manual detection using [[metal detector]]s and prodders, detection by specially trained mine detection dogs, and mechanical clearance using armored vehicles fitted with [[mine flail|flails]], [[tiller]] or similar devices. There is an organization, [[APOPO]], that is training African rats to detect landmines much as dogs do, offering a local solution to countries in Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apopo.org/newsite/content/index.htm|title=A P O P O|publisher=A P O P O|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080802214756/http://www.apopo.org/newsite/content/index.htm| archivedate = August 2, 2008}}</ref> In many circumstances, the only method that meets the United Nations' requirements for effective humanitarian demining, the International Mine Action Standards (IMAS),<ref name="gichd.ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.gichd.ch/42.0.html|title=International Mine Action Standards (IMAS) project|publisher=Gichd.ch|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061212141823/http://www.gichd.ch/42.0.html| archivedate=December 12, 2006}}</ref> is manual detection and disarmament.<ref name="drwhatis">"[http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/info/what-is.html What Is Demining?]" Demining Research website. University of Western Australia, updated September 22, 1998.</ref> The process is typically slow, expensive and dangerous, although demining can be safer than construction work if procedures are followed rigorously.<ref name="drhelp">"[http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/info/help.html What you can do to help]" Demining Research website. University of Western Australia, updated January, 2000.</ref> New technologies may provide effective alternatives.
=== Manual detection with a metal detector === [[File:Detecteur de metal 501607 fh000007.jpg|thumb|Foerster Minex 2FD 4.500 [[metal detector]] used by the [[French army]].]] Metal detectors were first used, after their invention by the Polish officer [[Józef Kosacki]].<ref>''The History of Landmines'' by Mike Croll published in Great Britain in 1998 by Leo Cooper, Pen & Sword Books Ltd. {{ISBN|0-85052-628-0}}</ref> Allies used his invention, known as the [[Polish mine detector]], to clear the German mine fields during the [[Second Battle of El Alamein]] when 500 units were shipped to [[Field Marshal Montgomery]].<ref>"The Polish Contribution to The Ultimate Allied Victory in The Second World War" Tadeusz Modelski, Worthing, England 1986, Page 221</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=vSYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=popular+science+june+1941&hl=en&ei=cT2TTNqUB9Ofnwfn49ywCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=true Popular Science, May 1943, ''Detector Spots Buried Mines'']</ref> The "Polish" mine detector was later used together with the [[ERA mine-locator]] for detecting beach mines.<ref>The Royal Engineers Journal 1962-76 p34 "One man uses the early "Polish" mine-detector whilst others use the ERA mine-locator."</ref>
The first step in manual demining is to scan the area with [[metal detector]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gichd.org/fileadmin/pdf/LIMA/metal_detector_handbook.pdf |title=Metal detector handbook for humanitarian demining |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=November 8, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303171513/http://www.gichd.org/fileadmin/pdf/LIMA/metal_detector_handbook.pdf |archivedate=March 3, 2014 |df= }}</ref> which are sensitive enough to pick up most mines but which also yield about one thousand [[false positive]]s for every mine.<ref name="drwhatis" /> Some mines, referred to as [[minimum metal mine]]s, are constructed with as little metal as possible - as little as {{convert|1|g|oz}} - to make them difficult to detect. Mines with no metal at all have been produced, but are rare. Areas where metal is detected are carefully probed to determine if a mine is present; the probing must continue until the object that set off the metal detector is found.
=== Dogs === Well-trained [[dog]]s can sniff out explosive chemicals like [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] in landmines, and are used in several countries.<ref name="drdogs">[http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/k9/dogs-in-use.html "Mine Detection Dogs in Use"]. Demining Research website. University of Western Australia, updated March 28, 2000.</ref>
=== Rats === Like dogs, [[giant pouched rat]]s are being trained to sniff out chemicals like [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] in landmines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apopo.org|title=APOPO|publisher=APOPO|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref> These rats are currently working in minefields in [[Mozambique]] and are trained in Tanzania by [[APOPO]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reliefweb.int/rw/res.nsf/db900SID/OCHA-7FBE3S?OpenDocument |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080612000625/http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/res.nsf/db900SID/OCHA-7FBE3S?OpenDocument |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 12, 2008 |title=ReliefWeb » Vacancy » Management of APOPO Mine Action Operations |publisher=Reliefweb.int |date=July 31, 2008 |accessdate=September 10, 2009 }}</ref> The rats are called [[HeroRATS]].
These animals also have the advantage of being far lower mass than the human or dogs. They are less likely to set off small mines intended to injure or kill people, if the bomb-sniffing animal crosses directly over the top of a buried mine.
=== Mechanical clearance === Special machines effectively combine mine detection and removal into one operation. In the past, these machines were applied in both mine clearance and demining but are now generally used only for demining. They can be used to verify land that is not expected to be contaminated or as an extra layer of security after an area has been cleared by another method, such as dogs.
The machines consist of a special vehicle that is driven through the minefield, deliberately detonating the mines it drives over. These vehicles are designed to withstand the explosions with little damage. Some are operated directly with armour to protect the driver; some are operated under remote control. *[[Mine roller]]s and [[mine flail]]s. The roller method originated during [[World War I]] and the flail method during [[World War II]] but both are still used. Neither system is completely reliable and both will leave undetonated mines, requiring the minefield to be rechecked by another method. Mine flail effectiveness can approach 100% in ideal conditions, but clearance rates as low as 50–60% have been reported.<ref name="Geneva Report" >{{cite journal|title=A Study of Mechanical Application in Demining|publisher=Geneva International Centre for Humanitarian Demining|year=2004|url=http://www.gichd.org/fileadmin/pdf/publications/Mechanical_study/Mechanical_study_complete.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=July 23, 2007 }}</ref> This is well below the 99.6% standard set by the United Nations for humanitarian demining.<ref name="drwhatis" /> *[[Mine plow]] - a device in front of a tank that excavates the ground, exposing any mines or turning them upside down, which significantly lessens their effects if they explode. **The two of the above are sometimes combined on the same vehicle. *Modified long-armed demining [[bulldozer]]s are being used in a number of countries. They have the capability to remove vegetation before demining and can withstand antipersonnel and antitank landmines. Their long arms provide the benefit of reducing damage to the main body, especially to the operator's cab. The operator is protected from directional mines with {{convert|3|in|cm|adj=mid|-thick}} [[bulletproof glass]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.film.hitachi.jp/en/movie/movie705.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070507105101/http://www.film.hitachi.jp/en/movie/movie705.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 7, 2007 |title=Hitachi Now: The Challenge of Demining (Part 1) Returning fertility to the land and putting a smile on the face of the children |publisher=Film.hitachi.jp |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/gadgets/notag/japanese-contraption-safely-removes-landmines-8998.php|title=Japanese Contraption Safely Removes Landmines|publisher=Gizmodo.com|date=March 30, 2004|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref><!--<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ud2006.net/en/schedule/speaker/amemiya.html|title=Kiyoshi Amemiya: Invited Speaker – The 2nd International Conference for Universal Design in Kyoto 2006|publisher=Ud2006.net|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref> -->
Recently, armies have developed armored demining vehicles, and specially [[armored bulldozer]]s, that are remote controlled. This eliminates risk to the operator. Notable examples are the [[Caterpillar D7]] MCAP (United States) and [[Raam HaShachar]] [[Caterpillar D9]]N (Israel). <gallery mode="packed" heights="160" caption="Mechanical clearing equipment"> Sherman crab flail tank.jpg|World War II [[Sherman Crab]] mine-flail tank under test, April 27, 1944. Casspir vehicle Ai101503g1.jpg|The [[Casspir]], a steel, armor-bodied [[V-hull]]ed vehicle de-mining [[Bagram Air Base]] MaK Keiler working.JPEG|Mine clearing system ''Keiler'' of the [[German Army]] in [[Butmir]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] (1997). hydrema mine cleaning vehicle.jpg|[[Hydrema]] mine clearing vehicle. D9R-002.jpg|[[IDF Caterpillar D9]] [[armored bulldozer]] - used with the standard blade or a special mineplow for demining and removal of [[Improvised explosive device|IED]]s </gallery>
== Personal protective equipment == [[File:Spezialschuhe eines Minenraeumanzuges.jpg|thumb|Shoes of [[protective clothing]]]] Deminers may be issued [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE) such as helmets, visors, armoured gloves, vests and boots, in an attempt to protect them if a mine is set off by accident. IMAS specifies standards for such equipment but draws attention to its limitations and states that at close quarters, antipersonnel fragmentation mines and antitank mines overmatch PPE currently available.<ref name="gichd.ch"/> PPE can afford significant protection against antipersonnel blast mines, and these are more common. Related technologies that have been developed to improve safety include large, pillow-like pads strapped to the bottoms of shoes that distribute weight and dull the impact of footsteps, as very slight disturbances of the ground can tip off old, unstable, or intentionally sensitive mine triggers. First developed in 1954 by the British as overshoes that are first inflated by the combat soldier, this specialized footwear has become a needed item for some demining operations.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sdwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA106&dq=1954+Popular+Mechanics+January&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Pv4YT5SlG5PoggekxISEDA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=true "Inflatable Sneakers for Mine Field Distributes Weight Safely."] ''Popular Mechanics'', November 1954, p. 106.</ref>
== Removal methods ==
=== Removal methods in demining === In demining, once an object has been detected it is removed by one of the following methods: * Manual disarmament. * Remote burning of the explosive. Where possible, it is better to burn the explosive without detonation. [[Diethylene triamine]] (a close relative of [[ethylenediamine]]) reacts with TNT to generate heat. The compound that results from this reaction can then be combusted without detonation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanitarian-demining.org/demining/pubs/neutral/insituchem.asp |title=Humanitarian-demining.org |publisher= |accessdate=22 April 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060408184828/http://www.humanitarian-demining.org/demining/pubs/neutral/insituchem.asp |archivedate= 8 April 2006 |df= }}</ref> It has been reported that this amine is [[hypergolic]] with TNT, [[Tetryl]], [[Composition B]] and other TNT based explosives, but it does not react in the same way with RDX or [[PETN]]-based explosives. Other nitrogen-containing organic ligands (e.g. [[pyridine]], [[diethylamine]] and [[pyrole]]) are known to be hypergolic with TNT.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanitarian-demining.org/demining/pubs/neutral/eudem.asp |title=Humanitarian-demining.org |publisher= |accessdate=22 April 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050310215138/http://www.humanitarian-demining.org/demining/pubs/neutral/eudem.asp |archivedate=10 March 2005 |df= }}</ref> *Setting the mine on fire while avoiding high-order detonation. This can be done by cutting holes in the mine without detonating its contents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/tech/pn-chem/ecm.html|title=Electrochemical Machining for UXO Neutralisation|publisher=Mech.uwa.edu.au|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref>
=== Removal methods in mine clearance === Some removal methods that are not applied in humanitarian demining, but are common in mine clearance, include: * The [[Bangalore Torpedo]] of World War II — the predecessor to the [[mine-clearing line charge]] that clears a path through a minefield. This can also be done using the [[Antipersonnel Obstacle Breaching System]] or [[Giant Viper]], a hose-pipe filled with explosives and carried across a minefield by a rocket.<ref>{{cite web|author=John Pike|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/munitions/apobs.htm|title=Mk7 Antipersonnel Obstacle Breaching Systems (APOBS)|publisher=Globalsecurity.org|date=January 25, 2006|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref> * [[Helicopter]]s dragging a plow to overturn or detonate mines. This has the problem of bringing down the helicopter when the plow snags onto objects such as large rocks, but has been corrected by use of pressure-sensitive plow rakes which release when over-pressured. This does, however, affect its effectiveness as mines planted in hard ground or near rocks will not be detonated. * [[Cattle]] and other heavy livestock are often left to graze in mined areas in order to facilitate mine detonation. * The Nazi Germans used captured civilians who were chased across minefields to detonate the explosives. According to Laurence Rees, "[[Curt von Gottberg]], the SS-Obergruppenfuhrer who, during 1943, conducted another huge anti-partisan action called [[Operation Cottbus|Operation Kottbus]] on the eastern border of [[BSSR|Belorussia]], reported that 'approximately two to three thousand local people were blown up in the clearing of the minefields'."<ref>Laurence Rees (1999). ''[[War of the Century|War of the century: when Hitler fought Stalin]]''. [[BBC Books]]. p.118. {{ISBN|0-563-38477-8}}</ref>
== Case study == Along the China-Vietnam border are numerous minefields. These are the legacy of border clashes in the 1980s. The mines are mainly anti-personnel, and have kept large areas of arable land from use by local farmers. A typical demining process deployed by the Chinese is as follows. Firebreaks are dug around the minefield to be cleared. Then engineers would set the minefield on fire with flamethrowers. Key factors of this burning process are: thick vegetation covering the minefields; most anti-personnel mines are buried very close to the ground level; the mines are made of mostly either wood, thin metal or plastic. This burning process would usually destroy about 90% of the mines, as the mines are either detonated or melted. Mines which have trip wires would have these wires burned off. Demining teams then would plow the area with mine detectors. When the teams have cleared the mines, they would walk over the field hand in hand themselves to show to the locals that all the mines have been cleared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icbl.org/lm/2004/china|title=China , Landmine Monitor Report 2004|publisher=Icbl.org|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref>
== Detection methods under development == In 2003, the Rand Corporation published a comprehensive report on innovative methods of landmine detection.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rand.org/pubs/monograph_reports/MR1608/index.html |series= Monograph/Reports |title= Alternatives for Landmine Detection |publisher=RAND |date=2003 |accessdate= September 10, 2009}}</ref>
=== Advanced electromagnetic methods ===
==== Ground penetrating radar ==== Conventional metal detectors rely on electromagnetic signals with frequencies of the order of 10–100 kHz, which are not sensitive to plastic or wooden mine bodies and the high explosive block itself. The only part of a low-metal mine that they may be able to detect is the detonator. Much higher frequency signals (of the order of 1 GHz) are employed in Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) and these signals are also sensitive to the non-metallic parts of the mine. Unfortunately, as they are also affected by innocuous objects such as tree roots and stones and by local changes in soil moisture, it is difficult to distinguish a mine on a GPR image.
==== Dual-sensor ==== A hybrid approach employing both GPR and metal detector sensors in a single instrument has been developed by several companies and research organisations.
=== Biological detection ===
==== Honey bees ==== {{main article|Trained hymenoptera}} Research by the University of Montana has revealed that [[honey bee]]s can, with minimal training, be used to detect landmines with a far greater accuracy and far higher clearance rate than dogs or rats.<ref name="Journal of Mine Action">[http://maic.jmu.edu/JOURNAL/7.3/focus/bromenshenk/bromenshenk.htm "Bees used in Area Reduction and Mine Detection"]. Jerry J. Bromenshenk et al. Journal of Mine Action. Issue 7.3. December 2003.</ref>
==== Mammals ==== Recent experiments with the [[Gambian giant pouched rat]], also known as the African giant pouched rat, have indicated that it has the required sensitivity to smell, can be trained reliably with food-reward incentives, and is typically too small to set off the mines.<ref name="reuters">[http://www.aegis.com/news/re/2004/RE040956.html "Move Over Sniffer Dogs, Here Come Africa's Rats."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051205100017/http://www.aegis.com/news/re/2004/RE040956.html |date=2005-12-05 }} Reuters, September 27, 2004.</ref> These rats also offer a local solution to many African countries because they are indigenous to East Africa. These rats are trained by a non-profit, research organization called [[APOPO]] and are called HeroRATs. Additionally, experiments with [[electrode-guided rat]]s suggest that demining could one day be accomplished by guiding "ratbots" into areas that humans are unable to reach.<ref name="bbc">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1961798.stm "Here Come the Ratbots"]. BBC News, May 1, 2002.</ref>
Engineer Thrishantha Nanayakkara and colleagues at the University of Moratuwa in Sri Lanka have come up with a method where a [[dwarf mongoose]] is trained to detect landmines by smell and guided by a remote-controlled robot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/channel/tech/mg19826535.900-mongooserobot-duo-sniff-out-landmines-on-the-cheap.html|title=Mongoose-robot duo sniff out landmines|publisher=Technology.newscientist.com|date=April 26, 2008|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.seas.harvard.edu/~thrish/Books/Hedem_chap.pdf |title=A Human-Animal-Robot Cooperative System for Anti-Personal Mine Detection |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327111331/http://people.seas.harvard.edu/~thrish/Books/Hedem_chap.pdf |archivedate=March 27, 2009 }}</ref>
The [[U.S. Navy Marine Mammal Program]] uses [[California_sea_lion#Intelligence_and_trainability|sea lions]] and [[Military dolphin|dolphins]], among other species, in the detection of [[seamines]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spawar.navy.mil/sandiego/technology/mammals/mine_hunting.html|title=Mine Hunting Systems of the U.S. Navy Marine Mammal Program|publisher=Spawar.navy.mil|date=|accessdate=September 10, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414132416/http://www.spawar.navy.mil/sandiego/technology/mammals/mine_hunting.html|archivedate=April 14, 2009|df=}}</ref>
==== Plants ==== The [[mustard plant|mustard]] ''[[Arabidopsis thaliana]]'', one of the best-studied plants in the world, normally turns red under harsh conditions. But using a combination of natural mutations and genetic manipulation, scientists from Danish [[biotechnology]] company Aresa Biodetection, created a strain that only changes color in response to the [[nitrous oxide]] that leaks from landmines and other explosives. Because nitrous oxide can also be formed by [[denitrifying bacteria]], there is some risk of false positives using this technique, and researchers are attempting to make the plant less sensitive. The plants would aid demining by indicating the presence of mines through color change, and could either be sown from [[aircraft]] or by people walking through demined corridors in minefields. As of February 2005, no studies have been conducted with actual landmines, though successful studies have been done in greenhouses. In order to prevent the spread of this [[genetically modified organism]] into the wild, the plants have been further modified so that they will only sprout when provided with an external growth factor.<ref name="acf">[http://www.acfnewsource.org/science/mine_sniffing_plants.html Mine-sniffing Plants] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060105182641/http://www.acfnewsource.org/science/mine_sniffing_plants.html |date=January 5, 2006 }}. [[American Communications Foundation]], February 17, 2005. </ref><!--possibly other information at www.undp.org.vn/mlist/envirovlc/012004/post8.htm and http://www.aresa.dk/-->
==== Bacteria ==== A [[bacterium]], known as a [[bioreporter]], has been genetically engineered to [[fluoresce]] under [[ultraviolet light]] in the presence of [[trinitrotoluene|TNT]]. Tests involving spraying such bacteria over a simulated minefield successfully located mines. In the field, this method could allow for searching hundreds of acres in a few hours, which is much faster than other techniques, and could be used on a variety of terrain types. While there are some false positives (especially near plants and water drainage), even three ounces of TNT were detectable using these bacteria. Unfortunately, there is no strain of bacteria capable of detecting [[RDX]], another common explosive, and the bacteria may not be visible under desert conditions. Also, well-constructed munitions that have not had time to corrode may be undetectable using this method.<ref name="burlage">R.S. Burlage, M. Hunt, J. DiBenedetto, and M. Maston. [http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/others/ornl/rsb.html Bioreporter Bacteria For The Detection Of Unexploded Ordnance]. Excerpt from the Demining Research website.</ref>
=== Nuclear detection ===
There are two principal techniques to detect land mines through nuclear reactions. Both rely on the use of [[neutron]]s.
The first such technique relies on the fact that the vast majority of [[explosive]]s used in land mines are very [[nitrogen]] rich when compared with other materials. To detect such anomalies one may make use of the nuclear reaction
:<sup>14</sup>(n, γ)<sup>15</sup>N (10.8 MeV)
In practice a detection system using this reaction works by subjecting the mine to [[thermal neutrons]] while searching for the characteristic gamma ray emitted from the excited state in nitrogen-15; these photons will only be observed when an object containing nitrogen is being subjected to the neutron irradiation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull432/article4.pdf |title=IAEA.org |publisher= |accessdate=22 April 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927002301/http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull432/article4.pdf |archivedate=27 September 2006 |df= }}</ref> One possible neutron source is [[californium]]-252 which undergoes spontaneous [[Nuclear fission|fission]]. A better neutron source is to use a sealed tube electrostatic D-T neutron generation tube, this has the advantage that the [[tritium]] is much less [[radiotoxic]] than the californium so in the event of an accident such as an explosion, the nuclear mine detection equipment would pose a smaller threat to humans. This type of explosive detection has been proposed for use in [[airport security]] and for the detection of explosives in [[truck]]s coming into [[military]] bases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuke.hun.edu.tr/~lo/ak-drug.pdf |title=Aydin Karahan, "Drug and Explosive Detection" |publisher= |accessdate=22 April 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050213120534/http://www.nuke.hun.edu.tr/~lo/ak-drug.pdf |archivedate=13 February 2005 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/issues/2003/Jun/Fast_Neutron.htm NDM Article - Fast Neutron Technology Used for Explosive Detection<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008234043/http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/issues/2003/Jun/Fast_Neutron.htm |date=October 8, 2006 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bath.ac.uk/~lh226/idaho.pdf Batch.ac.uk] {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
An alternative way of spotting land mines through nuclear reactions with the help of neutrons is that of measuring the thermalization of neutrons. In this technique the soil is irradiated by fast neutrons and the flux of thermal neutrons scattering back is measured. The motivation for this technique is that explosives contain much higher concentrations of hydrogen, which is a very effective moderator of neutrons.<ref>356 IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NUCLEAR SCIENCE, VOL. 53, NO. 1, FEBRUARY 2006 Land Mine Detection With Neutron Back Scattering Imaging Using a Neutron Generator http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=01611003 </ref>
=== Acoustic detection === It is possible to detect land mines by directing [[sound waves]] at the area to be demined, which causes the land mines to vibrate, and then using a laser to search for vibrations on the surface by means of the Doppler shift - this technique is termed [[scanning laser doppler vibrometry]]. Such devices have been constructed, e.g., at the [[University of Mississippi]],<ref name="SLDV Miss">{{cite news|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/iel5/8859/28004/101109LGRS2004836257.pdf|format=PDF|title=Laser Doppler Vibrometer-Based Acoustic Landmine Detection Using the Fast M-Sequence Transform, N Xiang and J M Sabatier, IEEE Geosci. and Remote Sens. Letts. Vol. 1 (4) 2004 }}</ref> at [[MIT]]<ref name="vibrating">{{cite news|url=http://www.newscientisttech.com/article/dn10868-vibrations-could-reveal-landmine-locations.html|title=Vibrations could reveal landmine locations|publisher=[[New Scientist]]|accessdate=December 29, 2006|date=December 22, 2006}}</ref> and by the Kayser-Threde Company.<ref name="KT">{{cite news|url=http://spiedl.aip.org/browse/vol_range.jsp |title=M Heybel, K-H Bers and V H Klein, Proc. SPIE, Volume 5415, pp. 80-90 (2004) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624100327/http://spiedl.aip.org/browse/vol_range.jsp |archivedate=2007-06-24 |df= }}</ref>
=== Drones === Since January 2016 British scientists are developing [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]] with advanced imaging technology to more cheaply and effectively map and speed up the clearing of minefields. The [[Find A Better Way]] charity, working since 2011 to advance technologies that will enable safer and more efficient clearance of landmines, teamed up with scientists at the [[University of Bristol]] to develop drones fitted with [[hyperspectral imaging]] technology that can quickly identify landmines buried in the ground. John Fardoulis, project researcher from Bristol University states that "the maps [their] drones will generate should help deminers focus on the places where mines are most likely to be found". Their intended drones will be able to perform flyovers and gather images at various wavelengths which, according to Dr John Day from the University of Bristol, could indicate explosive chemicals seeping from landmines into the surrounding foliage as "chemicals in landmines leak out and are often absorbed by plants, causing abnormalities" which can be detected as "living plants have a very distinctive reflection in the near infrared spectrum, just beyond human vision, which makes it possible to tell how healthy they are".<ref name="newatlas">{{cite web|last1=Lavars|first1=Nick|title=Imaging drones to spot signs of explosive chemicals leaking from landmines|url=http://newatlas.com/drones-landmines-bristol/42732/|publisher=New Atlas|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref>
In the 2015 $1 million [[Drones for Good]] competition, Spanish company [[CATUAV]] was selected as a finalist for a drone fitted with optical sensors to scan war-affected regions of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] for landmines buried during the 1990s.<ref name="newatlas"/><!--aerial photographs from the drone are run through a post-processing programme that provides a mosaic map of the area and determines the probability of landmines.--><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wasmi|first1=Naser Al|title=UAE entrants offer positive alternatives uses for drones in competition|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/technology/uae-entrants-offer-positive-alternatives-uses-for-drones-in-competition|publisher=The National|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Derek|title=Drones for Good awards to give $1 million to UAVs that do things other than killing and spying|url=http://www.t3.com/news/drones-for-good-awards|publisher=T3|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kennedy|first1=David|title=How these drones for disaster relief and eliminating landmines are aiming to rebrand the controversial technology|url=http://business.financialpost.com/fp-tech-desk/how-these-drones-for-disaster-relief-and-eliminating-landmines-are-aiming-to-rebrand-the-controversial-technology?__lsa=0180-ebbe|publisher=Financial Post|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref>
The Dutch Mine Kafon project, led by designer <!--Afghanistan-born-->Massoud Hassani is working on a drone system that can quickly detect and clear land mines. The unmanned airborne de-mining system called [[Mine Kafon Drone]] uses a three step process to autonomously map, detect and detonate land mines. It flies above potentially dangerous areas, generating a 3D map, and uses a metal detector to pinpoint the location of mines. The drone can then place a detonator above the mines using its robotic gripping arm, before retreating to a safe distance. The firm claims its drone is safer, 20 times faster and up to 200 times cheaper than current technologies and might clear mines globally in 10 years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vincent|first1=James|title=This drone can detect and detonate land mines|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/19/12222104/landmine-detecting-drone-mine-kafon-drone|publisher=The Verge|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Liberatore|first1=Stacy|title=Land mine-hunting drone aims to rid the world of EVERY ground explosive in under 10 years|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3734014/Land-hunting-drone-aims-rid-world-ground-explosive-10-years-Firm-claims-20-times-faster-traditional-techniques.html|publisher=Dailymail|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Myers|first1=Joe|title=This drone could help remove all landmines around the world in 10 years|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2016/08/this-is-a-landmine-hunting-drone|publisher=World Economic Forum|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> The project raised funds on the [[crowdfunding]] site [[Kickstarter]] with their goal set at €70,000 and receiving over €100,000 above it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mine Kafon Drone on Kickstarter|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/massoudhassani/mine-kafon-drone|accessdate=20 December 2016}}</ref> <!--https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261471990_Air_Drones_for_Explosive_Landmines_Detection-->
== See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} * [[Aftermath: The Remnants of War (film)|''Aftermath: The Remnants of War'' (film)]] * [[APOPO]] * [[Bomb disposal]] * [[Corfu Channel Incident]] * [[Digger DTR]] * [[Geneva International Centre for Humanitarian Demining]] {{Col-break}} * [[HALO Trust]] * [[HeroRAT]] * [[Land mines in Central America]] * [[Mine action]] * [[Mine Action Information Center]] * [[Mines Advisory Group]] * [[Mine clearance agencies]] {{Col-break}} * [[Minesweeper (ship)]] * [[MineWolf Systems]] * [[Naval Mine]] * [[Ottawa Treaty]] * [[Pookie (vehicle)]] * [[Rule of Law in Armed Conflicts Project (RULAC)]] * [[Unexploded ordnance]] {{Col-end}}

Miles, Arthur Dogariu, and James B. Michael, ''IEEE Spectrum,'' February 2012 * [http://www.maginternational.org Mines Advisory Group] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080802214756/http://www.apopo.org/newsite/content/index.htm Demining with Africa`s Sniffer Rats (APOPO)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011093652/http://ec.europa.eu/external_relations/mine/intro/index.htm European Commission action programme against antipersonnel landmines] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060908000922/http://www.eudem.vub.ac.be/ EUDEM] The European Union in humanitarian DEMining - technical research and development database * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090310031206/http://www.itep.ws/ International Test and Evaluation Program for Humanitarian Demining] * [http://www.mech.uwa.edu.au/jpt/demining/ Humanitarian Demining Research] at the [[University of Western Australia]] * [http://www.DanishDeminingGroup.dk Danish Demining Group] * [http://www.snailaid.org/Locostra LOCOSTRA] Modified Agricultural Technologies for Technical Survey that can be used for fostering agricultural development when demining is over
{{Col-end}}

revision.text:
{{infobox historic site | name =Encino Oak Tree | image = Encino Oak Tree.jpg | caption = Encino Oak Tree stump | location= Louise Avenue, 210 feet south of Ventura Boulevard, [[Encino, Los Angeles, California]] | coordinates= {{Coord|34.160249|-118.509873|type:landmark_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Los Angeles | area = | built = | architect = | architecture = | designation1 = Los Angeles | designation1_date = September 6, 1963<ref name = "LAHCM_list">{{Cite book | last = Los Angeles Department of City Planning | date = September 7, 2007 | title = Historic — Cultural Monuments (HCM) Listing: City Declared Monuments | place = | publisher = City of Los Angeles | edition = | url =http://www.cityprojectca.org/ourwork/documents/HCMDatabase090707.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-29 }}</ref> | designation1_number = 24 | governing_body = City of Los Angeles }}
The '''Encino Oak Tree''', also known as the '''Lang Oak''', was a 1,000-year-old California live oak tree, ''[[Quercus agrifolia]]'', in the [[Encino, Los Angeles, California|Encino]] section of [[Los Angeles, California]]. It was designated as a [[Los Angeles Historic-Cultural Monument]] (HCM #24) in 1963.
==History of the oak== The ''Los Angeles Times'' once wrote of the Encino oak: "When the famed Lang oak tree of Encino was but a sapling, the Mayan Empire was crumbling and Vikings were sacking English sea towns."<ref name=Times>{{cite news|author=Steve Padilla|title=Ancient Oak May Be Out on a Limb Nature: The 1,000-year-old Encino landmark is threatened by disease and drought. Experts differ over what to do|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1991-04-15}}</ref> It was already 100 years old when [[Pope Urban II]] launched the first Crusade. And when the first Europeans passed through Encino in 1769 as part of the Portola Expedition, the tree was already more than 700 years old.<ref name=Guide>{{cite book|author=Judson Grenier (Editor-in-chief)|title=A Guide to Historic Places in Los Angeles County, p. 96|publisher=Kendall/Hunt Publishing Co.|year=1978|isbn=0-8403-7501-8}}</ref>
==Encino landmark== As Encino was developed into a residential community in the mid-20th century, the Encino oak became recognized as a landmark, known for its size and longevity. It was recognized as "the oldest known tree in the city of Los Angeles."<ref name=Rense>{{cite news|author=Rip Rense|title=L.A. Stories; An Elder Statesman Rooted in History|publisher=Angeles Times|date=1996-03-20}}</ref> A California live oak tree is considered to be old at 300 years, and arborists considered the Encino tree's longevity to be extraordinary. One arborist noted, "It's just like standing next to a dinosaur."<ref name=Times/>
The majestic California live oaks were such an impressive presence in the pre-urban Encino that the community was named after the Spanish word for "oak." The Encino oak was the most magnificent of the community's oaks, so large that Louise Avenue was split to accommodate its enormous {{convert|150|ft|adj=on}} canopy, {{convert|8|ft|adj=on}} diameter, and {{convert|24|ft|adj=on}} circumference.<ref name=Guide/><ref name=Times/> It has been said that the Encino oak "creates a woodsy atmosphere more resembling a whole forest than just a single tree."<ref name=Times/>
In 1958, the oak was threatened when a developer planned to bulldoze the tree to build a road. Local residents formed a group called Encino Save the Oaks and the developer eventually donated the tree to the city. It was declared a Historic-Cultural Monument in 1963. In the years following its designation as a monument, the tree was a tourist attraction.<ref>{{cite news|author=Gloria Lopez|title=A Crook in the Road|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1985-10-20}}</ref>
==Threatened by slime flux and other ailments== By the 1990s, the tree was in a weakened condition. Some attributed its condition to the Encino Reservoir, built in 1921, for cutting off the natural water flow to the tree. Others blamed it on air pollution from traffic on nearby Ventura Boulevard. It also suffered from oak-root fungus.<ref name=Rense/> In 1991, it was diagnosed with [[slime flux]], a tree ailment caused by bacteria that generate fermentation inside the tree and send toxic sap oozing through the bark.<ref name=Times/> Arborists reported that the tree desperately needed special care to save it. Arborists and city officials argued over the proper treatment for the ailing tree, with one arborist suggesting the city chisel small holes in the bark to release the toxic sap that was slowly killing the oak. Others suggested the drilling would put too much stress on the tree, which should be allowed to heal itself.<ref name=Times/>
Efforts to save the ailing oak became a publicized cause. In 1996, the ''Times'' reported on the oak: "His skin is mottled, some of his limbs are held together with pins, and his great, shaggy head hangs from its own weight. Old Lang is in trouble."<ref name=Rense/> In 1997, the Encino oak was honored at an Arbor Day ceremony attended by Wirt Morton, the great-great-grandson of National Arbor Day founder J. Sterling Morton, who on seeing the giant oak said: "I've never seen anything as phenomenal as that."<ref>{{cite news|author=Sylvia L. Oliande|title=Encino; Lang Oak Honored on State Arbor Day|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1997-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Stacy Brown|title=Grand-old Tree: Lang Oak Praised on Arbor Day|publisher=Daily News (Los Angeles, CA)|date=1997-03-08|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83858687.html}}</ref>
==Death in El Niño rains== On February 7, 1998, an [[El Niño]] storm "delivered the death blow, felling the ailing tree with storm winds."<ref name=Ribbon>{{cite news|author=Agnes Digggs|title=Valley Roundup; Encino; Piece of Lang Oak Tree to Be Unveiled at Park|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1999-04-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=A Tree Dies, but Not Its Legacy|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Peter Hartlaub|title=Arboreal Landmark Succumbs to Rain: 1,000-Year-Old Oak Collapses in Encino|publisher=Daily News (Los Angeles, CA)|date=1998-02-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Editorial: Goodbye to a Landmark|publisher=Daily News (Los Angeles, CA)|date=1998-02-10}}</ref> As news of the tree’s demise spread, onlookers gathered, some crying and taking branches as mementos.<ref name=Storm>{{cite news|author=Evelyn Larrubia|title=Storm's Oldest Casualty; History: Residents come to mourn as workers cut up 1,000-year-old Lang Oak, toppled in Saturday's rains. Encino landmark was declared a state monument in 1963|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-02-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Evelyn Larrubia|title=If a Tree Falls in the Valley, We All Hear It|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-02-09}}</ref> After decades of being threatened by development and pollution, one resident noted the irony that "now it goes because of nature."<ref name=Storm/> As souvenir-hunters sought to take pieces of the tree, police officers guarded it until its remains could be removed. One officer noted: "It got out of control. It's sad that we had to take two policemen off the street to watch a tree."<ref>{{cite news|author=Eric Slater|title=After the Fall; Police Say Souvenir Seekers Are Barking Up Wrong Tree|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-02-10}}</ref>
In the weeks following the tree's death, city officials debated what should be done with the tree's remains, leading the ''Times'' to ask: "How many bureaucrats, City Council aides, homeowners, urban planners and arborists does it take to decree the fate of a fallen king, the mighty oak of Ventura Boulevard?"<ref>{{cite news|author=Eric Slater|title=Officials Trim Options to Recycle Fallen Oak; Landmark: Meetings continue on what to do with 1,000-year-old Encino tree's trunk. Carving it into a celebrity likeness gets the kibosh|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-04-15}}</ref> Ultimately, the city opted to plant five new trees where the Encino oak had grown—three California sycamores and two coast live oaks. The city also unveiled an {{convert|8|x|6|ft|adj=on}} oval slice of the tree in an April 1999 ribbon-cutting ceremony.<ref name=Ribbon/><ref>{{cite news|author=Eric Slater|title=Tribute to Fallen Oak Will Be a Chip Off the Old Block|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=1998-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jesse Hiestand|title=Encino Planting Future Symbols: Community Picks 5-Tree Tribute for Histori Lang Oak|publisher=Daily News (Los Angeles, CA)|date=1998-04-18|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83819081.html}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Los Angeles Historic-Cultural Monuments in the San Fernando Valley]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.wildbell.com/oak/index.htm ''A Tall Tree's Tale'', by Will Campbell]
{{Encino, Los Angeles}} {{LAHMC}}

|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2012/06/nasa-teams-evaluating-iss-built-exploration-platform-roadmap/ |title=NASA teams evaluating ISS-built Exploration Platform roadmap |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |last=Bergin |first=Chris |date=14 June 2012 |accessdate=21 July 2012}} | orbit_reference = [[Lunar orbit|Selenocentric]] | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = 6 days | orbit_epoch = | apsis = selene |interplanetary = {{Infobox spaceflight/IP |type = orbiter |object = [[Moon]] |arrival_date = Planned: 2020 |apsis = selene }} | programme = Orion program | previous_mission = [[Exploration Flight Test 1|EFT-1]] | next_mission = [[Exploration Mission 2|EM-2]] | insignia = Exploration Mission-1 patch.png }} '''Exploration Mission-1''' or '''EM-1''' (previously known as '''Space Launch System 1''' or '''SLS-1''') is the uncrewed first planned flight of the [[Space Launch System]] and the second flight of the [[Orion (spacecraft)|Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle]]. The launch is planned for June 2020 from [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39|Launch Complex 39B]] at the [[Kennedy Space Center]]. The Orion spacecraft will spend approximately 3 weeks in space, including 6 days in a [[retrograde orbit]] around the [[Moon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/the-ins-and-outs-of-nasa-s-first-launch-of-sls-and-orion |title=The Ins and Outs of NASA's First Launch of SLS and Orion |publisher=[[NASA]] |editor-first=Daniel |editor-last=Huot |date=27 November 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2016}} It is planned to be followed by [[Exploration Mission 2]] in 2023. ==Mission overview== [[File:Orion Exploration Mission-1 Animation.webm|thumb|left|Animation of EM-1]] [[File:Orion Service Module (cropped).jpg|thumb|Orion spacecraft with the [[Delta Cryogenic Second Stage|ICPS]] in orbit]] [[File:EM1-Mission-Map_Update.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.25|EM-1 will send an uncrewed Orion capsule 1.3 million miles over 25.5 days. It will deploy 13 CubeSats and re-enter at 24,000mph (mach 32).]] The Block 1 version of SLS used on this mission will consist of two [[Space Shuttle Solid Rocket Booster#Five-segment booster|five-segment Solid Rocket Boosters]], four [[Space Shuttle Main Engine|RS-25D]] engines built for the Space Shuttle program and an [[Delta Cryogenic Second Stage|Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage]]. EM-1 is intended to demonstrate the integrated spacecraft systems prior to a crewed flight, and in addition, test a high speed reentry (11 km/s) on Orion's thermal protection system. On 16 January 2013, NASA announced that the [[European Space Agency]] will build the [[Orion Service Module]] based on its [[Automated Transfer Vehicle]], so the flight could also be regarded as a test of ESA hardware as well as American, and of how the ESA components interact with the American Orion components.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/exploration/systems/mpcv/orion_feature_011613.html |title=Engineers resolve Orion will 'lose weight' in 2015 |publisher=NASA |date=16 January 2013 |accessdate=22 March 2013}} The [[Exploration Flight Test 1]] (EFT-1) flight article was consciously constructed in a way that if all the missing components (seats, life support systems) were added, it would not meet the mass target. It was planned that subsequent capsules would be modified to be lighter, based on manufacturing experience. In January 2015 NASA and Lockheed announced that some components in the EM-1 capsule would be up to 25 percent lighter compared to the previous one. This would be achieved by changes to the primary structure - the EM-1 article would be welded together from 3 panels for the cone, as opposed to 6 panels used for the [[Exploration Flight Test 1|EFT-1]] article. The total number of welds was reduced from 19 to 7,{{cite news |url=http://www.waaytv.com/space_alabama/orion-program-manager-talks-eft--in-huntsville/article_17894640-9b43-11e4-b731-1feb498f3882.html |title=Orion program manager talks EFT-1 in Huntsville |work=Space Alabama |publisher=WAAY |first=Josh |last=Barrett |date=13 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/YKKUw |archivedate=18 January 2015}} thus saving the additional mass of the weld material. Other savings would be due to revisiting its various components and wiring. For EM-1 the capsule will be outfitted with complete life support system and crew seats, but will be left uncrewed.{{cite news |url=http://www.waff.com/story/27841631/engineers-resolve-orion-will-lose-weight-in-2015 |title=Engineers resolve Orion will 'lose weight' in 2015 |publisher=WAFF |date=13 January 2015 |accessdate=15 January 2015}} However, in February 2017 NASA announced that [[Robert M. Lightfoot Jr.]], the agency's Acting Administrator, had asked the Human Exploration and Operations Mission Directorate to study the feasibility of redesigning the mission to include a crew.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-to-study-adding-crew-to-first-flight-of-sls-and-orion |title=NASA to Study Adding Crew to First Flight of SLS and Orion |publisher=NASA |editor-first=Brian |editor-last=Dunbar |date=15 February 2017 |accessdate=15 February 2017}} ===Crewed version=== The mission will be uncrewed, however NASA did initiate a study to investigate a crewed version of the mission. A crewed version of EM-1 would be composed of a crew of two astronauts, and will be much shorter than the uncrewed version due to safety reasons. The study investigated a crewed mission even with the possibility of further delays to the launch.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-kicks-off-study-to-add-crew-to-first-flight-of-orion-sls-as-progress-continues-to-send |title=NASA Kicks Off Study to Add Crew to First Flight of Orion, SLS |publisher=NASA |last=Warner |first=Cheryl |accessdate=27 February 2017 |date=24 February 2017}} On 12 May 2017 NASA revealed that it will not be sending astronauts to space for Orion's EM-1 mission following a months-long feasibility study.{{cite news |url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2017/05/nasa-em-1-uncrewed-costs-main-reason/ |title=NASA will not put a crew on EM-1, cites cost – not safety – as main reason |work=[[NASASpaceFlight.com]] |first=Chris |last=Gebhardt |date=12 May 2017}} ==History== Originally EM-1 was planned to follow a [[circumlunar trajectory]] without entering orbit around the Moon.{{cite web |url=http://spirit.as.utexas.edu/~fiso/telecon/Singer_4-25-12/Singer_4-25-12.pdf |title=Status of NASA's Space Launch System |publisher=NASA Marshall Space Flight Center |last=Singer |first=Jody |date=25 April 2012 |accessdate=5 August 2012}} ==Chronology== {{EM1 chronology}} ==Orion payloads== [[NASA]] has partnered with the [[German Aerospace Center]] (DLR) and the [[Israel Space Agency]] (ISA) in conjunction with [[StemRad]] and [[Lockheed Martin]] to perform the Matroshka AstroRad Radiation Experiment (MARE), which will measure tissue dose deposition and test the effectiveness of the AstroRad radiation vest in a radiation environment beyond [[low Earth orbit]]. While radiation shielding strategies of the past have relied on storm shelters in which astronauts can seek refuge as solar storms erupt, the AstroRad's ergonomic design provides a mobile protection system with the same shielding factor as storm shelters without hindering the astronauts’ ability to perform mission sensitive tasks.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-israeli-space-agencies-join-forces-to-protect-astronauts-from-radiation-1523969713 |title=U.S., Israeli Space Agencies Join Forces to Protect Astronauts From Radiation |last=Pasztor |first=Andy |date=17 April 2018 |work=Wall Street Journal |access-date=21 June 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0099-9660}} The crew compartment of the unmanned EM-1 [[Orion (spacecraft)|Orion spacecraft]] will include two female anthropomorphic [[imaging phantom|phantoms]] which will be exposed to the intense radiation environment along the lunar orbit, including solar storms and galactic [[cosmic ray]]s. One phantom will be shielded with the AstroRad and the other will be left unprotected. The phantoms provide the opportunity to precisely measure radiation exposure not only at the surface of the body, but also at the exact location of sensitive organs and tissues inside the human body. Radiation exposure will be measured with implementation of both passive and active [[dosimeter]]s intentionally distributed throughout the inside of the anthropomorphic phantoms at precise locations of sensitive tissues and high stem cell concentrations.{{cite conference |url=https://ispcs.com/wp-content/uploads/Thomas-Berger-ISPCS-2017-FINAL-1.compressed.pdf |title=Exploration Missions and Radiation |conference=International Symposium for Personal and Commercial Spaceflight. 11-12 October 2017. Las Cruces, New Mexico. |first=Thomas |last=Berger |year=2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l25-4XhcneY&t=634s |title=ISPCS 2017 - Thomas Berger 'Exploration Missions and Radiation' |work=YouTube.com |publisher=International Symposium for Personal and Commercial Spaceflight |first=Thomas |last=Berger |year=2017}} The results of MARE should enable Orion as a platform for other scientific experiments, provide accurate radiation risk projections of deep space exploration, and validate the protective properties of the AstroRad. ==Secondary payloads== [[File:SLS MPCV Stage Adapter for 11 CubeSats.png|thumb|MPCV Stage Adapter for 13 [[CubeSat]] spring-loaded dispensers]] Thirteen low-cost [[CubeSat]] missions were competitively selected as secondary payloads on the EM-1 test flight.{{cite news |url=http://www.govconwire.com/2016/02/boeing-built-rocket-to-carry-lockheed-martins-skyfire-cubesat/ |title=Boeing-Built Rocket to Carry Lockheed Martin's Skyfire CubeSat |work=GovConWire |last=Healy |first=Angel |date=4 February 2016 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} They will reside within the second stage on the launch vehicle from which they will be deployed. Two CubeSats have been selected through NASA's Next Space Technologies for Exploration Partnership, three through the Human Exploration and Operations Mission Directorate, two through the Science Mission Directorate, and three were chosen from submissions by NASA's international partners. The CubeSat spacecraft selected are:{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-space-launch-system-s-first-flight-to-send-small-sci-tech-satellites-into-space |title=NASA Space Launch System's First Flight to Send Small Sci-Tech Satellites into Space |publisher=NASA |first1=Kathryn |last1=Hambleton |first2=Kim |last2=Newton |first3=Shannon |last3=Ridinger |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=3 February 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3025131/An-asteroid-hunter-lunar-flashlight-DNA-kit-Nasa-reveals-experiments-mega-rocket-carry-test-flight.html |title=An asteroid hunter, lunar flashlight and DNA kit: Nasa reveals experiments its mega rocket will carry on its first test flight |work=Daily Mail |location=London |last=Zolfagharifard |first=Ellie |date=3 April 2015 |accessdate=24 May 2015}} *[[Lunar Flashlight]] is a spacecraft that will seek exposed water ice, and map its concentration at the 1-2 kilometer scale within the permanently shadowed regions of the [[lunar south pole]].{{cite web |url=http://sservi.nasa.gov/articles/lunar-flashlight/ |title=Lunar Flashlight |work=Solar System Exploration Research Virtual Institute |publisher=NASA |date=2015 |accessdate=23 May 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/27388-nasa-moon-mining-missions-water.html |title=NASA Is Studying How to Mine the Moon for Water |work=Space.com |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=9 October 2014 |accessdate=23 May 2015}} *[[Near-Earth Asteroid Scout]] is proof-of-concept of a controllable CubeSat [[solar sail]] spacecraft capable of encountering [[near-Earth asteroid]]s (NEA).{{cite conference |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20140012882.pdf |title=Near-Earth Asteroid Scout |conference=AIAA Space 2014 Conference. 4-7 August 2014. San Diego, California. |publisher=American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics |first1=Leslie |last1=McNutt |first2=Les |last2=Johnson |first3=Dennon |last3=Clardy |first4=Julie |last4=Castillo-Rogez |first5=Andreas |last5=Frick |first6=Laura |last6=Jones |display-authors=1 |date=2014 |id=M14-3850}} Observations will be achieved through a close (≈10 km) flyby and using a high resolution science-grade monochromatic camera to measure the physical properties of a near-Earth asteroid. A variety of potential targets would be identified based upon launch date, time of flight, and rendezvous velocity. *[[BioSentinel]] is an [[astrobiology]] mission that will use [[yeast]] to detect, measure, and compare the impact of deep space radiation on living organisms over long durations beyond [[low-Earth orbit]]. *[[SkyFire (spacecraft)|SkyFire]] is a spacecraft designed by [[Lockheed Martin]] to fly by the Moon and collect surface [[Astronomical spectroscopy|spectroscopy]] and [[Infrared spectroscopy|thermography]]. *[[Lunar IceCube]], designed at the [[Morehead State University]], will search for additional evidence of [[Lunar water|lunar water ice]] from a low lunar orbit. *[[CubeSat for Solar Particles]] (CuSP), designed at the [[Southwest Research Institute]] will study the dynamic [[Solar energetic particles|particles]] and [[Sun#Magnetic field|magnetic fields]] that stream from the Sun{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2016/heliophysics-cubesat-to-launch-on-nasa-s-sls |title=Heliophysics CubeSat to Launch on NASAs SLS |publisher=NASA |first=Sarah |last=Frazier |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} and as a proof of concept for the feasibility of a network of stations to track [[space weather]]. *[[Lunar Polar Hydrogen Mapper]] (LunaH-Map), designed at the [[Arizona State University]],[http://lunahmap.asu.edu/ LunaH-Map] - Homepage at the Arizona State University. will map hydrogen within craters near the lunar south pole, tracking depth and distribution of hydrogen-rich compounds like water. It will use a neutron detector to measure the energies of neutrons that interacted with material in the lunar surface. Its mission is planned to last 60 days and perform 141 orbits of the Moon.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/lunah-map-university-built-cubesat-to-map-water-ice-on-the-moon |title=LunaH-Map: University-Built CubeSat to Map Water-Ice on the Moon |publisher=NASA |editor-first=Jennifer |editor-last=Harbaugh |date=2 February 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} *[[EQUULEUS (spacecraft)|EQUULEUS]], designed by [[JAXA]] and the [[University of Tokyo]], will image Earth's [[plasmasphere]] to study the radiation environment around the Earth while demonstrating low thrust maneuvers for trajectory control in the space between Earth and the Moon.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/exploration/systems/sls/international-partners-provide-cubesats-for-sls-maiden-flight |title=International Partners Provide CubeSats for SLS Maiden Flight |publisher=NASA |first1=Kathryn |last1=Hambleton |first2=Kim |last2=Henry |first3=Tracy |last3=McMahan |date=26 May 2016 |accessdate=15 February 2017}} *[[OMOTENASHI]], designed by JAXA, is a lander/impact probe to study the lunar radiation environment.{{cite conference |url=https://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3615&context=smallsat |title=Trajectory Design for the JAXA Moon Nano-Lander OMOTENASHI |conference=31st Annual AIAA/USU Conference on Small Satellites. 5–10 August 2017. Logan, Utah. |first1=Javier |last1=Hernando-Ayuso |first2=Yusuke |last2=Ozawa |first3=Shota |last3=Takahashi |first4=Stefano |last4=Campagnola |first5=Toshinori |last5=Ikenaga |first6=Tomohiro |last6=Yamaguchi |first7=Tatsuaki |last7=Hashimoto |first8=Chit Hong |last8=Yam |first9=Bruno V. |last9=Sarli |display-authors=1 |date=2017 |id=SSC17-III-07}} *[[ArgoMoon]], designed by [[Argotec]] and coordinated by [[Italian Space Agency|ASI]], is designed to image the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage (ICPS) of Orion for mission data and historical records. It will demonstrate technologies necessary for a small spacecraft to maneuver and operate near the ICPS. The remaining three slots were selected through a competition pitting CubeSat teams from the United States against each other in a series of ground tournaments called 'NASA's Cube Quest Challenge',{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/04/08/nasa-adding-to-list-of-cubesats-flying-on-first-sls-mission/ |title=NASA adding to list of CubeSats flying on first SLS mission |work=Spaceflight Now |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=8 April 2015 |accessdate=25 May 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2014/november/nasa-opens-cube-quest-challenge-for-largest-ever-prize-of-5-million-0/ |title=NASA Opens Cube Quest Challenge for Largest-Ever Prize of $5 Million |publisher=NASA |last=Steitz |first=David E. |date=24 November 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2015}} and were announced by NASA Ames on 8 June 2017. The competition was to contribute to opening deep-space exploration to non-government spacecraft. These slots were awarded to:{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/three-diy-cubesats-score-rides-on-nasa-s-first-flight-of-orion-space-launch-system |title=Three DIY CubeSats Score Rides on NASA's First Flight of Orion, Space Launch System |publisher=NASA |first1=Gina |last1=Anderson |first2=Molly |last2=Porter |date=8 June 2017}} *[[Cislunar Explorers]] will demonstrate the viability of [[water electrolysis]] propulsion and interplanetary optical navigation to orbit the Moon. It was designed by Cornell University, Ithaca, New York. *[[Earth Escape Explorer]] (CU-E3) will demonstrate long-distance communications while in [[heliocentric orbit]]. It was designed by the University of Colorado in Boulder. *[[Team Miles]] will demonstrate long-distance communications while in [[heliocentric orbit]] and show low-thrust trajectory control techniques by employing a hybrid [[ion thruster]]. It was designed by Fluid and Reason, LLC, Tampa, Florida. ==Gallery==

The '''Fur Rendezvous Festival''' (usually called '''Fur Rendezvous''', '''Fur Rondy''', or simply '''Rondy''') is an annual [[Winter Carnival|winter festival]] held in [[Anchorage, Alaska]] in late February. The self-styled "largest winter festival in North America", Fur Rendezvous is highly anticipated by many Anchorage-area residents as marking the beginning of the end of a long winter and the approach of spring. In 2012, Fur Rendezvous was selected as the number one winter carnival in the world by the National Geographic Traveler. <ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20120421232245/http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/winter-trips/winter-carnivals/ Winter Carnivals]", National Geographic Traveler, January/February 2012.</ref>
== History and Origins == The name "Fur Rendezvous" derives from [[Flea market|swap meet]]s at which [[Trapping (Animal)|fur trappers]] would gather to sell their winter harvests. In early Anchorage, these usually took place in mid-February.
In 1935, Anchorage had a population of only about 3,000 and was very isolated, so to bring the community together and lift [[Seasonal affective disorder|spirits]], resident Vern Johnson organized a three-day sports tournament, called the ''Winter Sports Carnival'', timed to coincide with the rendezvous, which brought increased activity. As the [[fur trade]] was then the second-largest industry in Alaska, folding it into the event seemed natural, and it was renamed the ''Winter Sports Tournament and Fur Rendezvous'' from 1937, and later just Fur Rendezvous.
It was common for miners and trappers to have beards in the early days, so a "law" was even made that all men had to grow beards for this event or suffer a fine! This was considered to be part of the fun, because most men participated in it.
Fur Rendezvous was canceled during the [[World War II|war]] years, but resumed in 1946, when the festival began to draw visitors from [[Outside (Alaska)|Outside]], and has been held every year since. Since 1955 the event has been run by the non-profit '''Greater Anchorage, Inc.'''
Traditionally Fur Rendezvous lasted ten days, but since 2004 it has extended through early March, in order to lead into the [[Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race]] and draw more visitors.
== Events == The original Winter Sports Carnival included [[skiing]], [[hockey]], [[basketball]], [[boxing]], and a [[Dogsled racing|sled dog race]] for children, as well as a [[bonfire]] and torchlight [[parade]]. Modern Rondy has well over 100 events; some of the more significant include: * Rondy Grand Prix - The Oldest Street Race in the U.S. * Official Fur Rondy Fur [[Auction]] - the descendant of the original fur trade rendezvous, present since the earliest days. * Miners' and Trappers' Charity Ball and [[Mr. Fur Face]] beard contest (since 1950) - Beards are grown as long as possible and they are dyed, decorated and shaped for this contest. * [[World Championship Sled Dog Race]] (since 1946, with a women's race since 1953) - This three-day, 75-mile [[sled dog race]] brings [[musher]]s from across Alaska and the world. However, it is sometimes canceled in recent years due to warm weather, with the most recent cancellation being in 2006. * World Championship Dog Weight Pull (since 1967) - [[sled dogs]] attempt to pull the greatest weight * Miss Fur Rendezvous [[beauty pageant|pageant]] (from at least late 1950s [https://books.google.com/books?um=1&q=%22miss+fur+rendezvous%22&btnG=Search+Books] through mid 1970s [http://consortiumlibrary.org/archives/CollectionsInv/GtoJ/GAIFURR.wpd.html]), also called Miss Fur Rondy * [[Snow sculpture|Snow Sculpture]] Competition * Fur Rondy [[Carnival]] * Frostbite Footrace - [[Costume]]d competitors run through downtown Anchorage * Rondy Grand Parade * Running of the Reindeer - a whimsical annual event, started in 2008, that sends "herds" of people running down a four-block downtown street, with a group of reindeer released behind them, charging through the runners in a spoof of Pamplona's [[Running of the Bulls]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20170130062230/http://www.furrondy.net/events/running-reindeer Running of the Reindeer listing], official Fur Rondy website. Accessed 2017.</ref> * Rondy on Ice - [[figure skating]] show * World [[ice bowling|Ice Bowling]] Championships
Many events tend toward the whimsical, such as the [[Outhouse]] Races (in which teams build outhouses and pull them on skis with a rider inside), [[ice bowling]], or even [[snowshoe]] [[softball]] matches. Others focus on [[Alaska Native]] culture, such as the Multi-Tribal Gathering and Native Arts and Crafts Show.
==Pins== Since 1939, promotional [[pin]]s have been created and sold each year to raise money for the event. These pins have become popular collectibles, and older or rare pins can sell well in excess of $100. The Anchorage University [[Kiwanis Club]] sells pins and booster buttons dressed as Keystone Cops for the duration of the festival. During the parade the Keystone Cops, or "Rondy Kops," playfully detain attendees in a mobile jail until pins or buttons are purchased in exchange for their release.
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category|Fur Rendezvous}} * {{Official website|http://www.furrondy.net}} * [http://www.furrondy.net/aboutus-history.html History of Fur Rondy] * [http://alaskastuff.com/Pages/Cache/Pins_and_Buttons/Fur_Rendezvous_Collection/Fur_Rendezvous_Pins.htm Pictures of Rondy pin designs from the 1960s through the 1990s] * [http://www.anchorageuniversitykiwanis.org Anchorage University Kiwanis Club] * [http://www.tips-for-backwoods-alaska-vacations.com/fur-rendezvous.html Pictures of Fur Rendezvous Events]
