{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox tunnel | name = Gerrards Cross Tunnel | image = Gerrards Cross Railway Station - geograph.org.uk - 1475557.jpg | alt = railway station and tunnel | caption = [[Gerrards Cross]] [[Gerrards Cross railway station|station]] and tunnel in 2009 | official_name = | other_name = | line = [[Chiltern Main Line]] | location = [[Gerrards Cross]], [[Buckinghamshire]], England | coordinates = {{coord|51.588343|-0.553007|display=inline,title|region:GB_scale:10000}} | os_grid_ref = | status = | system = | crosses = | start = | end = | stations = | startwork = 2003 | opened = 2010 | closed = <!-- or |closes for future dates --> | rebuilt = | reopened = <!-- or |reopens for future dates --> | owner = | operator = | traffic = | character = | engineer = | construction = | length = | linelength = | tracklength = | notrack = 2 | gauge = {{track gauge|uksg}} | el = | speed = | hielevation = | lowelevation = | height = | width = | depth_below_water = | shipping_clearance_above = | grade = | map = | extra = }} '''Gerrards Cross Tunnel''' is a [[railway tunnel]] in [[Gerrards Cross]], [[Buckinghamshire]], on the [[Chiltern Main Line]]. The purpose of the tunnel was to enable a new [[Tesco]] supermarket to be built over the railway line. Plans were initially met with anger by local residents, and the council refused planning permission but this decision was overturned by [[John Prescott]].
During construction of the tunnel, it [[Structural failure|partially collapsed]] on 30 June 2005. No-one was injured in the accident, although a train heading towards the tunnel when it collapsed had to perform an emergency stop. Early reports suspected the cause was the backfilling operation; the [[Health and Safety Executive]] are yet{{when|date=May 2018}} to release their findings owing to legal issues.<ref name="FOI 2017">{{cite web | url=https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/375739/response/938345/attach/html/3/201702198%20Ben%20Kinglsey%20Whatdotheyknow.com%20Freedom%20of%20information%20response.DOCX.docx.html | title=Freedom of Information request Ref 201702198 | publisher=whatdotheyknow.com | date=15 February 2017 | accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>
Despite the incident, the construction continued in 2007 with different contractors building the tunnel. The store opened in November 2010, fourteen years after the project was commissioned.
==Background== Tesco, the third largest retailer in the world measured by revenues and the second largest measured by profits<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deloitte.com/assets/Dcom-Australia/Local%20Assets/Documents/news-research/Press%20releases/Global%20Powers%20of%20Retailing/Global_Powers_of_Retailing_2010_report.pdf |title=Global Powers of Retailing 2010 |publisher=Deloitte |page=14 |accessdate=18 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614041846/http://www.deloitte.com/assets/Dcom-Australia/Local%20Assets/Documents/news-research/Press%20releases/Global%20Powers%20of%20Retailing/Global_Powers_of_Retailing_2010_report.pdf |archivedate=14 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> first proposed a store on the site in 1996.<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news |title=In a hole |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2005/aug/25/architecture.supermarkets |date=25 August 2005 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=17 June 2009 | first=Jonathan | last=Glancey |location=London}}</ref> The local council also objected to the development and a public inquiry endorsed this decision. In July 1998, however, [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]] John Prescott overturned the council's ruling on the basis of the recommendations of an independent planning inspector. Due to a lack of space in the area, Tesco had proposed building over the railway line, which would free up a large area of land suitable for the development.<ref name="guardian1" />
The work was let under a [[Design-build|design and build]] contract to Jackson Civil Engineering, who announced the store would be designed by White Young Green, and specialist supplier Reinforced Earth Company.<ref name="nce4">{{Citation|last=Hansford|first=Mark|title=Tesco finally restarts work at Gerrards Cross tunnel collapse site | periodical =New Civil Engineer|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/tesco-finally-restarts-work-at-gerrards-cross-tunnel-collapse-site/1965393.article |publication-date=14 January 2009 |publisher=[[EMAP]] |accessdate=17 June 2009}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> Work started on site in early 2003.<ref name="bucks1">{{Citation|last=Cain|first=Rebecca|title=Controversial Gerrards Cross Tesco store opened today|date=29 November 2010|accessdate=12 January 2011|publisher=[[Bucks Free Press]]|url=http://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/8708434.Controversial_Tesco_store_opens_to_flood_of_shoppers/}}</ref> At the time Jackson Civil Engineering were part of the Peterhouse Group, which was subsequently bought by [[Babcock International Group]] in 2004, after the Jackson Civil Engineering division had been sold in a management buyout.<ref>{{Citation|last=Reece|first=Damian|title=Babcock grows with £105m Peterhouse buy|date=23 March 2004|accessdate=12 January 2011|publisher=[[The Independent]]|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/babcock-grows-with-pound105m-peterhouse-buy-567294.html|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Management Buy Out |publisher=Jackson |accessdate=12 January 2011 |url=http://www.jackson-civils.co.uk/news/news_archive_MBO.htm }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Babcock were still subject to the parent company guarantee that Peterhouse Group had entered into when the contract to build the tunnel was let.<ref name="babcock">{{Citation|title=Annual Report and Accounts 2009 |publisher=Babcock International Group PLC |page=31 |url=http://www.babcock.co.uk/uploads/financial/Babcock_AR2009.pdf |accessdate=12 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212063124/http://babcock.co.uk/uploads/financial/Babcock_AR2009.pdf |archivedate=12 December 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The design used [[precast concrete]] sections, each of which made up half of a [[three-pinned arch]]. These segments were connected to each other at the middle of the arch, and material then built back up over the arch, known as backfilling. The method of construction was not unique. "There are eight tunnels like this in Britain," said James Ford of [[Chiltern Railways]], "and something like a thousand worldwide."<ref name="guardian1"/> At the time of collapse, construction work on the tunnel segments had finished, and the backfilling operation was taking place.<ref name="nce1">{{citation |last=Wynne|first=Alexandra|title=Cross purpose | periodical =New Civil Engineer|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/geotechnical/cross-purpose/1995578.article |publication-date=19 March 2009 |publisher=[[EMAP]] |accessdate=17 June 2009}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> The foundations had been built and the steel frame of the supermarket erected.
{{triple image|centre|Gerrards Cross railway station 2.jpg|200|Gerrards Cross Tesco Tunnel2.jpg|200|Gerrards Cross Tesco Tunnel1.jpg|200|Construction of the tunnel, which was meant to enable the construction of a new [[supermarket]] over the railway line, pictured three months before the collapse. While the council blocked the store, the decision was overturned and construction began.|||||}}
==Collapse== [[File:Tunnel collapse Gerrards Cross.jpg|thumb|During the collapse, the crown of the tunnel caved in on itself, bringing the tonnes of soil piled on top down onto the railway tracks, which are visible in the foreground.]] At 7.34pm<ref>{{cite news|title=Gerrards Cross|url=http://www.railwaypeople.com/rail-news-articles/gerrards-cross-736.html|accessdate=14 October 2010|newspaper=RailwayPeople.com|date=26 August 2005}}</ref> on 30 June 2005,<ref>{{cite news|last=Brunetti|first=Nic|title=Railway tunnel collapses at Gerrards Cross|url=http://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/610794.railway_tunnel_collapses_at_gerrards_cross/ |newspaper=[[Bucks Free Press]] |date=1 July 2005 |accessdate=14 October 2010 }}</ref> 30 metres of the 320 metre<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Lewis|title=Railway tunnel collapse will cost Tesco millions|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article539550.ece|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=2 July 2005 |accessdate=14 October 2010 }}</ref> tunnel collapsed. At the time, there were no trains passing through the tunnel, although one train, heading west towards [[High Wycombe railway station|High Wycombe]], had to make an emergency stop. The train had passed through [[Denham Golf Club railway station|Denham Golf Club station]], the last stop before Gerrards Cross, before the driver was warned by radio. He reversed the train to Denham Golf Club, where all passengers were let off.{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} Additionally, a London-bound train was standing at the eastbound platform at Gerrards Cross waiting to depart. The driver of this train had just set the train in motion when he saw the collapse, stopped his train using the emergency brake, and informed the railway signallers by radio; they in turn stopped other trains.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jones |first=Hugh |title=The Chiltern Railways Story |year=2010 |publisher=[[The History Press]] |location=Brimscombe |isbn=978-0-7524-5454-2 |pages=12–13 |ref=harv }}</ref> There were no casualties as a result of the incident. One witness told a news channel that he was parking his car when he heard "what sounded like a clap of thunder - I thought it was an earthquake. I saw the tunnel falling on to the rail track."<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|title=Tunnel collapse causes rail chaos|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/4639671.stm|newspaper=[[BBC News]] |date=1 July 2005 |accessdate=14 October 2010 }}</ref> Reg Whittome, chairman of the Marylebone Travellers' Association and the Chiltern Railway Passenger Board, said after the incident that, had a train been going through the tunnel when it collapsed, there would have been an "almighty tragedy". He added: "Had it been during the rush hour, hundreds could have been killed."<ref name="guardian1" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Calling the shots: How supermarkets get their way in planning decisions|url=http://www.foe.co.uk/resource/briefings/calling_the_shots.pdf|publisher=[[Friends of the Earth]]|page=23|accessdate=3 January 2011}}</ref>
==Service disruption== Service was disrupted for two months after the collapse, until 22 August 2005, so material could be removed from site. The line was closed and [[Public transport bus service#Specialist services|rail replacement bus services]] were operated.<ref>{{cite news|title=Probe after Tesco tunnel collapses onto railway|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-354255/Probe-Tesco-tunnel-collapses-railway.html|accessdate=3 January 2011|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=1 July 2005|location=London}}</ref> The 29 precast concrete segments that had collapsed were removed, together with another 16 segments that were damaged.<ref name="nce1"/> Extensive design checks were carried out to ensure that the sections of tunnel lining that had not collapsed were safe. 15,000 tonnes of material were removed from the area which had suffered the collapse, and 12,000 tonnes of backfill was removed from the undamaged sections.<ref name="nce2">{{citation |title=No early opening for Tesco at Gerrards Cross| periodical =New Civil Engineer |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/no-early-opening-for-tesco-at-gerrards-cross/540465.article |publication-date=1 October 2005 |publisher=[[EMAP]] |accessdate=17 June 2009}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> Despite the railway line reopening, approval was not given to carry on with the work as originally proposed. [[Network Rail]] and [[Chiltern Railways]] advised that further checks were required to confirm the safety of the design.<ref name="nce3">{{citation |title=Backfilling thought to be culprit in Gerrards Cross rail tunnel collapse | periodical =New Civil Engineer|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/backfilling-thought-to-be-culprit-in-gerrards-cross-rail-tunnel-collapse/540662.article |date=1 August 2005 |publisher=[[EMAP]] |accessdate=17 June 2009}} {{Subscription required}}</ref>
"The tunnel has collapsed. We've now got to assess today why that happened," said Robin Gisby, head of operations for Network Rail.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> "Experts are in there right now and they will work through the tunnel and decide what was the cause of the delay. Then we're going to make it safe, then we're going to work out how we're going to clear up the considerable problem we've got. There's a couple of thousand tonnes of material in there that we've got to move. We've got to get the concrete structure, that has collapsed, out. We've probably got to do all of that by road. Although we brought the material in by rail, we don't think we can get it out by rail, but we won't assess that until later on today and through the night. I think that's going to be at least a week's work, possibly longer, before we can restore rail services on this route. Passengers are being advised to travel via alternative routes and buses have also been ordered. We are currently putting arrangements in place to minimise disruption."<ref name=autogenerated2 />
At the time of the accident, James Ford added that no further work would be carried out on the tunnel unless it had been certified as safe. "As to whether or not Tesco plans to continue building above the tunnel, we just don't know," he said. "What we do know is that there will be no further work, or anything that could have an effect on it, unless Network Rail and the HSE are satisfied that it's safe to do so. Network Rail will consult us if this situation arises. Tesco may, however, choose to continue work on parts of the supermarket project that are not directly connected to the tunnel."<ref name="guardian1" />
==Investigation== [[File:Denham Golf Club Station - geograph.org.uk - 89693.jpg|thumb|right|A train was forced to make an emergency stop after passing through [[Denham Golf Club railway station|Denham Golf Club]] – the last station before the tunnel]] The initial investigations into the cause of collapse focused on the [[fill dirt|backfilling]] operation. The tunnel segments allowed for substantial vertical settlement during construction, and it was vital that the material was built up evenly on both sides and over the crown of the arch. Shortly after the incident, however, Gisby said that "something" about the backfilling "is not right." The chief executive of Jackson Civil Engineering, however, said that the process used was "in line with what the design allowed. There was a strict loading regime in place."<ref name="nce4" /> [[Geotechnical engineering|Geotechnical engineers]] commenting in the wake of the incident expressed surprise at the difference in fill levels on either side of the arch, and doubts were expressed that the backfilling had been in accordance with the method statement. "The collapse was probably due to too much load on the crown of the arch and not enough fill on the sides," the head of a specialist consulting firm said.<ref name="nce4" />
"Units [appear to] have failed by creating a hinge in the concrete section. The hinge has rotated downwards, which is consistent with the crown of the arch moving downwards under excessive load and/or the sides of the arch moving outwards under too little lateral restraint. This problem would have been made worse if there was a significant difference in the level of the fill on the two sides. At the section that is still standing the central hinge has bent down indicating an imbalance between the vertical and horizontal loads and a failure by outward spreading of the arch."<ref name="nce4" /> He added that heavy rainfall, which had hit Gerrards Cross several days before the collapse, may have made the problem worse. "It is possible that rainfall increased the vertical load on the tunnel. At the same time, if the fill at the sides is not completely free draining, it could have led to a reduction in the passive pressure available from the fill on the sides."<ref name="nce4" /> Another construction specialist said: "You could trigger failure if you go straight from full depth fill over one section straight to no fill; that is, a section that's fully flexed next to one that's unflexed."<ref name="nce4" />
The Health and Safety Executive launched an investigation into the collapse in 2005. Owing to the complex nature<ref name="FOI 2010">{{cite web | url=https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/gerrards_cross_tunnel_collapse_r#incoming-121179 | title=Freedom of Information request | publisher=whatdotheyknow.com | date=18 October 2010 | accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref> of the probe, it remained open until 2015. A final report has been prepared, but has not yet been made public pending resolution of legal issues.<ref name="FOI 2017" />
==Aftermath== The incident brought protests from local residents and the council. The local [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[w:Member of Parliament (UK)|MP]], [[Dominic Grieve]], said: "If this particular disaster encourages Tesco to not go ahead with the scheme, everyone in Gerrards Cross will be absolutely delighted."<ref name="guardian1" /> Peter Hardy, the leader of South Bucks district council, added after the landslide that there would be "further years of disruption ... It would be better to abandon the project. I'm not against Tesco as such, but as a council, we want the inquiry into the collapse of the tunnel to be open and transparent. We want to know why such a hugely complex engineering process has been deemed necessary to build a relatively small new Tesco store. And we want something positive back from Tesco."<ref name="guardian1" />
There were protests by local residents against the store. One protester said they were "fighting to get Tesco to tell us exactly why the tunnel collapsed, and to stop them from succeeding in winning further planning permission to continue work on the store." Some were less opposed to the store. "People here like to have a go at Tesco," an estate agent said. "I suppose most of us would have preferred a [[Marks & Spencer]] food hall, but we'll all shop in Tesco anyway."<ref name="guardian1" />
[[File:New Supermarket at Gerrards Cross - geograph.org.uk - 29078.jpg|thumb|An image showing the store being erected shortly after construction restarted. [[Tesco]] appointed a new team to continue the design and construction of the tunnel and store.]]
In 2006, Tesco appointed a new team to carry out the design and construction of the tunnel and store. [[Costain Group|Costain]] were assigned as main [[General contractor|contractor]] and [[Scott Wilson Group|Scott Wilson]] as lead designer.<ref name="nce4" /> In light of the collapse, a far more cautious approach was taken to the design. Precast concrete arch sections were used, but these simply act as formwork for a 600mm thick in-situ concrete continuous arch, a much more robust structure. To further reduce the loading on the tunnel, [[Piling#Piled walls|piled walls]] have been installed either side of the tunnel, and a lighter fill material—including foamed concrete—used over the top of the arch.<ref name="nce1" />
The store opened in late November 2010,<ref name=opened>{{cite news|last=Abell|first=Jack|title=Tesco finally opens its doors|url=http://gerrardscross.buckinghamshireadvertiser.co.uk/2010/12/tesco-finally-opens-its-doors.html|accessdate=13 December 2010|date=3 December 2010}}</ref> 5 years later than originally planned,<ref name="guardian1" /> and 14 years after the project started.<ref name=opened/> The store manager, Lizzie Field, said: "We are really pleased to support our local community at a time when so many people are looking for jobs, and there is so much competition between applicants. The quality of applicants was fantastic and my new team and I are already enjoying working together."<ref name=opening/> When the store opened, the ''[[Bucks Free Press]]'' reported that there was still opposition to the "controversial" store. The newspaper reported that "some have complained about dust coming from the site, as well as traffic delays while roadworks were carried out."<ref name=opening/> A local resident, who protested against the project since it was announced, said: "It's been very very frustrating. I won't be using the store and a lot of people in Gerrards Cross feel the same way. I think the traffic situation is going to be horrendous."<ref name=opening>{{cite web| url=http://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/8625371.Tesco_to_finally_open_after_14_year_controversy/| title = Tesco to finally open after 14 year controversy| publisher = ''[[Bucks Free Press]]''| accessdate = 8 November 2010}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Unbalanced|date=March 2016}} [[File:Gestation crates 3.jpg|thumb|300px|Gestation crates, used on modern pig-production facilities, commonly referred to as [[Factory farming|factory farms]]]] A '''gestation crate''', also known as a '''sow stall''', is a metal enclosure in which a [[pig farming|farmed]] [[domestic pig#Glossary of terms|sow]] used for breeding may be kept during pregnancy and after parturition in order to keep her piglets safe in a small space setting.<ref name=Pond2011p151ff>Wilson G. Pond, Fuller W. Bazer, Bernard E. Rollin (eds.), ''Animal Welfare in Animal Agriculture'', CRC Press, 2011, p. 151ff.</ref><ref name=Rollin1995p76>{{citation |author=Bernard E. Rollin, |title=Farm Animal Welfare: Social, Bioethical, and Research Issues |publisher=Iowa State University Press |date=1995 |page=76}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.farmsanctuary.org/campaign/gestation_evidence.htm |title=The Welfare of Sows in Gestation Crates: A Summary of the Scientific Evidence |publisher=Farm Sanctuary |date=2004 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223155956/http://www.farmsanctuary.org/campaign/gestation_evidence.htm |archivedate=23 December 2007 |df= }}</ref> A standard crate measures 6.6 ft x 2.0 ft (2 m x 60 cm).<ref>Pauk D. Reun, et al., "Breeding and gestation facilities for swine: matching biology to facility design," ''Veterinary Clinics of North America: Food Animal Practice'', 8(3), 1992, pp. 475–502. {{PMID|1446265}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100703144502/http://www.hsus.org/web-files/PDF/farm/HSUS-Report-on-Gestation-Crates-for-Pregnant-Sows.pdf "An HSUS Report: Welfare Issues with Gestation Crates for Pregnant Sows"], Humane Society of the United States, 2008, p. 1.</ref>
Sow stalls contain no bedding material and are instead floored with slatted plastic, concrete or metal to allow waste to be efficiently collected below. This waste is then flushed into open-air pits known as [[Anaerobic lagoon|lagoons]].<ref name=Kaufmann2>Marc Kaufmann, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110724013229/http://www.pmac.net/AM/pigs_in_crates.html "In Pig Farming, Growing Concern, Raising Sows in Crates Is Questioned"], ''The Washington Post'', 18 June 2001.</ref><ref>Jeff Tietz, [https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/boss-hog-the-dark-side-of-americas-top-pork-producer-20061214 "Boss Hog"], ''Rolling Stone'', 14 December 2006.</ref> A few days before giving birth, sows are moved to farrowing crates where they are able to lie down, with an attached crate from which their piglets can nurse.
There were 5.36 million breeding sows in the United States as of 2016, out of a total of 50.1 million pigs.<ref>[http://usda.mannlib.cornell.edu/usda/nass/HogsPigs//2000s/2007/HogsPigs-12-27-2007.pdf "U.S. Hog Inventory up 4 Percent"], ''Quarterly Hogs and Pigs'', National Agricultural Statistics Service, 27 December 2007.</ref> Most pregnant sows in the US are kept in gestation crates.<ref name=Pond2011p151ff/> The crates are banned for new installations only in Canada, so many sows are still confined in Canadian pig breeding facilities. They are banned in the United Kingdom and Sweden, and in nine states in the US (Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Maine, Michigan, Ohio, Oregon and Rhode Island).<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite news|authors=Andrew Wasley, Jordan Gass-Poore and Cecilia Ferrara |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/mar/30/row-erupts-between-italys-parma-ham-makers-and-activists-over-pig-welfare |title=Row erupts between Italy's Parma ham makers and activists over pig welfare |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref><ref>Brett Mizelle, ''Pig'', Reaktion Books, 2012, p. 92; Roberta Lee, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/roberta-lee/summer-fun-but-not-for-pi_b_7759466.html "Summer Fun, But Not for Pigs: The Horror of Gestation Crates and Life in a Factory Farm"], ''The Huffington Post'', 16 July 2015.</ref> However, farrowing crates, in which female breeding pigs can be kept for up to five weeks, are not banned.<ref>Oliver Thring, [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2012/jan/26/is-red-tractor-pork-high-welfare "Is Red Tractor pork really 'high welfare'?"], ''The Guardian'', 26 January 2012.</ref>
Opponents of the crates argue that they constitute animal abuse, while proponents say they are needed to prevent sows from fighting among themselves.<ref>{{citation |quote=The major issues surrounding the housing of sows during gestation are focused on the detrimental effects of close confinement and barren environment afforded by stalls on the one hand versus the detrimental effects of aggressive social behavior afforded by group housing on the other |author=Jeremy N. Marchant Forde |url=http://www.ars.usda.gov/SP2UserFiles/Place/50201500/Sow%20Housing%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf |title=Housing and Welfare of Sows during Gestation |work=Livestock Behavior Research Unit |publisher=USDA |date=Fall 2010}}</ref>
==Usage==
===Pregnancy=== [[File:Gestation crate (Farm Sanctuary).jpg|thumb|Sows used for breeding in 6.6 ft × 2.0 ft (2 m × 60 cm) gestation crates]]
Between 60 and 70 percent of sows are kept in crates during pregnancy in the United States.<ref name=Webster2>J. Webster, ''Animal Welfare: A Cool Eye Towards Eden'', Oxford: Blackwell Science Ltd, cited in [https://web.archive.org/web/20060822182809/http://www.hsus.org/farm/resources/research/practices/gestation_crates.html#003 An HSUS Report: Welfare Issues with Gestation Crates for Pregnant Sows], Humane Society of the United States.</ref> Each pregnancy lasts for three months, three weeks, and three days. Sows will have an average of 2.5 litters every year for two or three years, most of which is spent in the crates.<ref name=Kaufmann2/><ref name=SwineNews>[http://mark.asci.ncsu.edu/Swine_News/2006/February/February06.pdf "Obtaining optimal reproductive efficiency"] (pdf), ''Swine News'', North Carolina State Cooperative Extension Service, February 2006, Volume 29, Number 1.</ref> They give birth to between five and eight litters before being culled from the herd. Some older sows may reach a size at which they have to sleep on their chests, unable to lie on their sides as pigs usually do.<ref name=Kaufmann1>Marc Kaufmann, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/25/AR2007012501785.html "Largest Pork Processor to Phase Out Crates"], ''The Washington Post'', 26 January 2007.</ref> The floors are slatted to allow excrement and other waste to fall into a pit below.
===Birth{{anchor|farrowing}}=== [[File:Piglets Nursing in a Farrowing Crate.jpg|thumb|Nursing sow in a farrowing crate]]
A few days before giving birth, sows are moved to [[farrowing crates]], which are slightly wider so they can lie down to nurse. Crates have 18-in. (46-cm) "troughs" on each side where the piglets can safely lie without being in danger of sow overlay (when the sow lies down on top of a piglet).
Piglet survival also depends on selection pressure. Groups of piglets bred for higher survival showed no difference in mortality when weaned in farrowing crates and outdoor systems.<ref>E. M. Baxter, et al., "Breeding for improved pre-weaning piglet survival in alternative farrowing systems," Proceedings of the 41st congress of the International Society for Applied Ethology (F. Galindo and L. Alvarez, eds.), 2007, Merida, Mexico.</ref>
====Piglet Mortality==== Although farrowing crates have been used based on the assumption that they reduce piglet mortality rates, there is little published evidence in support of this claim. The most comprehensive publication to date on this subject concluded that there is no significant effect of housing on overall piglet mortality, the authors stating that “Despite the fact that the crate system has been considered to reduce piglet mortality mainly through a reduction of crushing, there is not much scientific evidence for this when considering the few large surveys that compare the mortality rate in commercial herds“. The review goes on to describe several large studies dating from as early as 1983, the majority of which found no difference in piglet mortality rates between loose and crated sows. The review also details an argument as to why piglet mortality rates have been reported to be somewhat higher in a comparably small number of studies, citing methodological flaws.<ref name=Pedersen>L.J. Pedersen, http://www.wageningenacademic.com/doi/pdf/10.3920/978-90-8686-771-4_05 "Housing of sows during farrowing: a review on pen design, welfare and productivity", retrieved January 2017.</ref>
==Limitations on usage==
=== European Union === In the European Union, the crates must not be used after the fourth week of pregnancy following a 2013 EU Directive. They are illegal at all times in the United Kingdom and Sweden.<ref name="theguardian1"/>
===New Zealand=== The use of gestation crates following mating will be phased out in New Zealand by 2015. However the crates are still legal for up to 4 weeks after farrowing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10691325|title=Sow crates to be phased out by 2015 - National - NZ Herald News|date=1 December 2010|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=NZPA|accessdate=1 December 2010}}</ref> A review lead by the Ministry for Primary Industries, in 2016, found that "The current code of welfare allows for up to 5% of sows to be retained in crates for a further week (following the 4 week maximum in crates post-farrowing) as nurse sows. This practice enables slowly growing or poorly performing piglets to be properly weaned. It has been noted that industry does not accept or comply with this requirement and some producers are exceeding both the maximum 5% of sows allowed to be retained for this purpose and the amount of time that they are being retained (i.e. greater than the one week maximum as stated in the code)." And "The current code requires that sows in any farrowing system constructed after 3 December 2010, must be provided with material that can be manipulated until farrowing (to allow the sow to perform nesting behaviour which she is extremely motivated to do). It has been noted by NAWAC during this review that industry disagrees with this requirement and does not comply with this minimum standard."<ref>{{cite |url=http://www.mpi.govt.nz/document-vault/11959|title=NAWAC review of the use of Farrowing Crates for Pigs in New Zealand|date=14 March 2016|work=[[Ministry for Primary Industries (New Zealand)|Ministry for Primary Industries]]|publisher=MPI|accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref>
===North America=== In 2014 Canada instituted a nationwide ban on new gestation crates.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.onegreenplanet.org/news/victory-for-pigs-canada-bans-gestation-crates/ | author=Alexis Croswell | date=7 March 2014 | title=Victory for Pigs! Canada Bans Gestation Crates | accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref> {{US sow stall ban map}}
In the United States, they have been banned in Florida since 2002, Arizona since 2006, and California since late 2008.<ref name=Kaufmann1/> A Rhode Island law banning the crates, passed in June 2012, took effect in June 2013.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/06/new-ri-law-bans.html|title=New R.I. law bans cutting dairy-cow tails, raising pigs and calves in crates| author=Philip Marcelo| date=21 June 2012}}</ref> They are also being phased out in Colorado, Maine, Michigan, Ohio and Oregon.<ref>Centner, TJ (2009) Limitations on the confinement of food animals in the United States. Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics online first [http://www.springerlink.com/content/f7743741k385x233]</ref>
As of 2013 New Jersey had a pig population of about 9,000<ref>{{cite news | author = Matt Arco | title = Clock ticking for Chris Christie to act on controversial N.J. pig bill with 2016 implications | newspaper = The Star-Ledger | date = 26 November 2014 | url = http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2014/11/clock_ticking_for_chris_christie_to_declare_position_on_controversial_nj_pig_bill_with_presidential.html#incart_river}}</ref> none of which, according to the [[Humane Society]], are kept in gestation crates.<ref>{{cite news | author=Melissa Hayes | title = Humane Society urges ban in N.J. on gestational crates in pig breeding | publisher = The Record | date = 27 October 2014 | url = http://www.northjersey.com/news/humane-society-urges-ban-in-n-j-on-gestational-crates-in-pig-breeding-1.1118970}}</ref> In survey conducted in 2013, 90% of New Jersey voters were in favor of banning the crates.<ref>{{cite press release | title = N.J. TV Ads Call for End to Inhumane Gestation Crate Confinement of Pigs | publisher = Humane Society | date = 4 February 2013 | url = http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2013/02/NJ_gestation_crate_bill_020413.html | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref> In June 2013, [[Governor of New Jersey|Governor]] [[Chris Christie]] vetoed S1921,<ref>{{cite news | title = SENATE, No. 1921 | publisher = New Jersey Legislature | date = 13 May 2012 | url = http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2012/Bills/S2000/1921_R1.HTM | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref> a bill to ban pig gestation crates.<ref>{{cite news|title=\Chris Christie Vetoes NJ Pork Gestation Crate Ban|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/27/chris-christie-gestation-crate_n_3512521.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author = P. J. Huffstuutter | title = New Jersey governor vetoes ban on gestation crate use | newspaper = Reuters | date = 27 January 2013 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/27/us-usa-farm-gestation-crate-veto-idUSBRE95Q1I920130627}}</ref> which had passed in the [[New Jersey General Assembly|General Assembly]] with a vote of 60-5 and the [[New Jersey Senate|Senate]] 29-4. An attempt to override the veto did not come to a vote.<ref>{{cite news | last = Portnoy | first = Jenna | title = N.J. Senate to attempt to override Christie's veto on pig crates bill Gov. Chris Christie vetoed a bill in June that would have prohibited the farm practice of placing pregnant pigs in gestation cages | newspaper = The Star-Ledger | date = 11 November 2013 | url = http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/11/chris_christie_pig_veto_override.html | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref> In October 2014 the [[New Jersey Legislature]] adopted S998<ref>{{cite news | title = SENATE, No. 998 | publisher = New Jersey Legislature | date = 27 January 2014 | url = http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2014/Bills/S1000/998_I1.HTM | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref> with a vote in the Senate of 32-1 and in the Assembly 53-13 (with 9 abstentions)<ref>{{cite news | title = S998 Sca (1R) | publisher = New Jersey Legislature | date = | url = http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=S998 | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref> On 27 November 2014 Christie vetoed the bill.<ref>{{cite news | last = Brodesser-Akner | first = Claude | title = Christie vetoes pig crate ban, accuses sponsors of partisan politicking | newspaper = The Star-Ledger | date = 28 November 2014 | url= http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2014/11/christie_vetoes_pig_crate_ban_accusses_sponsors_of_partisan_politicking.html#incart_m-rpt-2 | accessdate = 30 November 2014}}</ref>
===Corporate policies=== Over 60 major food companies have policies to eliminate their use.<ref>http://cratefreefuture.com/pdf/Gestation%20Crate%20Elimination%20Policies.pdf</ref>
[[Smithfield Foods]], the largest pork producer in the United States, said in January 2007 that it will phase out gestation crates from its 187 piggeries over the next ten years because of concerns from its customers. In 2009 the company stated it would no longer be able to phase them out in ten years due to recent low sales,<ref name=Kaufmann1/> but reversed the decision in 2011 after intense pressure from the [[Humane Society of the United States]].<ref name="smithfield_recommit">{{cite news|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2011/12/smithfield-end-use-gestation-crates-2017|title=Smithfield to end use of gestation crates by 2017|author=Walzer, Philip|date=9 December 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref>
In February 2012 [[McDonald's]] announced that it would begin working with suppliers to phase out the use of gestation crates in response to pressure from the Humane Society of the United States and other animal advocates. McDonald's purchases around one percent of all pork in the United States.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/14/business/mcdonalds-vows-to-help-end-use-of-sow-crates.html | work=The New York Times | first=Stephanie | last=Strom | title=McDonald's Vows to Help End Use of Sow Crates | date=13 February 2012}}</ref>
==Welfare issues== [[File:Gestation crates 5.jpg|thumb|Gestation crates 5|thumbnail|A [[Pig|sow]] will stay in a gestation crate for the four-month period of her pregnancy.]] Animal welfare advocates regard the use of gestation crates as one of the most inhumane features of intensive animal production.<ref name="Kaufmann1"/> [[Temple Grandin]] of [[Colorado State University]]'s Department of Animal Science said in 2007: "... basically you’re asking a sow to live in an airline seat."<ref name=Shapiro>Shapiro, Paul. [http://www.globegazette.com/articles/2007/01/10/opinion/doc45a44853758c8203994884.txt Pork industry should phase out gestation crates (Guest View)], ''Globe Gazette'', 10 January 2007.</ref>
Pork producers argue that gestation crates are needed because sows that are housed together in pens will fight, injuring or killing their fellow penmates. The same effect could be achieved with larger pens that kept the animals separate, but allowed them more freedom of movement. There are also other ways of reducing, but not eliminating, aggression besides gestation crates. These include eliminating overcrowding, not mixing pigs from different litters, providing straw or other bedding material, and providing sufficient food that not only meets nutritional needs but satisfies the appetite.<ref>SA Weaver and MC Morris, "Science, pigs and politics: an New Zealand perspective on the phase-out of sow stalls," ''Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics'' 17 (2003), 51–66.</ref> Other important means to reduce aggression among sows rely on alternative feeding methods, as many sows will compete with each other for food. These include trickle feeding systems, individual feeding stalls, and electronic sow feeding equipment, all of which resolve feed competition among pigs.<ref>Gonyou HW. 2003. Group housing: alternative systems, alternative management. Advances in Pork Production 14:101-7.</ref>
Early veterinary studies seemed to support the use of gestation crates. According to the [[U.S. National Pork Producers Council]], which promotes pork as a food product and is a leading proponent of gestation crates, the [[American Veterinary Medical Association]] "recognize[s] gestation stalls and group housing systems as appropriate for providing for the well-being of sows during pregnancy."<ref name=Kaufmann1/> While the practice of immobilizing the animals in crates limits fighting, it subsequently increases the animals' stress levels, causing other health problems. The American Association of Swine Veterinarians adopted a position statement in 2002 specifying five standards of sow welfare and concluding, "Current scientific literature indicates that individual gestation stalls meet each of the aforementioned, provided the appropriate level of stockmanship is administered."<ref>"AASV Position Statement: Pregnant Sow Housing." Accessed 31 July 2012.</ref>
{{farming}} ''The Washington Post'' reported in 2001 that researchers have not found sows in gestation crates to have elevated levels of [[stress hormone]]s. The paper notes that this suggests their overall health is not compromised. Some producers in Europe use a “free access” maternity pen configuration in which sows are in individual pens for the first four weeks of pregnancy but can “unlock” the stall by backing out and entering a common area. The producers observed that pregnant pigs will stay in the individual pens more than 90 percent of the time, and return to the same stall more than 90 percent of the time.<ref name="Salek-Johnson">{{cite news|last=Salek-Johnson|first=Janeen|title=Individual pens for sows’ safety|url=http://thegazette.com/2012/09/30/individual-pens-for-sows-safety/|accessdate=10 January 2014|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)|The Gazette]]|date=30 September 2012}}</ref>
However, other veterinary studies contradict those earlier studies. A 1997 report of the Scientific Veterinary Committee of the European Union, where a gestation crate ban went into effect in 2013, noted that because "overall welfare appears to be better when sows are not confined throughout gestation, sows should be preferably be kept in groups."<ref name="washingtonpost.com">Tim Carman, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/food/pork-industry-gives-sows-room-to-move/2012/05/25/gJQAISlxyU_story.html "Pork industry gives sows room to move"], ''The Washington Post'', 29 May 2012.</ref> Likewise in 2008, the Pew Commission on Industrial Farm Animal Production, after 2.5 years of research, recommended "the phase-out, within 10 years, of all intensive confinement systems that restrict natural movement and normal behaviors, including swine gestation crates."<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
Many studies have shown that sows in crates exhibit behavior such as bar-biting, head weaving, and tongue rolling, indicating chronic frustration. Sows in crates bite the bars, chew even when they have no food, and press their water bottles obsessively, all reportedly signs of boredom. The ''Post''(uncited reference) writes that a report by veterinarians for the [[European Union]] concluded that abnormal behavior in sows "develop[s] when the animal is severely or chronically frustrated. Hence their development indicates that the animal is having difficulty in coping and its welfare is poor."<ref name=Kaufmann2/> This behavior, such as bar-biting and other stereotypic behavior can also lead to other physical trauma, such as sores from frequent contact with the metal bars, and mouth sores from sham-chewing and bar-biting.<ref>Mendl MT. 1991. The effects of alternative forms of intensive pig husbandry on measures of pig welfare. In: Bradley A and Sckofield WL (eds.), Proceedings of the First Association of Veterinary Students Animal Welfare Symposium (Cambridge, U.K.: Association of Veterinary Students).</ref> They also show behavior that indicates [[learned helplessness]], according to Morris, such as remaining passive when poked or when a bucket of water is thrown over them.<ref name=Morris>Morris, Michael C. [http://homepages.ihug.co.nz/~nezumi1/sowstalls.html "Sow stalls and farrowing crates – ethically, scientifically and economically indefensible"], ''[[Organic New Zealand]]'', 62, no. 1, Jan/Feb 2003, 38–39.</ref> A review by the Scientific Veterinary Council of the [[European Commission]] states that repetitive "[[Stereotypy (non-human)|stereotypical]]" behavior has been found in "every detailed study" of pigs in gestation crates, but not in any other housing systems examined.<ref name="svc">SVC (Scientific Veterinary Committee) (1997). The welfare of intensively kept pigs. Commission of the European Communities, Directorate-General for Agriculture, Brussels.[http://ec.europa.eu/food/fs/sc/oldcomm4/out17_en.pdf].</ref> A 2004 literature review by animal scientists determined that sows in stalls exhibited more "stereotypical" behavior than sows in group housing, but that animals housed in stalls had lower injury rates and higher farrowing rates.<ref>McGlone, J.J. et al. "Compilation of the Scientific Literature Comparing Housing Systems for Gestating Sows and Gilts Using Measures of Physiology, Behavior, Performance, and Health," Professional Animal Scientist April 2004 vol. 20 no. 2 105-117.</ref> Some studies have shown that "sow behavior has been shown to differ among housing systems; often it seems to be the non-housing component (i.e., direction of bar, other substances present) of the system that is responsible for the behavior displayed by the sow."<ref>{{cite web|last=Salak-Johnson|first=Janeen|title=The Reality of Sow Stalls|url=http://www.pork.org/filelibrary/SowHousing/2007SowHousingForum/Proceedings/JaneenJohnson.pdf|accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref>
Many other health related issues are to be found among pigs confined within gestation crates as opposed to group housing systems. Some of these include urinary tract infections, respiratory disease,<ref name=Tillon1>Tillon JP and Madec F. 1984 [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/16708998_Diseases_affecting_confined_sows._Data_from_epidemiological_observationsTillon "Diseases affecting confined sows: data from epidemiological observations"]. Annales de Recherches Vétérinaires (Annals of Veterinary Research) 15(2):195-9. *[http://www.humanesociety.org/assets/pdfs/farm/HSUS-Report-on-Gestation-Crates-for-Pregnant-Sows.pdf "An HSUS Report: Welfare Issues with Gestation Crates for Pregnant Sows"], Humane Society of the United States.</ref> skin lesions (e.g. pressure sores),<ref>Broom DM, Mendl MT, Zanella AJ. 1995. A comparison of the welfare of sows in different housing conditions. Animal Science 61:369-85.</ref> excessive heat-loss,<ref name=Webster2/> bone density,<ref name=Marchant1>Marchant JN and Broom DM. 1996. Effects of dry sow housing conditions on muscle weight and bone strength. Animal Science 62:105-13.</ref> muscle health,<ref name=Marchant1/> cardiovascular health,<ref name=Commission1>Commission of the European Communities. 2001. COM(2001) 20 final 2001/0021 (CNS) Communication from the Commission to the Council and the European Parliament on the welfare of intensively kept pigs in particularly taking into account the welfare of sows reared in varying degrees of confinement and in groups. Proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 91/630/EEC laying down minimum standards for the protection of pigs.</ref> foot injuries,<ref name=Kornegay1>Kornegay ET, Bryant KL, and Notter DR. 1990. Toe lesion development in gilts and sows housed in confinement as influenced by toe size and toe location. [[Applied Agricultural Research]] 5(4):327-34.</ref> damage to joints,<ref name=Fredeen1>Fredeen HT and Sather AP. 1978. Joint damage in pigs reared under confinement. ''[[Canadian Journal of Animal Science]]'', 58:759-73.</ref> and even lameness<ref name=Marchant1/>
According to John Webster, head of the Veterinary School at [[Bristol University]] in the United Kingdom, "Sows on concrete in confinement stalls suffer abuse according to all the Five Freedoms." These include freedom from hunger, discomfort, pain, distress, and freedom to express normal behavior.<ref name=Webster1>Webster J. 2005. [http://103.9.88.89/app/2014-06-22/Animal%20Welfare%20%20Limping%20Towards%20Eden%20John%20Webster%20(UFAW%20Animal%20Welfare)%20(2005).pdf "Animal Welfare: Limping Towards Eden"] (Oxford, U.K.: Blackwell Publishing, pp. 12, 116).</ref> Sows that have to lay on concrete flooring can experience excessive heat loss and chronic physical discomfort,<ref name=Webster1/> while this same concrete flooring can contribute to foot injuries,<ref name=Kornegay1/> joint pain complications,<ref name=Fredeen1/> and skin lesions <ref name=Webster2/> - due to the pigs prolonged contact with an unusually hard surface and chronic inactivity.<ref>Webster J. 2005. [http://103.9.88.89/app/2014-06-22/Animal%20Welfare%20%20Limping%20Towards%20Eden%20John%20Webster%20(UFAW%20Animal%20Welfare)%20(2005).pdf "Animal Welfare: Limping Towards Eden"] (Oxford, U.K.: Blackwell Publishing, pp. 112).</ref>
Poor cardiovascular health, bone density issues, and poor muscle health all have been attributed to lack of exercise.<ref name=Marchant1/><ref name=Commission1/> The decreased amount of muscle mass makes even simple movements difficult,<ref>Marchant JN, Broom DM. 1993. The effects of dry sow housing conditions on lying behaviour of sows. [In] Nichelmann M, Wierenga HK, Braun S, editors. ''Proceedings of the [[International Congress on Applied Ethology]]''; Darmstadt: KTBL; p 455-58.</ref> while one study found that crated sows had two thirds the bone density of non-crated sows, with researchers concluding that weakened bones led to a higher incidence of broken bones or injuries<ref name=Marchant1/> and another study finding that a common factor in mortality cases was leg weakness.<ref>Christensen, G., Vraa-Anderson, L. and Mousing, J. (1995) Causes of mortality among sows in Danish pig herds. ''[[Veterinary Record]]'', 137: 395-399</ref> The lameness contributed to these weakened bones is also in part due to the hardness of the concrete flooring, which inevitably leads to a higher incidence of injuries to the feet and or legs,<ref name=Sather1>Sather AP and Fredeen HT. 1982. "The effect of confinement housing upon the incidence of leg weakness in swine". ''Canadian Journal of Animal Science'' 62:1119-28. *[http://www.humanesociety.org/assets/pdfs/farm/HSUS-Report-on-Gestation-Crates-for-Pregnant-Sows.pdf "An HSUS Report: Welfare Issues with Gestation Crates for Pregnant Sows"], Humane Society of the United States.</ref> not to mention shoulder sores and abrasions to the skin from rocks, sharp edges, and bolts fastening the crates in place.<ref>Miller D. 2004. Sows flourish in pen gestation. ''National Hog Farmer'', 15 March.</ref><ref>Stalder K and Baas T. 2005. Screen gilts for feet and leg disorders. ''National Hog Farmer'', 15 February.</ref> This same flooring is thought to contribute to toe lesions,<ref name=Kornegay1/> with some reports claiming that up to 80% of crated sows suffer from this illness.<ref name=Tillon1/> Due to lack of exercise, sows may develop a number of additional physical conditions that compromise their overall well-being. Urinary tract infections may develop as a result of the pigs immobility, which causes them to drink less frequently and consequently develop bacteria within the urinary tract.<ref name=Tillon1/> Though this same illness is contributed to the fact that sows are forced to lie, or sit, in their own feces<ref name=Sather1/> - another reason some think there is a higher incidence of respiratory disease among sows confined in gestation crates.<ref name=Tillon1/>
In a symposium held in 2002 on swine housing and well being, Edmond A. Pajor, Associate Professor at [[Purdue University]], told the audience that "In gestation stalls, sows are prevented from performing many of the behavior patterns that pigs would perform in more natural or less restricted conditions resulting in a negative impact on sow welfare."<ref>Pajor EA. 2002. Group housing of sows in small pens: advantages, disadvantages and recent research. In: Reynells R (ed.), Symposium on Swine Housing and Well-being (Beltsville, MD: [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]], pp. 37-44). www.ces.purdue.edu/pork/sowhousing/swine_02.pdf. Accessed 19 May 2008.</ref>
Paul Sundberg, a veterinarian and vice president of the U.S. National Pork Board, a leading proponent of gestation crates, told ''[[The Washington Post]]'': "Farmers treat their animals well because that's just good business. The key to sow welfare isn't whether they are kept in individual crates or group housing, but whether the system used is well managed." Sundberg said: "[S]cience tells us that she [a sow] doesn't even seem to know that she can't turn ... She wants to eat and feel safe, and she can do that very well in individual stalls."<ref name=Kaufmann2/>

*[https://www.avma.org/KB/Resources/Reports/Documents/sow_housing_tfr.pdf A comprehensive review of housing for pregnant sows]. Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association, Vol. 227, No. 10, 15 November 2005. Accessed 1 August 2012. *Smith, Lewis W. [http://www.ars.usda.gov/is/AR/archive/jun01/form0601.htm "Forum—Observing Swine Behavior To Lower Piglet Mortality"], Agriculture Research Service, United States Department of Agriculture. {{Pigs}} {{Animal rights|state=collapsed}}

{{other uses}} {{Multi| {{essay|date=October 2016}} {{refimprove|date=January 2015}} }} {{russianterm | russian = гла́сность | rusr = glasnost' | literal meaning = publicity }} In the [[Russian language]] the word '''''Glasnost''''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|g|l|æ|z|n|ɒ|s|t}}; {{lang-ru|гла́сность}}, {{IPA-ru|ˈɡɫasnəsʲtʲ|IPA|ru-glasnost.ogg}}) has several general and specific meanings. It has been used in Russian to mean "openness and transparency" since at least the end of the eighteenth century.<ref>{{cite book |language=Russian |title=Словарь Академии Российской. Часть II |year=1790 |publisher= Императорская Академия Наук|location= СПб.|page= 72|url=http://www.runivers.ru/bookreader/book10108/#page/100/mode/1up |accessdate=}}</ref>
In the [[Russian Empire]] of the late-19th century, the term was particularly associated with reforms of the judicial system, ensuring that the press and the public could attend court hearings and that the sentence was read out in public. In the mid-1980s, it was popularised by [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] as a political slogan for increased government transparency in the [[Soviet Union]].
==Historical usage== "For centuries", [[human rights]] activist [[Lyudmila Alexeyeva]] has explained, the word ''glasnost'' has been in the Russian language: "It was in the dictionaries and lawbooks as long as there had been dictionaries and lawbooks. It was an ordinary, hardworking, non-descript word that was used to refer to a process, any process of justice or governance, being conducted in the open."<ref>Alexeyeva, Lyudmila and Paul Goldberg ''The Thaw Generation: Coming of Age in the Post-Stalin Era'', Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press, 1990, pp. 108-109.</ref> In the mid-1960s, however, as Alexeyeva recounts, it acquired a new and topical importance.
==Glasnost in the USSR== ===Glasnost and the dissidents=== On 5 December 1965, a key event in the emergence of the Soviet civil rights movement, often known as the [[Glasnost meeting| Glasnost rally]], took place in Moscow when protesters on Pushkin Square led by [[Alexander Yesenin-Volpin]] demanded access to the closed trial of [[Yuli Daniel| Yuly Daniel]] and [[Andrei Sinyavsky]]. They specifically asked for "glasnost", i.e. the admission of the public, independent observers and foreign journalists, to the trial, something that was required in the newly issued, but not widely available, Code of Criminal Procedure. With a few specified exceptions, Article 111 of the Code stated that judicial hearings in the USSR should be held in public.
Such protests against closed trials continued throughout the post-Stalin era. [[Andrei Sakharov]], famously, did not travel to Oslo to receive his [[Nobel Peace Prize]] because he was standing outside a court building in Vilnius (Lithuania), demanding access to the 1976 trial of [[Sergei Kovalev]], an editor of the ''[[Chronicle of Current Events]]'' and prominent rights activist.<ref>https://chronicleofcurrentevents.net/2016/03/07/38-2-before-the-trials-of-kovalyov-and-tverdokhlebov/</ref>
===Glasnost and Gorbachev=== In 1986, aware of the term's historical and more recent resonance, [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] and his advisers adopted "glasnost" as a political slogan, together with the obscure "[[perestroika]]".
Glasnost was taken to mean increased openness and [[Transparency (social)|transparency]] in government institutions and activities in the [[Soviet Union]] (USSR).<ref>{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Milestones in Glasnost and Perestroyka: Politics and People | publisher = Brookings Institution Press | year = 1991 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8157-3623-1 }}</ref> ''Glasnost'' apparently reflected a commitment to getting Soviet citizens to discuss publicly the problems of their system and seek solutions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/907585907|title=The world transformed : 1945 to the present|last=H.|first=Hunt, Michael|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780199371020|location=|pages=315|oclc=907585907}}</ref> Gorbachev encouraged popular scrutiny and criticism of leaders, as well as a certain level of exposure by the mass media.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/907585907|title=The world transformed : 1945 to the present|last=H.|first=Hunt, Michael|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780199371020|location=|pages=316|oclc=907585907}}</ref> Some critics, especially among legal reformers and dissidents, regarded the Soviet authorities' new slogans as vague and limited alternatives to more basic liberties.
Alexei Simonov, president of the Glasnost Defence Foundation, would define the term as follows: "Glasnost is a tortoise crawling towards Freedom of Speech".<ref>http://www.gdf.ru</ref>
====Various meanings of Gorbachev's "glasnost"==== Between 1986 and 1991, when the USSR attempted and failed to reform itself, glasnost was frequently linked with other generalised concepts such as [[perestroika]] (literally: restructuring or regrouping) and [[Demokratizatsiya (Soviet Union)|demokratizatsiya]] (democratisation). Gorbachev often appealed to glasnost when promoting policies aimed at reducing corruption at the top of the Communist Party and the Soviet government, and moderating the abuse of administrative power in the [[Central Committee]].
The ambiguity of "glasnost" defines the distinctive five-year period (1986–1991) at the end of the USSR's existence. There was decreasing pre-publication and pre-broadcast [[censorship]] and greater [[freedom of information]].
The "Era of Glasnost" saw greater contact between Soviet citizens and the Western world, particularly the [[United States]]: restrictions on travel were loosened for many, allowing increased business and cultural interchange{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}.
====International Relations under Glasnost==== Gorbachev's interpretation of "glasnost" can best be summarized, translated, and explained in English as "openness". While associated with [[freedom of speech]], the main goal of this policy was to make the country's management transparent, and circumvent the narrow circle of bureaucrats who previously exercised complete control of the economy.
Soviet history under Stalin was re-examined; censored literature in the libraries was made more widely available;<ref>[http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/glasnost.htm Glasnost] im sowjetischen Bibliothekswesen (by Peter Bruhn)</ref><ref>А.П. Шикман: ''Совершенно несекретно'' in: Советская библиография, 1988,6 (231), P.3-12</ref> and there was a greater freedom of speech for citizens and openness in the media.
Propaganda about the supposedly higher quality of consumer goods and quality of life in the [[United States]] and [[Western Europe]] began to be transmitted to the Soviet population,<ref name="ScottChapter8">{{cite book|title=Dismantling Utopia: How Information Ended the Soviet Union|last=Shane|first=Scott|publisher=Ivan R. Dee|year=1994|isbn=1-56663-048-7|location=Chicago|pages=212 to 244|chapter=Letting Go of the Leninist Faith|quote=All this degradation and hypocrisy is laid not just at the feet of Stalin but of Lenin and the Revolution that made his rule possible.}}</ref> along with western [[popular culture]].<ref name="ScottChapter7">{{cite book|last=Shane|first=Scott|title=Dismantling Utopia: How Information Ended the Soviet Union|year=1994|publisher=Ivan R. Dee|location=Chicago|isbn=1-56663-048-7|pages=182 to 211|chapter=A Normal Country: The Pop Culture Explosion|quote=...market forces had taken over publishing...}}</ref>
==Glasnost in Russia since 1991==
The outright prohibition of censorship was enshrined in Article 29 of the new 1993 Constitution of the Russian Federation.<ref>[http://www.constitution.ru/search/index.html?cx=partner-pub-7056500280970989%3A2czdvm-pse9&cof=FORID%3A10&ie=windows-1251&q=censorship&sa.x=0&sa.y=0 Constitution of the Russian Federation, 1993, Article 29, point 5]</ref> This did not end attempts by officials to restrict access to information in post-Soviet Russia or pressure by the authorities on media outlets not to publicise or discuss certain events or subjects. Monitoring of the infringement of media rights in the years from 2004 to 2013 would find that instances of censorship were the most commonly reported type of violation.<ref>[http://mediaconflictsinrussia.org/search ''Russia - Conflicts in the Media since 2004, a database. Censorship.'']</ref>
There were also periodic concerns about the extent of glasnost in court proceedings, as restrictions were placed on access to certain cases for the media and for the public
==See also== * [[Glasnost meeting|1965 Glasnost rally]] * [[Democratisation in the Soviet Union|Gorbachev's "Demokratizatsiya"]] * [[Glasnost Bowl]] * ''[[Glasnost The Game]]'' * [[Perestroika| Gorbachev's "Restructuring"]] * [[Uskoreniye| Gorbachev's "Acceleration"]]

W. Norton & Company |location= |isbn=0-393-30735-2 }} *{{cite book |last=Gibbs|first=Joseph |title=Gorbachev's Glasnost: The Soviet Media in the First Phase of Perestroika |year=1999 |publisher=Texas A&M University Press |location= |isbn=0-89096-892-6 }} *{{cite book |last=Horvath|first=Robert |title=The Legacy of Soviet Dissent: Dissidents, democratisation and radical nationalism in Russia |year=2005 |publisher=Routledge Curzon |location=London & New York |isbn=0-415-33320-2 }}

revision.text:
[[File:Remington - A Gander-Pull.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Goose pulling in 19th-century West Virginia, as depicted by [[Frederic Remington]]]]
[[File:Gänsereiten 2010.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Modern goose pulling (using a dead goose) in Germany]]
'''Goose pulling''' (also called '''gander pulling''', '''goose riding''', '''pulling the goose''' or '''goose neck tearing'''<ref name="brooke-hitching">Edward Brooke-Hitching. ''Fox Tossing, Octopus Wrestling, and Other Forgotten Sports'', p.102. Simon and Schuster, 2015. {{ISBN|978-1-4711-4899-6}}</ref>) was a [[blood sport]] practiced in parts of the [[Netherlands]], [[Belgium]], [[England]], and [[North America]] from the 17th to the 19th centuries. It originated in the 12th century in [[Spain]] and was spread around Europe by the [[Tercio | Spanish Third]]. The sport involved fastening a live goose with a well-greased head to a rope or pole that was stretched across a road. A man riding on horseback at a full gallop would attempt to grab the bird by the neck in order to pull the head off.<ref name="Bird">"Dutch". Bird, Thomas E. in ''Encyclopedia of ethnicity and sports in the United States'', eds. Kirsch, George B.; Harris, Othello; Nolte, Claire Elaine. Greenwood Publishing Group, 2000. {{ISBN|978-0-313-29911-7}}</ref> Sometimes a live hare was substituted.<ref name="Vickers">{{cite book|last=Vickers|first=Anita|title=The new nation|page=147|year=2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31264-9}}</ref>
It is still practiced today, using a dead goose, in parts of Belgium and in [[Grevenbicht]] in the Netherlands<ref name="ganstrekken">{{cite news|title=Dierenpartij wil komaf maken met ganstrekken|url=http://demorgen.be/dm/nl/990/Buitenland/article/detail/176081/2008/02/18/Dierenpartij-wil-komaf-maken-met-ganstrekken.dhtml|work=De Morgen Buitenland|date=2008-02-18|accessdate=2010-05-04}}</ref> as part of [[Shrove Tuesday]] and in some towns in Germany as part of the [[Shrove Monday]] celebrations. It is referred to as ''Ganstrekken'' in the Netherlands, ''Gansrijden'' in Belgium and ''Gänsereiten'' in Germany using a dead goose that has been humanely killed by a veterinarian.
==The practice==
=== Spain ===
In [[El Carpio de Tajo]] goose pulling is practised on every July 25th to celebrate the liberation ([[Reconquista]]) from the Arabs in 1141.<ref>[http://www.eickenscheidt-nienhausen.de/300/archiv/14_9.pdf Artikel zum Gänsereiten].</ref> Later, during the [[Francoist Spain|dictatorship of Franco]], the use of live geese was prohibited by a new animal protection law. Instead of geese, ribbons tied to sticks were used, which the riders had to insert into metal rings. When democracy returned to Spain, the use of geese was again allowed.
=== Netherlands ===
Goose pulling is attested in the Netherlands as early as the start of the 17th century; the poet [[Gerbrand Adriaensz Bredero]] referred to it in his 1622 poem ''Boerengeselschap'' ("Company of Peasants"), describing how a party of peasants going to a goose-pulling contest near Amsterdam end up in a brutal brawl, leading to the lesson that it is best for townspeople to stay away from peasant pleasures.<ref>{{cite book|title=Dutch literature in the age of Rembrandt: themes and ideas|last=Schenkeveld|first=Maria A|page=80|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|year=1991|isbn=978-90-272-2216-9}}</ref>
Although the use of live geese was banned in the 1920s, the practice still arouses some controversy. In 2008 the Dutch [[Party for Animals]] (PvdD) proposed that it should be banned; the organisers, Folk Verein Gawstrèkkers Beeg, rejected the proposal, pointing out that there was no question of cruelty to animals because the geese were already dead.<ref name="ganstrekken" />
=== Belgium ===
Belgian goose pulling is accompanied by an elaborate set of customs. The rider who succeeds in pulling off the goose's head is "crowned" as the "king" for one year and given a crown and mantle. At the end of his "king year" the ruling king has to treat his "subjects" to a feast of beer, drinks, cigars and bread pudding or sausages held either at his home or at a local pub. The kings compete with each other to become the "emperor".<ref>{{cite news|title=Het abc van het gansrijden |url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=GP2M7ASP |work=het Nieuwsblad |date=2010-02-13 |accessdate=2010-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611190716/http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=GP2M7ASP |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }}</ref> Children participate as well; in 2008, the children's goose pulling tournament in [[Lillo, Antwerp|Lillo]] near [[Antwerp]] was won by a 14-year-old who won 390 euros and a trip to the [[Plopsaland De Panne|Plopsaland]] theme park.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michaël (14) wint gansrijden voor kinderen |url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleID=HD1UVEJ5_2 |work=het Nieuwsblad |date=2008-08-05 |accessdate=2010-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611190844/http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleID=HD1UVEJ5_2 |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }}</ref>
=== Germany ===
In [[Wattenscheid]] it is believed that the custom was brought by Spanish soldiers who were stationed in 1598 and 1599 during the [[Eighty Years' War]] and later in the [[Thirty Years' War]].<ref>[http://www.donews.de/oldstuff/Archiv/G/Gansereiter/gansereiter.html so Bochum's Stadtarchivar ''Eduard Schulte'' in his study from 6 February 1925, cited by donews.de – Karneval mit den Gänsereitern]</ref>
In some other places of Germany it was forbidden. In [[Dortmund]] and [[Essen]] rattraps are used.
=== United Kingdom ===
The sport appears to have been relatively uncommon in Britain, as all references are to it as a curiosity practiced somewhere else. The 1771 Philip Parsons locates it in "Northern parts of England" and assumes it is unknown in [[Newmarket, Suffolk|Newmarket]] in Southern England. Parsons described how it was carried out in England:
{{quote|In the Northern parts of England it is no unusual diversion, to tie a rope across a street, and let it swing about the distance of ten yards<!--30 feet??--> from the ground. To the middle of this a living cock is tied by the legs. As he swings in the air, a set of young people ride one after another, full speed, under the rope, and rising in the stirrups, catch at the animal's head, which is close clipped and well soaped, in order to elude the grasp. Now he who is able to keep his seat in his saddle, and his hold of the bird's head, so as to carry it off in his hand, bears away the palm, and becomes the noble hero of the day.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parsons|first=Philip|title=Newmarket: or, An essay on the turf|publisher=R. Baldwin and J. Dodsley|year=1771|pages=174–5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7kBAAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22essay%20on%20the%20turf%22%201771&pg=PA174#v=onepage&q=%22essay%20on%20the%20turf%22%201771&f=false}}</ref>}}
In a satirical letter to ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' in 1845 it is regarded as a barbarous practice known only to the bloodthirsty Spaniards, like [[bull-fighting]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wyEIAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA121&dq=goose+pulling+England&hl=en&ei=cpLhS57qC835-AbP69jwDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=goose%20pulling%20England&f=false|title=Sports for Queens|work=Punch|date=1845|volume=9}}</ref>
The serious work ''Observations on the popular antiquities of Great Britain'', of 1849, calls it "Goose-riding" and says it has been "practiced in [[Derbyshire]] within the memory of persons now living", and that the [[antiquary]] [[Francis Douce]] (1757–1834) had a friend who remembered it "when young" in [[Edinburgh]] in [[Scotland]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Observations on the popular antiquities of Great Britain: chiefly illustrating the origin of our vulgar and provincial customs, ceremonies, and superstitions, Volume 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rDcFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA419&dq=goose+pulling+England&hl=en&ei=1I7hS_iAEILK-Qbw8tj1Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q&f=false|author1=Brand, John|author2=Ellis, Sir Henry|author3=Halliwell-Phillipps, James Orchard|publisher=Bohn|location=London|year=1849}}</ref>
From these references it would appear to have died out in Britain by the end of the 18th century.
=== United States ===
The Dutch settlers of North America brought it to their colony of [[New Netherland]] and from there it was transmitted to English-speaking Americans. Goose-pulling was taken up by those at the lower levels in American society,<ref name="Vickers" /> though it could attract the interest of all social strata. In the pre-[[American Civil War|Civil War]] South, slaves and whites competed alongside each other in goose-pulling contests watched by "all who walk in the fashionable circles."<ref name="Parsons">{{cite book|last=Parsons|first=Charles Grandison|title=Inside view of slavery: or A tour among the planters|pages=136–7|publisher=John P. Jewett and Co|year=1855}}</ref> Charles Grandison Parsons described the course of one such contest held in [[Milledgeville, Georgia]] in the 1850s:
{{quote|At the appointed time, rude whisky tents, and festive seats, and shades, were prepared around the "pulling course;" and thousands of spectators – ladies as well as gentlemen, the elite as well as the vulgar – assembled to engage in or witness the favorite sport...
Tickets were issued by the proprietor of the gander, at fifty cents each, to all gentlemen present who wished for them, and they entered their names as "pullers". The pullers were to start about ten rods [about 50 m / 165 ft] from the gander, on horseback, riding at full speed, and as they passed along under the gander, they had the privilege of pulling off his head – which would entitle them to the additional privilege of eating him...
One entered the list – a "gentleman of property and standing" – and dashed over the course. The poor gander – seeming quite resigned to his fate, or not comprehending his danger, and not knowing how to "dodge" – had his neck seized by the first rider; but being well oiled, and his head so small, and his strength not yet exhausted, he slipped his head through the puller's hand without suffering much from the twist... After this he kept a sharp look out, and many pullers passed by without being able to grapple his neck. The game went on, and the pullers increased, till the jaded gander could elude their grasp no longer. An old Cracker – with a sandpaper glove on – pulled off his head at last, amid the shouts of a wondering host of intoxicated competitors.<ref name="Parsons" />}}
The prizes of a goose-pulling contest were trivial – often the dead bird itself, other times contributions from the audience or rounds of drinks. The main draw of such contests for the spectators was the betting on the competitors, sometimes for money or more often for alcoholic drinks.<ref name="Vickers" /> One contemporary observer commented that "the whoopin', and hollerin', and screamin', and bettin', and excitement, beats all; there ain't hardly no sport equal to it."<ref>{{cite book|last=Bartlett|first=John Russell|title=Dictionary of Americanisms: A glossary of words and phrases usually regarded as peculiar to the United States|pages=166–7|publisher=Little, Brown, and Company|year=1859}}</ref> Goose-pulling contests were often held on [[Shrove Tuesday]] and [[Easter Monday]], with competitors "engaged in this sport not just for its excitement but also to prove they were "real men," physically strong, brave, competitive and willing to take risks."<ref>{{cite book|last=Pleck|first=Elizabeth Hafkin|title=Celebrating the family: ethnicity, consumer culture, and family rituals|page=76|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-674-00279-1}}</ref>
Unlike some other contemporary blood sports, goose pulling was often frowned upon. In [[New Amsterdam]] (modern [[New York (state)|New York]]) in 1656, [[Director-General of New Netherland|Director General]] [[Pieter Stuyvesant]] issued ordinances against goose pulling, calling it "unprofitable, heathenish and pernicious."<ref name="Bird" /> Many contemporary writers professed disgust at the sport; an anonymous reviewer in the ''[[Southern Literary Messenger]]'', writing in 1836, described goose pulling as "a piece of unprincipled barbarity not infrequently practised in the South and West."<ref>Anonymous, review of ''Georgia Scenes''. ''Southern Literary Messenger'', p. 289, vol. II, no. 4. March 1836</ref> William Gilmore Simms described it as "one of those sports which a cunning devil has contrived to gratify a human beast. It appeals to his skill, his agility, and strength; and is therefore in some degree grateful to his pride; but, as it exercises these qualities at the expense of his humanity, it is only a medium by which his better qualities are employed as agents for his worser nature."<ref name="Simms" />
The sport was challenging, as the oiling of the goose's neck made it difficult to retain a grip on it, and the bird's flailing made it difficult to target in the first place. Sometimes the organisers would add an extra element of difficulty; one writer describing an event in the American South witnessed "a nigger, with a long whip in hand ... stationed on a stump, about two rods [10 m / 32 ft] from the gander, with orders to strike the horse of the puller as he passed by."<ref>p. 157. INSIDE VIEW OF SLAVERY: OR A TOUR AMONG THE PLANTERS, by C.G. PARSONS, 1855.</ref> The reaction of the startled horse would make it even more difficult for the puller to grab the goose as he went by. Many riders missed altogether; others broke the goose's neck without snapping off the head.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forret|first=Jeff|title=Race relations at the margins: slaves and poor whites in the antebellum Southern countryside|page=62|publisher=LSU Press|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8071-3145-9}}</ref> The American poet and novelist [[William Gilmore Simms]] wrote that
{{quote|It is only the experienced horseman, and the experienced sportsman, who can possibly succeed in the endeavor. Young beginners, who look on the achievement as rather easy, are constantly baffled; many find it impossible to keep the track; many lose the saddle, and even where they succeed in passing beneath the saplings without disaster, they either fail altogether in grasping the goose, which keeps a constant fluttering and screaming; or, they find it impossible to retain their grasp, at full speed, upon the greasy and eel-like neck and head which they have seized.<ref name="Simms">{{cite book|title=As good as a comedy: or, The Tennesseean's story|last=Simms|first=William Gilmore|page=115|publisher=A. Hart|year=1852}}</ref>}}
Goose-pulling largely died out in the United States after the Civil War, though it was still occasionally practised in parts of the South as late as the 1870s; a local newspaper in [[Osceola, Arkansas]] reported of an 1870s picnic that "after eats, gander-pulling was engaged in. Mr. W.P. Hale succeeded in pulling in twain the gander's breathing apparatus, after which dancing was resumed."<ref>{{cite book|last=Cochran|first=Robert|title=Our own sweet sounds: a celebration of popular music in Arkansas|page=17|year=2005|publisher=University of Arkansas Press|isbn=978-1-55728-793-9}}</ref>
A variant called "rooster pulling" has survived in [[New Mexico]] for some time. A rooster was buried in the sand up to its neck, and riders would try to pull it up as they rode past. This was later done with bottles buried in the sand. "Rooster racing in the Hispanic villages of northern New Mexico exists only in the history books and in the minds of a few men and women who ... still recall the popular sport of yesteryear".<ref>{{cite book|page=94|last=Garcia|first=Nasario|title=Grandma's Santo on Its Head: Stories of Days Gone By in Hispanic Villages of New Mexico|year=2013|location=Albuquerque|publisher=University of New Mexico Press}}</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading==
* George Johnson, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/24/us/in-new-mexico-an-ancient-rite-or-a-blood-sport.html "In New Mexico, An Ancient Rite or a Blood Sport?"] ''New York Times,'' June 24, 1995. * Marc Simmons, [http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/trail_dust/trail-dust-history-of-rooster-pulls-traces-to-spain/article_278919f9-823e-570a-b59f-1895619b36d9.html "Trail Dust: History of Rooster Pulls Traces to Spain,"] ''Santa Fe New Mexican,'' Nov. 15, 2013. * "[https://books.google.com/books?id=JQEfAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22gander%20pulling%22&lr&num=50&as_brr=3&pg=PA110#v=onepage&q=%22gander%20pulling%22&f=false The Gander Pulling]", in ''Georgia scenes, characters, incidents, &c., in the first half century of the Republic'' (Augustus Baldwin Longstreet, 1859). Satirical account of a goose-pulling contest held in Georgia in 1798.
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=heZVmRXSP9s Goose pulling in Nijverseel, Belgium, June 2007] (video) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kP9CHUcwlLs "De Vrije Gans" (The Free Goose) goose-pulling contest, Berendrecht, Belgium, April 2008] (video)
