revision.text:
[[File:Jesús en casa de Anás Museo del Prado José de Madrazo.jpg|thumb|300px|Jesus about to be struck in front of the High Priest [[Annas]], as in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#18:22|John 18:22]], depicted by [[José de Madrazo|Madrazo]], 1803]] {{Death of Jesus}} {{Gospel Jesus}}
In the New Testament, the '''Sanhedrin trial of Jesus''' refers to the trial of [[Jesus]] before the [[Sanhedrin]] (a Jewish judicial body) following [[Arrest of Jesus|his arrest]] in [[Jerusalem in Christianity|Jerusalem]] and prior to his [[Pilate's court|dispensation by Pontius Pilate]]. It is an event reported by all four [[canonical gospels]] of the [[New Testament]], although [[John's Gospel]] does not explicitly mention a Sanhedrin trial in this context.<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|14:53–65|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Matthew|26:57–68|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Luke|22:63–71|NIV}}, and {{bibleverse||John|18:12–24|NIV}}</ref>
Jesus is generally quiet, does not mount a defense, and rarely responds to the accusations, but is condemned by the Jewish authorities when he will not deny that he is the [[Son of God]]. The Jewish leaders then take Jesus to [[Pontius Pilate]], the governor of [[Roman Judaea]], and ask that he be tried for claiming to be the [[Jesus, King of the Jews|King of the Jews]].
The trial as depicted in the [[Synoptic Gospels]] is temporally placed informally on Thursday night and then again formally on Friday morning. Although some believe this informally happened Wednesday night and then again finally on Thursday morning, with him eventually being taken off the cross Thursday night, being the beginning of the Jews 'day of preparation', according to account in the [[Gospel of John|Gospel of John.]]
==Trial== In the narrative of all the canonical gospels, after the [[Kiss of Judas|betrayal]] and arrest of Jesus, he is taken to the Sanhedrin. From a historical perspective, in the era in which the narrative is set, the Sanhedrin body was an ''[[ad hoc]]'' gathering, rather than a fixed court.<ref>[[Raymond E. Brown|Brown, Raymond E.]] ''An Introduction to the New Testament'' Doubleday 1997 {{ISBN|0-385-24767-2}}, p. 146.</ref> The portrayal of the Sanhedrin body contradicts that of Jewish tradition and texts, which portray the Sanhedrin to be an established court based in Jerusalem with strict guidelines on how to function<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/the-sanhedrin|title=The Sanhedrin|website=www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-19}}</ref>. An entire [[Sanhedrin (tractate)|tractate]] explaining the Sanhedrin and its laws can be found in both the [[Mishnah|Mishna]] and [[Gemara]].
In the four canonical gospels, Jesus was tried and condemned by a majority of the Sanhedrin members, although at least one member, [[Joseph of Arimathea]], dissented from this decision.<ref>Luke 23:50-51</ref> Jesus was [[Mocking of Jesus|mocked]] and beaten and condemned for making the claim of being the Son of God.<ref name=Craig396 >''Jesus and the Gospels: An Introduction and Survey'' by Craig L. Blomberg 2009 {{ISBN|0-8054-4482-3}} pages 396-400</ref><ref name=CEvans487 >''The Bible Knowledge Background Commentary: Matthew-Luke, Volume 1'' by Craig A. Evans 2003 {{ISBN|0-7814-3868-3}} page 487-500</ref><ref name=Holman608 >''Holman Concise Bible Dictionary'' 2011 {{ISBN|0-8054-9548-7}} pages 608-609</ref> Although the Gospel accounts vary with respect to some of the details, they agree on the general character and overall structure of the trials of Jesus.<ref name=GBromiley1050 >''The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'' by Geoffrey W. Bromiley 1982 {{ISBN|0-8028-3782-4}} pages 1050-1052</ref>
[[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#26:57|Matthew 26:57]] states that Jesus was taken to the house of [[Caiaphas]] the [[High Priest]], where the scribes and the elders were gathered together. [[Matthew 27:1]] adds that, the next morning, the priests held another meeting. [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#14:53|Mark 14:53]] states that Jesus was taken that night "to the high priest" (without naming the priest), where all the chief priests and the elders gathered, and [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#15:1|Mark 15:1]] adds that another consultation was held among the priests the next morning. [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:54|Luke 22:54]] states that Jesus was taken to "the high priest's house" (without naming the priest), where he was mocked and beaten that night. It is added in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:66|22:66]] that, "as soon as it was day", the chief priests and scribes gathered together and led Jesus away into their council.<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 />
In [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#18:12|John 18:12-14]], however, Jesus is first taken to [[Annas]], the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was the [[List of High Priests of Israel|high priest]] at that time. Annas is believed to have been the former high priest, and it appears that Caiaphas sought Annas' confirmation of Caiaphas' actions. In [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#18:28|18:24]], Jesus is sent from Annas to Caiaphas the high priest, and [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#18:28|18:28]] states that, in the morning, Jesus was led from Caiaphas to [[Pontius Pilate]] in the [[Praetorium#Biblical reference|Praetorium]].<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 />
In all four Gospel accounts, the trial of Jesus before the priests and scribes is interleaved with the [[Denial of Peter]] narrative, where [[Apostle Peter]], who has followed Jesus, denies knowing him three times.<ref name=Bromiley105 >''Theological dictionary of the New Testament'' by Gerhard Kittel, Geoffrey William Bromiley, Gerhard Friedrich 1980 {{ISBN|0-8028-2248-7}} page 105</ref> [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:61|Luke 22:61]] states that as Jesus was bound and standing at the priest's house Peter was in the courtyard. Jesus "turned and looked straight at him", and Peter remembered the words Jesus had spoken to him: "Before the [[rooster]] crows today, you will disown me three times."<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 /><ref name=Bromiley105 />
In the Gospel accounts, Jesus speaks very little, and gives very infrequent and indirect answers to the questions of the priests, prompting an officer to slap him. In [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#26:62|Matthew 26:62]], the lack of response from Jesus prompts the high priest to ask him: "Answerest thou nothing?" In the Gospel accounts, the men that hold Jesus at the high priest's house mock, blindfold, insult and beat him, at times slapping him and asking him to guess who had hit him that time.<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 /><ref>[[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#26:67|Matthew 26:67]] [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#14:65|Mark 14:65]] [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:63|Luke 22:63-65]] [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#18:22|John 18:22]]</ref>
[[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#14:55|Mark 14:55–59]] states that the chief priests had sought witness against Jesus to put him to death but did not find any, so they arranged false witness against him, but their witnesses did not agree together. [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#14:61|Mark 14:61]] states that the high priest then asked Jesus: "Art thou the [[Christ]], the Son of the Blessed?" And Jesus said "I am", at which point the high priest tore his own robe in anger and accused Jesus of blasphemy. In [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#26:63|Matthew 26:63]], the high priest asks: "tell us whether you are the Christ, the Son of God." Jesus responds "You have said it", prompting the High Priest to tear his own robe,<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 /> breaking [[Mosaic Law]] ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Leviticus#21:10|Leviticus 21:10]]).
In [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:67|Luke 22:67]], Jesus is asked: "If thou art the Christ, tell us. But he said unto them, If I tell you, ye will not believe". But, in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#22:70|22:70]], when asked "Are you then the Son of God?", Jesus answers "You say that I am", affirming the title Son of God.<ref>''Luke's presentation of Jesus: a christology'' by Robert F. O'Toole 2004 {{ISBN|88-7653-625-6}} page 166</ref> At that point, the priests say "What further need have we of witness? for we ourselves have heard from his own mouth", and they decide to condemn Jesus.<ref name=Craig396 /><ref name=CEvans487 /><ref name=Holman608 />
Thereafter, in [[Pilate's Court]], the Jewish elders ask Pontius Pilate to judge and condemn Jesus, accusing him of claiming to be the [[Jesus, King of the Jews|King of the Jews]]. Such a claim would be considered treasonous, being a direct challenge to the Roman authorities.<ref name=Holman608 />
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Mattias Stom, Christ before Caiaphas.jpg|[[Matthias Stom]]'s depiction of Jesus before [[Caiaphas]], c. 1630. File:Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn 012.jpg|[[Rembrandt]]'s 1660 depiction of ''[[Denial of Peter|Peter's Denial]]''. Jesus, in the upper right hand corner, is at the high priest's house, his hands bound behind him, and turns to look at Peter. </gallery>
==See also== {{Portal|Bible}} * [[Chronology of Jesus]] * [[Jesus at Herod's court]] * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] * [[Passion of Jesus]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Brown, Raymond E., et al. ''The New Jerome Biblical Commentary''. Prentice Hall, 1990, {{ISBN|0-13-614934-0}}. * [[John Dominic Crossan|Crossan, Dominic]], ''Who Killed Jesus? Exposing the Roots of Anti-Semitism in the Gospel Story of the Death of Jesus'', 1995, {{ISBN|0-06-061480-3}},
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Caiaphas}}
{{Jesus footer}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sanhedrin Trial Of Jesus}} [[Category:Judaism-related controversies]] [[Category:Passion of Jesus]] [[Category:Judaism in the New Testament]] [[Category:Stations of the Cross]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Sayidaty | image_file = Sayidaty (magazine).jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = [[Mohammed Fahad Al-Harthi]] | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 143.351 (2009) | category = [[Women's magazine]] | company = [[Saudi Research and Marketing Group]] | publisher = Saudi Research and Publishing Company | firstdate = {{Start date and age|1981|3|1|df=yes}} | country = Saudi Arabia | language = Arabic and English | website =[http://sayidaty.net/ Sayidaty website] | issn = }}
'''''Sayidaty''''' ([[Arabic]] سيدتي ''Sayyidatī'', meaning ''My Lady'' in English)<ref>{{cite book|author=Andrew Hammond|title=Popular Culture in the Arab World: Arts, Politics, and the Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O06bOHRW7s8C&pg=PA237|accessdate=5 September 2014|year=2007|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|isbn=978-977-416-054-7|page=251}}</ref> is a weekly Arabic and a monthly English [[List of women's magazines|women's magazine]] published in both [[Dubai]] and [[Beirut]] and distributed throughout [[the Middle East]], [[North Africa]], [[Europe]] and [[The U.S.|America]].<ref name=gih>{{cite web|title=Saudi Research and Marketing Group|url=http://mec.biz/term/uploads/SRMG_03112009.pdf|work=Global Investment House|accessdate=28 May 2012|date=November 2009}}</ref>
==History== ''Sayidaty'' was founded by [[Hisham Hafiz]] and his brother Muhammed Hafiz in London.<ref name=hisham>{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.hishamalihafiz.com/bio.htm|publisher=Hisham Ali Hafiz|accessdate=22 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722005217/http://www.hishamalihafiz.com/bio.htm|archivedate=22 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Later, it was founded in [[Riyadh]] in March 1981.<ref name=srpc>{{cite web|title=Magazines|url=http://www.srpc.com/en/magazines|publisher=SRPC|accessdate=21 May 2012}}</ref> The magazine was relocated from London to [[Dubai]] in 2005.<ref name=anews06>{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Mushtak|title=SRMG: Taking the Publishing Sector in Mideast by Storm|url=http://archive.arabnews.com/?page=15&section=0&article=89604&d=8&m=6&y=2012|accessdate=8 June 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=6 December 2006}}</ref> The English edition was launched in 2007.<ref name="eng1">(24 December 2007). [http://www.ameinfo.com/142708.html First issue of Sayidaty magazine in English releases in Dubai], ''AMEinfo'', Retrieved 13 December 2010</ref>
Hala Al Nasser, who is current editor-in-chief of ''[[Rotana Magazine]]'', is one of the magazine's former editors.<ref name=sakr>{{cite journal|last=Sakr|first=Naomi|authorlink=Naomi Sakr|title=Women and Media in Saudi Arabia: Rhetoric, Reductionism and Realities|journal=British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies|year=2008|volume=35|issue=3|pages=385–404|doi=10.1080/13530190802525197}}</ref> [[Mohammed Fahad Al-Harthi]] has been the editor-in-chief of the magazine since 2004.<ref name=carabia>{{cite news|title=Jobs Shuffle at Saudi Research & Media Group|url=http://xrdarabia.org/2013/01/05/jobs-shuffle-at-saudi-research-media-group/|accessdate=9 February 2013|newspaper=Crossroads Arabia|date=5 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=wan>{{cite web|title=Mohammed Fahad Alharthi|url=http://www.wan-ifra.org/events/speakers/mohammed-fahad-alharthi|publisher=WAN IFRA|accessdate=26 February 2013}}</ref> As of 2010 [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] journalist Hadia Said was the cultural editor of the magazine.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Houda Trabelsi|title=Electronic media can spur Arab press reform, magazine editor says|url=http://magharebia.com/en_GB/articles/awi/features/2010/05/07/feature-02|work=Magharebia|accessdate=5 September 2014|location=Tunis|date=7 May 2010}}</ref>
==Ownership== ''Sayidaty'' is one of the magazines published by Saudi Research and Publishing Company, a subsidiary of [[Saudi Research and Marketing Group |Saudi Research and Marketing Group (SRMG)]].<ref name=mabout>{{cite web|title=Al Jamila Fact Sheet|url=http://www.magazinesabout.co.uk/magazines/view/Al+Jamila|publisher=Magazines About|accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> SRMG also owns other magazines such as ''[[Al Jamila]]'', ''[[The Majalla]]'', ''Bassim'', ''Urdu Magazine'' and ''[[Hia (magazine)|Hia]]'' as well as newspapers such as ''[[Arab News]]'', ''[[Al Eqtisadiah]]'', ''[[Urdu News]]'' and ''[[Asharq al Awsat]]''.<ref name=mepa>{{cite journal|title=Medıa personalıty of the year; AMF honours Saudı Prınce Faısal|journal=MEPA Monthly Bulletin|date=March 2009|volume=31|issue=31|url=http://www.mepa.cc/Pdf/en/mb_march2009.pdf|accessdate=28 May 2012}}</ref>
==Contents== ''Sayidaty'', the first and only Pan Arab women weekly, provides professional and quality reading, making it the most powerful advertising vehicle among women's magazine in Saudi Arabia and the [[Persian Gulf]] region.<ref name=publ>{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia|url=http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/italy/Files/ME_portfolio_01.pdf|work=Publicitas|accessdate=8 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202073858/http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/italy/Files/ME_portfolio_01.pdf|archivedate=2 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The magazine mostly covers a wide range of topics favoured by the modern Arab women, from beauty and fashion to social and family life.<ref name=gih/><ref name=sppc>{{cite web|title=Publications of SPPC|url=http://www.sppc.com.sa/Templates/SRMG/InternalTemplate.aspx?PostingId=276|publisher=Saudi Research and Marketing Group|accessdate=28 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116083752/http://www.sppc.com.sa/Templates/SRMG/InternalTemplate.aspx?PostingId=276|archivedate=16 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2013 it was expanded to cover two new sections: one on [[human behavior]], and another for [[teenagers]] and [[college students]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sayidaty New look|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?no_cache=1&rss=true&newsid=105196&title=Middle-East%3A-Sayidaty-New-look#.VGi111esUX4|accessdate=16 November 2014|work=Publicitas|date=19 June 2014}}</ref>
==Target readership and circulation== The magazine is said to target primarily families, focusing on conscious housewives.<ref name=srpc/> ''Sayidaty'', along with ''[[Al Yamamah]]'' and ''[[The Majalla]]'', is among popular magazines in Saudi Arabia.<ref name=saudinet>{{cite web|title=Saudi Arabia - Marketing and Sales Strategy|url=http://the-saudi.net/business-center/marketing_and_sales_strategy.htm|work=The Saudi Network|accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref>
The circulation of the magazine at the end of the 1990s was 140,000 copies per issue.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alterman|first=Jon B.|title=New Media New Politics?|journal=The Washington Institute|year=1998|volume=48|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PolicyPaper48.pdf|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> In April 2014, its online version received 39 million hits according to the reports by the editor-in-chief.<ref>{{cite news|author=K. T. Abduraab|title=Sayidaty soars to 39 million pageviews|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/578566|accessdate=8 October 2014|work=Arab News|date=29 May 2014}}</ref>
==See also== [[List of magazines in Saudi Arabia]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}}

page.title: The Diary of Anne Frank (radio play)

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl''''' is an original [[radio play]] by author [[Meyer Levin]] (1905–1981). It was adapted from Levin’s original stage dramatization of the same name, adapted from ''[[The Diary of a Young Girl]]'', [[Anne Frank]]'s diary. It aired on [[CBS Radio|CBS]] on September 18, 1952, the eve of [[Rosh Hashanah]], to critical acclaim, and again in November 1952.<ref>{{cite web|title=Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center at Boston University|url=http://www.bu.edu/phpbin/search/?t=gotlieb&col=gotlieb&dir=0&maps=0&q=Meyer+Levin&Search=Search}}</ref>
==Meyer Levin== Author Meyer Levin was born in 1905 to Jewish immigrants in [[Chicago]]. He began a [[journalism]] career at the age of 16 when he started reporting for the ''[[Chicago Daily News]]''. In 1943 Levin was based in [[London]] as a [[war correspondent]]. He followed the stories of American Jewish soldiers and Germany’s genocidal campaign. Levin was one of the first American journalists to enter a work camp, [[Ohrdruf]], then Bergen-Belsen, [[Dachau]], and more. He suffered tremendous guilt as witness to the atrocities and wrote of his inability to tell the story of the Jews of Europe. That changed when he encountered ''The Diary of Anne Frank'', the first personal diary to emerge from the war. Levin wrote to [[Otto Frank]] and met with him before leaving Europe, inquiring into the American publication and dramatic rights. He was the first to see the dramatic potential of the Diary. <ref name="In Search">{{cite book|last=Levin|first=Meyer|title=In Search|year=1950|publisher=Authors Press|location=Paris, France|pages=524}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Anne Frank Fonds|url=http://www.annefrank.ch/}}</ref>
==The Reappearance== Producer [[Jennifer Strome]] discovered the Radio Play script in 1999 while researching Levin’s life story. She met a member of Levin’s family and was captivated by Levin’s history with the ''Diary of Anne Frank'' stage play. She contacted Levin’s son Mikael Levin who introduced her to his mother, French author [[Tereska Torres]], and to Levin’s vast collection of books and films.
With permission from Torres, Strome began her research in earnest at the Howard Gotleib Archival Research Center of rare book and manuscript collections at [[Boston University]]. More than 50 boxes of personal letters, trial transcripts, and articles belonging to Meyer Levin were made available. It was there that she came across Levin’s original, annotated script for the Radio Play, a document Levin’s family had never seen. It is a historical piece of literature that had fallen into obscurity after what appeared as a controversy between Levin and Otto Frank.
Strome's effort to restore Levin's radio play as part of Anne Frank's legacy of dramatic adaptations resulted in a North American Educational Initiative, [http://annefrankunites.org annefrankunites.org], as a contribution to the fight against intolerance. Strome was authorized by the Anne Frank Fonds, Basel Switzerland ([http://AnneFrank.ch AnneFrank.ch]) to provide the materials with Limited Use July 15th 2013-2015.
==2009 Live Performance == On September 14, 2009, Strome produced a private, live performance of Levin’s Radio Play at the [[Museum of Jewish Heritage]]--A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in NYC. It was the first time the play was heard since its original air date in 1952. This performance marks the first time that the [[Anne Frank Fonds]] in Basel, Switzerland, acknowledged Meyer Levin’s work on the Diary. The Museum performance was followed by a panel discussion moderated by Neil Baldwin, PhD and featuring author Cynthia Ozick and Strome.
'''Actors'''
[[Jonathan Hogan]] (Otto Frank)
Sara Kapner (Anne Frank)
Lori Wilner (Mrs. Frank)
Jessica Dean (Margot)
Mary Rasmussen (Miep/Lies)
[[Stuart Zagnit]] (Mr. Van Daan)
Cberyl Stern (Mrs. Van Daan)
Macleod Andrews (Peter Van Daan)
Andy Prosky (Announcer/Koophius/Dussel)
'''Production'''
composer/musical director: Bob Magnuson
==2012 Podcast== On September 15, 2012 Strome produced and directed a free On Demand podcast of the radio play to commemorate the 60th anniversary of its original and only CBS broadcast in 1952.
'''Actors'''
Bruce Nozick (announcer, Mr. Van Daan, Albert Dussel)
[[Tara Platt]] (Miep, Margot)
Rick Zieff (Otto Frank)
[[Tasia Valenza]] (Mrs. Frank)
Justine Huxley (Anne)
Katie Zieff (Lies)
Tracy Pattin (Mrs. Van Daan)
[[Yuri Lowenthal]] (Peter Van Daan, Koophuis)
'''Production'''
Composer/Musician: Bob Magnuson
Technical director/audio engineer: Mark Holden

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Biographies|date=January 2010}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2010}} {{cleanup|date=January 2010}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} }} '''Tim Soar''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[fashion designer]], [[graphic designer]], [[event planner]] and [[DJ]]. ==Career== Soar began his creative career working with designer [[Neville Brody]] on an interiors project POST Design. This was followed by independent practice as a graphic designer, and then in the design company STAC collaborating with photographer [[Andrew Catlin]]. His work was focussed in music, producing artwork for numerous international record sleeves, publications and campaigns. ==Career as a DJ== While working with Neville Brody, Soar became involved in the music industry and began working as a DJ. Soar had residencies at a number of venues and clubs across London. He was also involved in the writing and arrangement of [[23 Skidoo (band)|23 Skidoo]]'s song ''Just Like Everybody''. He was also part of the band called Toll, which released the album ''Christ Knows'' in 2006. ==Design label== In 2005, Soar launched the Tim Soar design label and this was described as “really well-made menswear that mixes minimalism, sportswear, tailoring, and unusual fabrications.”{{Cite web|url=http://londonfashionweek.co.uk/designers_profile.aspx?DesignerID=1162|title=London Fashion Week - Tim Soar|website=londonfashionweek.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} In an interview, Soar described his foray from music to fashion design with these words:
I felt that I had something to say about modern menswear and that it was time to move on from the flippant to something more serious. I was tired of seeing gimmicky menswear that was badly made and did not fit correctly. I set out to produce clothes that are a synthesis of minimalism and the avant garde made to the highest possible standards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.notjustalabel.com/designer/soar|title=Soar {{!}} NOT JUST A LABEL|website=www.notjustalabel.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}
The first collection was presented by the London-based B-Store, the second collection by [[Liberty (department store)|Liberty]], and has continued with packed shows at each [[London Fashion Week]] since Spring/Summer 09. His women's wear line debuted in 2011 with a capsule collection for Browns 24. Soar told [[Vogue (British magazine)|British Vogue]] that the concept is womenswear for boyish women.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/tim-soar-launches-womenswear|title=Girls Who Like Boys|last=Alexander|first=Ella|access-date=2018-07-04}} Soar's collections are now available in numerous countries worldwide. ==Music Concrete== Soar is also creative head of Music Concrete, a music consultancy that was established in 1987. It initially catered to the boutique hotel market but has since expanded into launches, fashion, and events.{{Cite web|url=http://musicconcrete.com/about-music-consultancy/|title=Music Concrete: Music consultant for hotels, spas and bars|website=musicconcrete.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-04}} He has worked with many of the leading UK and international fashion designers and design houses, including [[Donna Karen]] [[Prada]], [[Ralph Lauren]], [[Levi's]], [[Fendi]], [[LVMH]], Mathew Williamson, Fendi and Adidas. Through Music Concrete, Soar also collaborated with luxury hotels groups including Schrager Hotels, St. Martin's Lane Hotel, Sanderson, Columbus and Great Eastern. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.soar-london.com/news Tim Soar news] * [http://www.soar-london.com/press Press Articles] * [http://www.londonfashionweek.co.uk/designer_profile.aspx?DesignerID=1162 London Fashion Week Profile] * [http://www.selectism.com/news/2009/08/24/tim-soar-springsummer-2010-preview/ Selectism Review] * [http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/full-length-photos/id,8512 Vogue story] * [http://en.sevenload.com/shows/London-Fashion-Week/episodes/7REIq9A-Tim-Soar-backstage-interview-London-Fashion-Week Interview] * [http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/gq-blogs/fashion-shows/entries/090924-tim-soar-springsummer-2010-catwalk.aspx GQ Magazine] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soar, Tim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English fashion designers]] [[Category:English DJs]] [[Category:Event planners]]

{{redirect-multi|2|Lixil Cup|Microsoft Cup|the Soviet Union association football championship|Soviet Top League}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox rugby league cup |name=Top League Champions |logo= |pixels= |sport= [[Rugby union|Rugby union football]] |inaugural= [[2003–04 Top League#Cup|2004]] |country= [[Japan]] |most_champs= [[Toshiba Brave Lupus]] &
[[Suntory Sungoliath]] (5 titles each) |champion= [[Suntory Sungoliath]] (5th title)
([[2017–18 Top League#Cup|2018]]) |season= |website = [http://www.top-league.jp www.top-league.jp] }} [[File:Lixil Cup presentation 2016.jpg|right|thumb|263px|[[Yoshiaki Fujimori]] presents the 2016 Lixil Cup trophy to Panasonic captain [[Shota Horie]].]] The '''Top League Championship''' is Japan's highest-level knockout tournament for [[rugby union]] clubs. Held annually, the leading teams from the [[Top League]] regular season qualify for the playoffs to decide the Cup title. From 2018 onward, the All-Japan Rugby Football Championship has doubled as the Top League Championship Cup. Previously, teams competed for the Lixil Cup, from 2014 to 2016, and Microsoft Cup (prior to 2009). The Top League competition is a Japanese industrial league that presently consists of sixteen teams, all owned by major companies. {{toc level|3}} Initially sponsored by [[Microsoft Japan]], the knockout tournament was first contested by the top eight teams from the Top League in 2004. It was considered a separate competition to the Top League for the first three seasons but was officially integrated for the 2006–07 season. The number of teams was also cut to four to give a format of two semi-finals and a final, and from that time onward until the 2016–17 season the winner of the knockout cup was recognised as the Top League champion. There were no title-play-offs in 2016–17, and the team on top of the league after the round-robin stage won the Top League title. ==Overall== Summary totals for all Top League championships up to and including 2018: {{Aligned table | class = wikitable sortable nowrap |style=border:1; cellpadding:4; |row1header = y | cols = 5 | colstyle= text-align:center; |colwidth= 9.5em | col1style= text-align:left; |col1width= 8.5em | row1style=font-size:95%; | '''Team''' | '''Championships''' | '''Runners-up''' | '''Semi-final losses''' | '''Premierships''' | [[File:Toshibabravelupus.png|18px]] [[Toshiba Brave Lupus]] |5 |3|4 |5 | [[File:Suntorycolours.png|18px]] [[Suntory Sungoliath]] |5 |3|{{pad|0.1em}}2+|3 | [[File:PanasonicWildKnights.png|18px]] [[Panasonic Wild Knights]]1 |4 |5|{{pad|0.1em}}3^|5 | [[File:Kobesteelers.png|18px]] [[Kobelco Steelers]] | {{pad|0.1em}}1*|0|{{pad|0.1em}}5^|3 | [[File:Yamahajubilo.png|18px]] [[Yamaha Júbilo]] |0 |3|{{pad|0.1em}}2+|0 | [[File:Kubotaspears.png|18px]] [[Kubota Spears]] |0 |1|1 |0 | [[File:Toyotaverblitz.png|18px]] [[Toyota Verblitz]] |0 |0|6 |0 | [[File:NECgreenrockets.png|18px]] [[NEC Green Rockets]] | {{pad|0.1em}}0*|0|2 |0 }} '''Notes:''' {{pad|1em}}1{{pad|0.1em}}The Panasonic Wild Knights summary includes results for the Sanyo Wild Knights from 2003–2012.
{{pad|1em}}*{{pad|0.1em}}NEC won the 2004 Microsoft Cup but Kobe Steel was the Top League champion. These were separate competitions prior to 2007.
{{pad|1em}}^{{pad|0.1em}}The 2004 Kobe Steel and Sanyo (Panasonic) semi-final appearances are included, although that cup was not part of the championship.
{{pad|1em}}+{{pad|0.01em}}Yamaha was 3rd and Suntory 4th in the 2003–04 Top League championship, but these results are not counted as semi-final appearances. ==Tournaments== Teams listed are those that qualified from the Top League for the title play-offs in each season, or the top four teams where there were no play-offs. Results of the play-offs are written so that the score of the team in each row is mentioned first. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; line-height:100%; font-size:100%; width:60%;" |- ! colspan="4" style="border:0px" | Legend |- | style="height:10px; width:5%; background:#d0ffd0;" | | style="width:30%;" | Cup winner
(knockout play-offs). | rowspan="2" style="width:5%; | | rowspan="2" style="width:60%; | Pos = Log Position, P = Games Played, W = Games Won, D = Games Drawn, L = Games Lost, PF = Points For, PA = Points Against, Diff = Points Difference, TB = Try Bonus Points, LB = Losing Bonus Points, SP = Starting Points for Group Stage, Pts = Log Points, Semi = Semi-final, Refs = References |- | style="height:10px;"| {{dagger}}|| Top League title winner. |} Suntory Sungoliath 12–8 Panasonic Wild Knights ===Top League and All-Japan titles: 2017 onward=== There were no title-play-offs in 2018, and the team on top of the league after the round-robin stage was crowned the Top League title winner. However, the top three teams progressed to the [[All-Japan Rugby Football Championship|All-Japan Championship]]. The All-Japan Championship doubled as the Top League Champions Cup title from 2018 onward, with university teams excluded. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Top League and All-Japan title (2017–present) !rowspan=2 style="padding:1px;"| Year !rowspan=2 style="padding:2px;"| {{nowrap|Cup period}} !rowspan=2 style="width:3.2em;"|{{Tooltip|Pos|Position in regular season standings}} !rowspan=2 style="width:12.5em;"|Team !colspan=9|Top League regular season !colspan=2|Play-offs !rowspan=2 style="padding:1px;"|{{Tooltip|Ref|References}} |- !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|Pts|Points total in regular season standings}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|W|Won}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|D|Drew}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|L|Lost}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|PF|Points scored for}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|PA|Points scored against}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|Diff|Difference of points scored for and against}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|TB|Try bonus points for 4 tries or more in a match}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|LB|Losing bonus points a loss by 7 or less}} !style="width:3.3em"|{{Tooltip|Semi|Semi-final}} !style="width:3.3em"|{{Tooltip|Final|Grand final}} |- !scope="row" rowspan=4|[[2017–18 Top League|2018]] |rowspan=4|6 January

9 February | 1 ||bgcolor="#d0ffd0" style="text-align:left;"| [[Panasonic Wild Knights]]{{dagger}} | 36 || 7 || 0 || 0 || 224 || 105 || 119 || 4 || 0 || 4 | — ||55–15||45–22 |rowspan=4|{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyarchive.net/Pagine/StagioneCompetizioni.aspx?ID=96&Stagione=2013/14 |title=2013/14 Top League |publisher= The Rugby Archive}} |- | 2 ||align=left| [[Suntory Sungoliath]] | 32 || 6 || 0 || 1 || 261 || 169 || 92 || 4 || 0 || 4 | — ||27–19||22–45 |- | 3 ||align=left| [[Kobelco Steelers]] | 24 || 4 || 0 || 3 || 223 || 194 || 29 || 5 || 1 || 2 | — || 19–27||— |- | 4 ||align=left| [[Toshiba Brave Lupus]] | 23 || 4 || 0 || 3 || 181 || 151 || 30 || 2 || 3 || 2 | — ||15–55||— |} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align:center; line-height:100%; font-size:100%; width:75%;" |- ! colspan="4" style="border:0px" |{{pad|2.2em}}Competition rules |- | colspan="4" | '''Points breakdown:'''
* 4 points for a win
* 2 points for a draw
* 1 bonus point for a loss by seven points or less
* 1 bonus point for scoring four or more tries in a match
* 4, 3, 2, or 1 starting points in the group stage for 1st through 4th respectively in the pool stage (seasons 2014–15 and 2015–16 only)
'''Classification:'''
Teams standings are calculated as follows:
* Log points
* Difference between points for and against
* Total number of points for
* Number of matches won
* Aggregate number of points scored in matches between tied teams |} ===Play-offs and Top League title: 2010 to 2013=== {{expand section|results for 2010 to 2013|date=January 2015}} {{Football kit and logo |logo=Microsoft Cup logo.png |title=Microsoft Cup banner 2005–2009.|logo_size=260px |nokit=true |align=right |margin_left=1em |margin_top=0.9em |margin_right=0 |margin_bottom=0.36em}} ===Microsoft Cup and Top League title: 2007 to 2009=== For the 2006–07 season the tournament was expanded to fourteen teams and the Top League and Microsoft Cup competitions were combined. Only the top four teams on the regular season table progressed to title play-offs and the winner of the knockout competition was awarded both the Microsoft Cup and the Top League title. Video referee (TMO) decisions were introduced for the 2009 Cup series. The naming rights partnership with Microsoft for the knockout competition ended after the 2009 Cup final. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Top League Championship play-off tournament (2007–2013) !rowspan=2 style="padding:1px;"| Year !rowspan=2 style="padding:2px;"| {{nowrap|Cup period}} !rowspan=2|{{Tooltip|Pos|Position in regular season standings}} !rowspan=2 style="width:13em;"|Team !colspan=9|Top League regular season !colspan=2|Play-off results !rowspan=2 style="padding:1px;"|{{Tooltip|Ref|References}} |- !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|Pts|Points total in regular season standings}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|W|Won}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|D|Drew}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|L|Lost}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|PF|Points scored for}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|PA|Points scored against}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|Diff|Difference of points scored for and against}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|TB|Try bonus points for 4 tries or more in a match}} !style="width:2em"|{{Tooltip|LB|Losing bonus points a loss by 7 or less}} !style="width:3.8em"|{{Tooltip|Semi|Semi-final}} !style="width:3.8em"|{{Tooltip|Final|Grand final}} |- !scope="row" rowspan=4|[[2008–09 Top League#Cup|2009]] |rowspan=4|17 February

* Total number of points for
* Number of matches won
* Aggregate number of points scored in matches between tied teams |} ===Top League, separate Microsoft Cup: 2004 to 2006=== For the first three seasons the competition format was a single round-robin tournament contested by twelve teams, with the team finishing top of the table winning the Top League title. {{note|tl-2005a|α}} Toshiba Brave Lupus won the Top League and Microsoft Cup double. {{note|tl-2005b|β}} The number of tries and goals being equal, the result was decided in favour of Yamaha over Toyota by a lottery at Hanazono after the game. {{note|tl-2005c|γ}} Reigning Microsoft Cup holders the NEC Green Rockets were knocked out at the quarter final stage. {{note|tl-2004d|δ}} In 2003–04, Kobe Steel won the Top League but NEC won the Microsoft Cup. The League and Cup were separate competitions prior to 2007.

revision.text:
[[File:American Furniture Mart Building 2.JPG|thumb|Chicago's Furniture Mart Building<ref name=Chicago_History>{{cite web |url=http://chsmedia.org/media/fa/fa/LIB/CHlist.htm |title=Guide to articles in Chicago History magazine |last1= Roth |first1=Marian |last2= |first2= |date=2015 |website= Chicago History|publisher= |access-date=September 4, 2015 |quote=Topic: April 18, 1925 was a raw, cold day, but a large crowd had gathered outside Chicago's Furniture Mart on North Lake Shore Drive for the opening of the Woman's World's Fair, an exposition to publicize the entry of women into nearly every field of endeavor.}}</ref>]] The first ''' Woman's World's Fair ''' was held in [[Chicago]] in 1925. The idea of the completely women-run fair was to display the progress of ideas, work, and products of twentieth-century women.
== Description == The first Women's World's Fair was held April 18–25 of 1925 in Chicago at the [[680 N Lake Shore Drive|American Furniture Mart Building]] and officially opened by First Lady [[Grace Coolidge]].{{sfn|Kane|1997|page=125}}<ref name=Am_Insur>{{cite journal |last= |first= |last2= |first2= |date= |title=1925 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AxvxAAAAMAAJ&q=The+first+Woman%E2%80%99s+World+Fair+was+held+in+Chicago+on+April+18%E2%80%9325,+1925.&dq=The+first+Woman%E2%80%99s+World+Fair+was+held+in+Chicago+on+April+18%E2%80%9325,+1925. |journal=Journal of American Insurance |publisher= |volume=40 |issue= |page=8 |quote=First Woman's World Fair opened April 18 in Chicago by Mrs. Calvin Coolidge, First Lady of the U.S. }}</ref> The eight-day fair was the idea of [[Helen Bennett (journalist)|Helen Bennett]]{{sfn|Ganz|2012|page=101}} and [[Ruth Hanna McCormick]]. It was run entirely by women and consisted of 280 booths representing some seventy women occupations. The fair drew about 200,000 visitors, earning a net of some $50,000.<ref name=Sawyers>{{cite news |last=Sawyers |first=June |date=May 15, 1988 |title=A Fair First In The Women's Movement |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-05-15/features/8803160977_1_women-s-movement-cow-helen-bennett |newspaper= Chicage Tribune |location= Chicago, Il|access-date=September 4, 2015|quote=On April 25, 1925, the first Woman's World Fair closed a successful eight-day run at the Furniture Mart on North Lake Shore Drive. The fair, which highlighted women`s achievements in art, commerce and industry, attracted more than 200,000 visitors, presented more than 100 exhibitions of women in business and earned a net income of $50,000. }}</ref>
The fair's purpose was to display women's ideas, work, and products for the twentieth century. At the 1876 [[Centennial Exposition]] there had been a Women's Pavilion funded and organized by women and in particular [[Elizabeth Duane Gillespie]]. The building was over {{convert|200|sqft}} and it was in the shape of a [[Maltese cross]].<ref name=firstww>[https://archive.org/stream/centennialexposi00ingr#page/116/mode/2up/search/gillespie+pavilion Women's pavilion], The Centennial Exposition, Page 116, Retrieved 11 September 2015</ref> The Chicago World's Fair of 1893 demonstrated some women's handicrafts in a sewing exhibit, but this fair was to show the progress women had made in seventy industries since then.{{sfn|Kane|1997|page=125}} A side benefit of the fair was that it raised money for the women's [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] organizations. The exhibits showed women's accomplishments in the arts, literature, science, and industry. These exhibits were also an inspiration to young women in their new careers. One of the exhibitors was [[Illinois Bell Telephone Company]]. Others were newspapers, manufacturers, hospitals, banks, and retail stores. Many local enterprises had employment opportunities.{{r|Enc_of_Chicago}}
Women lawyers, inventors, and artists had booths demonstrating women's contributions in these fields. As an example, American sculptor [[Harriet Whitney Frishmuth]] was represented by her 1920 bronze work ''Joy of the Waters''.{{sfn|Gerdts|1989|page=128}} Women's organizations were represented by the [[Women's Trade Union League]], Business and Professional Women's Club, the Visiting Nurse Association, the [[YWCA]], [[Hull House]], the Illinois Club for Catholic Women, and the Auxiliary House of the Good Shepherd.<ref name=Enc_of_Chicago>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Woman's World's Fair, 1925 |URL= http://encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/1374.html |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Chicago |author=Maureen A. Flanagan |year=2005 |publisher=Chicago Historical Society |location=Chicago, Illinois |id= }}</ref>
== Speeches == A group of about one thousand women from [[Sycamore, Illinois]], on April 23 had breakfast with famous women. An all woman's orchestra furnished music. The speakers were women of notoriety which included women authors, business women, and various women artisans. The speeches were limited to five minutes. The main speaker was [[Nellie Tayloe Ross]], the only state governor there. Another speaker was the collector of internal revenue of Chicago. Another was the secretary of the Cabinet Department of Commerce for President [[Herbert Hoover]]. The medical profession was represented by Dr. [[Alice Hamilton]] of [[Harvard University]]. The legal profession was represented by Judge [[Kathryn Sellers]] of [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name=True_Repub>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Woman's World's Fair in Chicago |url= |newspaper=The True Republican |location=Sycamore, Illinois |date=April 29, 1925 |access-date= }}</ref>
== Program == Whiting Hall was visited by the women after the speeches. The booths where artistically decorated showing some of a hundred or so different occupations in which women were employed. Some of these were antique needlework, pottery, silver fox farming, and goat breeding. Examples that received special attention were nurses and welfare workers. A key note was emphasis on earnestness, punctuality and thoroughness in whatever line of work was undertaken.<ref name=True_Repub/>
A unique feature of the first Woman's World's Fair was a daily program. There was a particular topic for each day. Besides being instructive it was entertaining. Music and dancing were especially emphasized each day. Bennett was the general director of the fair. The woman's fair was a success and held for three additional years.<ref name=Enc_of_Chicago/><ref name=True_Repub/>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== Sources == *{{cite book|last=Ganz|first=Cheryl R.|title=The 1933 Chicago World's Fair: A Century of Progress|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u2UNe2gpkksC&pg=PA101|date=January 2012|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-07852-1|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Gerdts|first=Abigail Booth |title=An American Collection: Paintings and Sculpture from the National Academy of Design|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TotIAQAAIAAJ|year=1989|publisher=The Academy|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Kane |first=Joseph Nathan |date=1997 |title=Famous First Facts, Fifth Edition |url= |location= |publisher=The H. W. Wilson Company |quote=The first Woman's World Fair was held in Chicago, IL, April 18–25, 1925, to demonstrate women's progress in 70 industries. At the Chicago World's Fair of 1893, women's handicrafts had been featured only at the sewing exhibit. The Woman's World Fair was officially opened by Grace Coolidge, the wife of President Calvin Coolidge. |isbn=0-8242-0930-3|ref=harv}}
== External links == *[http://encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/11230.html Woman's World Fair Souvenir Program - Chicago Historical Society.]
